questions.text:
37. Which of the following complications are associated with diabetic neuropathy?

* Stocking-and-glove polyneuropathy

* Autonomic neuropathy 

* Mononeuropathy 

* Distal symmetric polyneuropathy
questions.solution:
Complications of diabetic neuropathy are distal symmetric polyneuropathy, stocking-and-glove polyneuropathy, autonomic neuropathy, and mononeuropathy. 

Long-standing diabetes mellitus can lead to diabetic neuropathy, which is one of its microvascular complications. This can present in the following ways:

* Distal symmetric polyneuropathy (option 4): It is the most common form of diabetic neuropathy. It presents with distal sensory loss and pain in a stocking-and-glove (option 1) distribution and predisposes to foot ulceration. As the disease progresses, pain subsides while sensory deficits persist, and the patient develops motor weakness. On clinical examination, there may be loss of ankle reflexes, impaired position sense, muscle atrophy, or foot drop.

* Autonomic neuropathy (option 2): It is a common complication and presents with postural hypotension, silent myocardial infarction, hypoglycemia unawareness, erectile dysfunction, overflow incontinence, gastroparesis, and enteropathy with constipation or diarrhea.

* Mononeuropathy (option 3): It affects peripheral nerves (median, ulnar, radial) and cranial nerves (especially oculomotor). Mononeuropathy multiplex can also occur.

* Proximal motor neuropathy (diabetic amyotrophy): It involves the lumbar plexus or femoral nerve, leading to severe pain in the thigh or hip. It is associated with hip flexor or extensor weakness.

questions.text: 38. A neonate is born with extensive skin blistering at birth, a hoarse cry, and erosions in the oral cavity and larynx. Following examination and investigations, a diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa (EB) is made. Direct immunofluorescence shows a split within the lamina lucida. This severe variant is most likely:
questions.solution:
The given clinical features, along with direct immunofluorescence showing a split within the lamina lucida, most likely point towards a diagnosis of junctional epidermolysis bullosa (JEB).

Epidermolysis bullosa is a group of congenital mechanobullous disorders that arise after trauma and are common on the hands, feet, elbows, and knees. It can be divided into 4 groups based on the level of blister formation:

Group Defective protein

Features
Epidermolysis bullosa simplex K5/K14
  • Intraepidermal blister with a split in the basal layer
  • Oral involvement is rare
  • Mostly heals without scarring
Junctional epidermolysis bullosa Laminin
  • Dermoepidermal junction blister with a split in the lamina lucida layer
  • Perioral laryngeal involvement is frequent
  • May heal with scarring
Dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa Collagen VII in anchoring fibrils
  • Subepidermal tense blisters with a defect in the sublamina densa
  • Frequent mucosal involvement
  • Heals with scarring
Kindler epidermolysis bullosa Kindlin-1

Mixed type involving both dermo-epidermal and subepidermal blisters.


The diagnosis of epidermolysis bullosa (EB) initially relies on careful clinical evaluation, detailed family history, and determination of the level and severity of blistering. In neonates, where clinical signs may be subtle or misleading, confirmation often requires microscopic examination of a skin biopsy. Genetic and molecular testing can further help in identifying specific subtypes.

There is currently no cure for EB. Management is primarily supportive, focusing on protecting the skin, avoiding triggers, and relieving symptoms such as pain and itching. The goal is to prevent complications and improve the patient’s quality of life.

Pearl PM1875: Dermoepidermal Junction/Basement Membrane Zone

* The junction between epidermis and dermis is called the basement membrane zone or dermoepidermal junction and consists of a number of extracellular macromolecules.

* As many of these components are glycoproteins, the BMZ can be recognized histologically by staining with PAS stain.

* Ultrastructural examination by electron microscopy shows 2 different layers with different optical densities

* Lamina Lucida - upper, less electron dense layer

* Lamina Densa - lower, more electron dense layer

* This zone is composed of 3 components : 1. Hemidesmosome 2. Anchoring Filaments 3. Anchoring Fibrils.

1.HEMIDESMOSOME

* Hemidesmosomes are multiprotein complexes that facilitate the stable adhesion of basal epithelial cells to the underlying basement membrane.

* The intermediate keratin filaments K5/K14 present within the basal keratinocytes attach to the hemidesmosomes at the base of the cell.

* The major hemidesmosomal Protein is Bullous Pemphigoid Antigen-1 (BPAg1 or BP230) and this attaches to the transmembrane component protein BPAg2 (BP180) below.

* The other hemidesmosomal protein Plectin is attached to the transmembrane component protein called as α6β4 integrin below.

2.ANCHORING FILAMENTS/Lamina Lucida and Lamina Densa

* The anchoring filaments form the Lamina Lucida layer.

* Anchoring filaments consist of Laminin5/332 proteins that connect BPAg2 and α6β4 integrin above to Lamina Densa below.

* Lamina Densa consists mainly of type IV Collagen and other proteins like Nidogen.  

3.ANCHORING FIBRILS

* These are ultrastructurally U shaped structures that attach the Lamina Densa above to the underlying connective tissue below in dermis.

* Type VII Collagen is the major protein in anchoring fibrils.



Blistering disorders in the DEJ/BMZ arise due to defects or antibodies against any of the above mentioned proteins.

Image: Gene/protein systems within the cutaneous basement membrane zone that can harbour mutations and result in blistering of the skin in different forms of epidermolysis bullosa (EB). BP, bullous pemphigoid

questions.text: 39. A 50-year-old female complains of lower backache. Her bone mineral density is measured and her T-score is found to be -1.8. What does her T-score signify?
questions.solution:
A T-score of -1.8 signifies osteopenia. (T-score in osteopenia: -1 to -2.5).

Osteopenia refers to low bone mass with a T score of -1 to -2.5.

T-score is the comparison of the bone mineral density of a patient to that of a 30-year-old healthy individual.

Osteoporosis is caused due to the reduction in the strength of the bone that leads to an increased risk of fractures. WHO defines osteoporosis as a T-score less than -2.5. 

A T-score of -1 or higher is considered normal.

Pearl PM1958: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

* Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.

* Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.

* Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: 40. A research fellow in biochemistry is studying the lac operon concept of gene regulation. He cultures E. coli in a glucose-deficient and lactose-containing medium. Which of the following genes expressed in this condition helps convert lactose to galactose and glucose?
questions.solution:
The gene marked as 2 is the lac Z gene, which codes for β-galactosidase. This enzyme converts lactose to galactose and glucose.

Lac operon concept

Jacob and Monod studied the Lac operon model, which is the regulation of lactose metabolism by the intestinal bacterium Escherichia coli. It is switched on when the bacteria have to utilize lactose for utilization. Otherwise, it is switched off. It contains the following genes:

* lac I- it codes for the repressor protein

* cAMP response element (CRE)- It is activated by binding the cyclic AMP activator protein (CAP). When activated, it increases the binding of RNA polymerase and increases gene expression.

* Promoter site- It is the site where RNA polymerase binds the gene for transcription. 

* Operator site- It is the site where repressor protein binds.

* lac Z gene- It codes for β-Galactosidase that hydrolyzes lactose to galactose and glucose. 

* lac Y- It encodes for lactose permease, which increases the permeability of lactose into the cells.

* lac A- It encodes for thiogalactoside transacetylase.



For the working of Lac operon, the operator site should be free and the CRE site should be activated.

1. When glucose is present and lactose is absent- The bacteria utilize glucose. The lac I gene produces repressor protein, which binds to the operator site. Repressor-operator binding prevents the binding of RNA polymerase and, consequently, prevents transcription of the lacZ, lacY, and lacA structural genes into a polycistronic mRNA. 

In addition to this, excess glucose inhibits adenylyl cyclase. Therefore, the production of cAMP is reduced. Less cAMP means less cyclic AMP activator protein (CAP) binding to CRE. CRE is not activated, and lac operon is switched off.

2. When glucose is absent and lactose is present- Bacteria utilize lactose. The lactose inactivates the repressor protein. This prevents the binding of repressor protein to the operator site. The operator site is now free and RNA polymerase can start with the transcription. The low glucose level causes an increase in the adenylyl cyclase activity, and increases the cAMP levels. This increases the binding of CAP to CRE, which in turn activates the transcription of the lacZ, lacY, and lacA structural genes into polycistronic mRNA. 

3. When both glucose and lactose are present- The bacteria utilize glucose. The unused lactose binds to the repressor protein and renders it inactive. The operator site is free. However, the increased glucose level inhibits adenylyl cyclase and decreases the cAMP levels. Therefore, even though the operator site is free, CRE is not activated, which leads to the switching off of the lac operon.



Pearl PM1108: Difference between Lac & tryptophan operon

Lac Operon

Tryptophan Operon

Inducible gene complex

Repressible gene complex

Catabolic system

Anabolic system

Contain 3 structural genes

Contains 5 structural gene

Produce 3 inducible enzymes

Produce 5 Repressible enzymes

Repressor protein is active

Repressor protein is inactive

High lactose turn transcription on , in low glucose level

High tryptophan transcription off

Lactose act as inducer

Tryptophan act as co-repressor

Has only 1 type of gene regulation-Negative  control

Has only 1 type of gene regulation-Negative control

Usually OFF, Get activated under certain conditions

Usually ON, inactive at high level of tryptophan.

cAMP is necessary for CAP to switch transcription on

cAMP is not  necessary

questions.text: 41. An enzyme X catalyzes the following reaction. Based on this, to which class of enzymes does X belong?
questions.solution:
The image shows the cleavage of a carbon–carbon (C–C) bond without the involvement of water. Hence, the enzyme X belongs to the class of lyases.



Pearl PM2426: Enzyme classification

There are seven groups of enzymes according to IUBMB.

E.C. NO. Enzyme class Type of reaction catalyzed with examples
1 Oxidoreductases

Catalyze redox reactions

  • Dehydrogenase
  • Oxygenase
  • Oxidase
  • Catalase
  • Peroxidase
2 Transferases

Catalyze the transfer of functional groups from one substrate to another.

  • Kinases
  • Transaminases
  • Transmethylases
3 Hydrolases

Catalyze hydrolytic cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds.

  • Lipase
  • Arginase
  • Pepsin
  • Esterase
4 Lyases

Catalyze the cleavage of C-C, C-O, C-N, and other covalent bonds by atom elimination, thereby generating double bonds.

  • Aldolase
  • Fumarase
  • HMG-CoA lyase
  • Arginosuccinase
5 Isomerases

Catalyze structural changes within a molecule.

  • Phosphohexoisomerase
  • Mutase
  • Racemase
6 Ligases

Catalyze the joining together of two molecules in reactions.

  • Acetyl CoA carboxylase
  • PRPP synthetase
  • Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase
  • Glutamine synthetase
7 Translocases Catalyze the movement of molecules or ions across membranes.

questions.text: 42. A 9-month-old child comes to the immunisation clinic with low-grade fever and a mild cough for two days, but is otherwise active and feeding well. The mother is worried and asks if the scheduled measles vaccine should be given today. What should the health worker do?

choices.text: Defer vaccination until the child fully recovers
Give only oral vaccines, defer injectables
Vaccinate the child as per schedule
Give half the dose to reduce risk of adverse reaction

questions.solution:
The health worker should vaccinate the child as per the schedule.

Vaccinate the child as per schedule, as minor acute illnesses such as low-grade fever (<38°C), mild cough, cold, diarrhoea, mild skin infections, or malnutrition are not valid reasons to postpone routine immunisation. Missing an opportunity unnecessarily leaves the child vulnerable to vaccine-preventable diseases, which can have severe complications.

Conditions commonly misperceived as contraindications: mild ARI (cold, mild cough), low-grade fever, mild diarrhoea, malnutrition, current antibiotic use, family history of seizures, prematurity, convalescence from mild illness.

Immunisation is rarely contraindicated. It can be deferred in moderate to severe sickness, as it might inhibit the immune response. Contraindications of Measles vaccination include radiation therapy and pregnancy.

Other options:

Option A: Defer vaccination until fully recovered is incorrect. It increases the risk of exposure to measles during the delay.

Option B: No evidence supports withholding injectable vaccines for mild illnesses. The vaccine route is determined by the antigen, not by mild symptoms.

Option D. Giving half the dose is dangerous and makes the vaccine ineffective. Vaccines should never be given in reduced doses. Always provide the full recommended dose and route.

Pearl PM0701: Contraindications to Vaccines

Vaccine

Contraindications

All

Anaphylactic reaction to previous dose

Live vaccines (MMR, BCG, Varicella)

Pregnancy

Radiation therapy

Yellow fever

Egg allergy

Immunodeficiency

BCG

Symptomatic HIV infection

Influenza

Egg allergy

Pertussis-containing vaccines

Evolving neurological disorders

questions.text: 43. The initial dose of drug X, having a capacity-limited elimination, is doubled. Which of the parameters shall increase following the dose change?
questions.solution:
The half-life of drug X, which exhibits capacity-limited elimination, increases with an increase in the administered dose.

Capacity-limited elimination is also known as zero-order kinetics or Michaelis-Menten elimination. In these reactions, the clearance, i.e., the theoretical volume of plasma from which the drug is completely removed per unit time, decreases (Option A) as the drug concentration increases. Clearance is defined as the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance per unit time. It is calculated using the formula :



where,

* C​ stands for Renal clearance of substance X (mL/min)

* U stands for Urine concentration of X (mg/mL)

* V stands for Urine flow rate (mL/min), and

* P​ stands for Plasma concentration of X (mg/mL)

As drug clearance decreases, the half-life of the drug is prolonged. Half-life is the time taken for the plasma concentration to be reduced by 50% and is calculated by the formula:



The rate of elimination, that is, the amount of drug removed from the body per unit time (Option B) remains constant, irrespective of the drug concentration.

The volume of distribution (Vd, Option D) depends on the drug’s properties (lipophilicity, protein binding, ionisation at physiological pH, etc.) and, therefore, does not change with the dose of the drug. It refers to the volume that would accommodate the entire drug in the body if the concentration were the same as in plasma and is calculated as:



Pearl PM2378: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: 44. A 24-year-old male patient presents with dizziness and fatigue during a marathon. The patient is oriented and diaphoretic. Vitals reveal heart rate of 100/min, blood pressure of 90/60 mm of Hg and temperature of 101 °F. ECG is normal. His condition improves gradually after IV fluids. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features of dizziness, fatigue, hypotension, preserved thermoregulatory control (temperature < 105 °F) and absence of central nervous system dysfunction following endurance exercise (marathons) and exposure to high ambient temperature most likely points to a diagnosis of heat exhaustion.

Heat exhaustion is caused by excessive exposure to heat, leading to nausea, vomiting, dizziness, thirst, fatigue, headache, sweating, and decreased urine output. Body temperature may rise but does not exceed 40.5°C (105°F). Heat exhaustion is distinct from heat stroke as the body maintains thermoregulation and no CNS dysfunction occurs. Prompt treatment is essential to prevent progression to life-threatening heat stroke. Diagnosis involves ruling out heat stroke.

Heat stroke (Option A) is characterized by a raised core temperature of  > 40.5°C [105°F] due to loss of thermoregulatory function and failure of sweating. Predisposing factors include high temperature, increased humidity, infections, old age, lack of acclimatization, and alcoholism. Heat stroke can be of two types:

* Classic heat stroke (CHS) seen in those with chronic diseases who are predisposed to heat-related illnesses. 

* Exertional heat stroke (EHS) is seen in young, previously healthy people with prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures. 

Heat stroke usually presents as a sudden collapse. The skin is dry, flushed, and hot. Sweating is absent in CHS but present in about 50% of cases of EHS. Tachypnea (rapid Kussmaul breathing), tachycardia, hypotension, and widened pulse pressure are other findings.

CNS dysfunction includes delirium, coma, and convulsions. Thermal cardiomyopathy and heat-related reversible increase in cardiac biomarker levels are also seen. ECG findings include tachyarrhythmias, nonspecific ST-T wave changes, and heat-related ischemia or infarction. Other complications include rhabdomyolysis, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), and multiorgan failure.

Heat stroke is managed by rapid cooling, continuous monitoring with a rectal thermistor (flexible thermometer), fluid resuscitation and correction of electrolyte and metabolic abnormalities (hyponatremia and hypoglycemia).

Other options : 

Option C: Heat syncope (exercise associated collapse) is when the patient collapses following endurance exercise or prolonged standing in the heat. Heat stress causes relative volume depletion, decreased vasomotor tone, and peripheral vasodilation. This results in decreased venous return and postural hypotension, especially in nonacclimated elderly individuals. After removal from heat source, most patients recover promptly with cooling and rehydration. 

Option D: Heat cramps are painful muscle spasms caused by the loss of water and salt in high temperatures due to profuse sweating.

Pearl PM2132: Hyperthermic disorders

Hyperthermic disorders Mechanisms
Heat edema Cutaneous vasodilation and pooling of interstitial fluid leads to swelling of hands, feet, and ankles
Heat syncope Vasodilation and volume depletion(from sweating) following exercise or prolonged standing with consequent systemic and cerebral hypotension
Heat cramps Deficiency of sodium, potassium, and water at an intracellular level, leading to intermittent, painful, and involuntary spasmodic contractions of skeletal muscles
Heat exhaustion

Results from prolonged strenuous activity. There is water or salt depletion, but thermoregulatory mechanisms are maintained. Temperature < 40.5° C
Heatstroke

Thermoregulatory mechanisms are lost

Temperature > 40.5° C

questions.text: 45. An 8-year-old male child presents with pain in the right hip, particularly during passive movement. The X-ray of the pelvis is shown below. Which movements are expected to be restricted on examination?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an 8-year-old boy with hip pain on passive movement and the X-ray showing a fragmented head of the right femur, suggests a diagnosis of Perthes disease, in which abduction and internal rotation of the hip are restricted.

Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, is the avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 4-9 years. The incidence is higher in boys than in girls.

It is usually a unilateral disease, but it can occur bilaterally in 10% of cases. Risk factors include low birth weight, passive smoking, family history, low socioeconomic status, and attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder.

The disease is characterised by the disruption of blood flow to the femoral head, resulting in osteonecrosis and the cessation of bone growth. The lateral epiphyseal artery is involved. Over time, healing and fibrosis occur as new blood vessels infiltrate the dead bone and remove the necrotic bone, which leads to a loss of bone mass and weakening of the femoral head. 

The condition usually presents with painless limping; however, pain may occur with synovitis or activity. Physical examination reveals pain on passive movement of the hip, and abduction and internal rotation are limited. Long-standing disease can lead to hip flexion contracture and loss of epiphyseal height and proximal femoral deformity, resulting in weakening of musculature around the hip, giving a Trendelenburg gait. 

X-ray findings depend on the stages 

* Initial phase: Medial joint space widening and increased density in the ossific nucleus

* Fragmentation phase: Alternating patches of sclerosis and fibrosis

* Re-ossification phase: Complete removal of necrotic bone. Epiphyseal density is regained in this phase

* Remodelling phase: Remodelling occurs until skeletal maturity is attained

The radiograph below shows features of bone necrosis followed by remodelling in Perthes disease.

questions.text: 46. A new rapid test for malaria has a sensitivity of 95% and a specificity of 85%. What does this mean in practical terms?

choices.text: The test correctly identifies 95% of diseased individuals
The test correctly identifies 95% of non-diseased individuals
The test correctly identifies 85% of diseased individuals
The individuals who test positive, 95% have the disease

questions.solution:
This means the test correctly identifies 95% of diseased individuals and 85% of non-diseased individuals.

Sensitivity is the ability of a test to correctly identify those who have the disease (true positives). So, a sensitivity of 95% means that 95% of people with malaria will be correctly identified by the test. 

Sensitivity = TP / (TP + FN) or Sensitivity = 1 – false-negative rate.

Specificity is the ability of a test to correctly identify those who do not have the disease (true negatives). So, a specificity of 85% means that 85% of people without malaria will be correctly identified as disease-free by the test.

Specificity = TN / (TN + FP) or specificity = 1 – false-positive rate.

Other options:

Option B and C: The test correctly identifies 95% of non-diseased individuals and 85% of diseased individuals ;it occurs when we reverse the definition of senstivity and specificity .

Option D: The individuals who test positive, 95% will have the disease ; it confuses sensitivity and specificity with positive predictive value (PPV). PPV depends on disease prevalence and cannot be directly determined from sensitivity and specificity alone.

Pearl PM0358: Validity of a Screening Test

* Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.

* It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.

* These are the inherent properties of a screening test.

* PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.

* Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.



Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN


* PPV varies directly with prevalence

* NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: 47. A 54-year-old man presents with several months of abdominal discomfort and bloating. He recently developed a serpiginous, urticarial rash over his thighs. On further questioning, he reports frequently walking barefoot and rarely using footwear. Stool microscopy reveals the characteristic rhabditiform larvae. Which of the following statements about the causative organism is true?

choices.text: Rhabditiform larvae is the infective stage
Hyperinfection is a complication of the causative organism
The adult worms are found in the caecum of humans

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with serpiginous rash along with a history of walking barefoot and rhabditiform larvae on stool microscopy is suggestive of Strongyloides stercoralis infection, and hyperinfection is a known complication.

The adult worm is found in the small intestine (duodenum and jejunum) of humans (Option D) and exists in three forms: adult, larvae (four stages), and egg. They are ovoviviparous, i.e., eggs once laid immediately hatch out to larvae.

The mode of infection is by penetration of skin by the filariform larva (L3) when a person walks barefoot (Option A) and through autoinfection, in which the rhabditiform larvae metamorphose in the bowel into filariform larvae and then penetrate the perianal skin. S. stercoralis involves only one definitive host, that is, humans (Option B), although dogs can also harbor the parasite.

Clinical features include:

* Asymptomatic infection in more than 50% of chronically infected people 

* Recurrent maculopapular or urticarial rashes primarily involving the buttocks, perineum, and thighs

* Pathognomonic serpiginous urticarial rash (commonly on the thigh) called larva currens (or racing larva) caused by migrating larvae

* Pulmonary symptoms occurring secondary to underlying chronic obstructive lung disease 

The image below shows larva currens:



Stool microscopy reveals the characteristic rhabditiform larvae (diagnostic form).

Complications of strongyloidiasis include hyperinfection syndrome, resulting from repeated autoinfection cycles (Option C), and disseminated strongyloidiasis, where larvae may invade the gastrointestinal tract and migrate to various organs, including the CNS, peritoneum, liver, and kidneys. 

The image given below shows the life cycle of Strongyloides stercoralis:

questions.text: 48. A 7-year-old boy is brought in with the following lesion on the scalp. KOH mount suggests dermatophyte infection. What finding is most likely under Wood's lamp examination?
questions.solution:
The lesion is typical of favus, caused by Trichophyton schoenleinii, which shows a pale or dull green fluorescence under Wood’s lamp examination.

Favus is a chronic, scarring type of tinea capitis. The clinical features include:

* Cup-shaped yellow crusts (scutula)

* Patchy alopecia, which may progress to scarring

* Mousy or musty odor (due to microbial metabolism)

Wood’s lamp examination uses long-wave UV light (365 nm) in a dark room to detect fluorescence from certain organisms, pigments, or substances in the skin and hair. It is a non-invasive, bedside diagnostic aid in dermatology.

Other options:

Option A: Faint yellow fluorescence is seen in pityriasis versicolor caused by Malassezia furfur.

Option B: Brilliant green fluorescence is classic for Microsporum spp.

Option D: Most of the Trichophyton species are non-fluorescent except Trichophyton schoenleinii.

Pearl PM0260: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

Table: Various diseases and their color on Wood’s lamp examination

Disease

Colour on Wood’s Light

Tinea capitis

 

Microsporum species: brilliant green (M. canis, M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum, M. distortum)

Trichophyton schoenleinii: pale green

Most Trichophyton species, with the exception of T. schoenleinii, are non-fluorescent

Erythrasma

Coral pink

Pityriasis versicolor

Faint yellow

Pseudomonas

Green

Scabies

Fluorescein solution fills the burrows and fluoresces on Wood’s light.

Porphyria

Urine, feces, blister fluid fluoresce red or pink

Vitiligo

Ivory or milky white

questions.text: 49. Identify the instrument given below.
questions.solution:
The instrument shown in the image is Jackson’s double-lumen metal tracheostomy tube.

It has an outer tube, an inner tube, and an obturator (not shown in the image). The outer tube is not split, the inner tube can be fixed to the shield of the outer tube by a lock.

Other options:

Option A: The image below shows a cuffed tracheostomy tube.



Option C: The images below show Fuller’s tracheostomy tube, inner and outer tubes.





Pearl PM2157: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

* Done through the 1st tracheal ring

* An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 

* Done in case of malignancy of the larynx

* Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

* Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings

* Most commonly done tracheostomy

* Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

* Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring

* Done below the isthmus

* Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level

* Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck

questions.text: 50. A 42-year-old woman presents with lesions as shown in the image below, with shortness of breath and velcro-like crackling sounds in the lungs. She has no trouble climbing stairs or combing her hair. Creatine kinase is mildly elevated. Subsequently, a diagnosis of dermatomyositis is made. Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be positive in this case?
questions.solution:
The antibody most likely to be positive in this case is Anti-MDA5.

In the given clinical scenario, the image shows Gottrón's papules (violaceous, erythematous papules overlying the dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal, elbow, or knee joints) with ulcerations. There is no/mild muscle weakness (amyopathic), as evidenced by the patient’s ability to perform daily activities, and a mildly elevated serum creatine kinase (CK). The shortness of breath and velcro-like sounds in the lungs are indicative of ILD. These features are most likely to be seen in the case of Anti-MDA5 positivity.

Dermatomyositis (DM) is an autoimmune disorder predominantly affecting the skin and skeletal muscle. The various manifestations of the disease include proximal myopathy, Gottrón's papules, Gottrón's sign, shawl sign, periungual telangiectasias, mechanic's hand, etc. It is associated with multiple autoantibodies, resulting in varied clinical presentations and associations.

Autoantibodies in dermatomyositis and their clinical associations:

Antibody Clinical Association
Anti-Jo-1 (option C)
  • Myositis with antisynthetase syndrome
  • Clinical features: Mechanic’s hand, interstitial lung disease, non-erosive arthritis
Anti-Mi-2
  • Rash is more prominent than myositis
  • Has a good prognosis
Anti-MDA5 (option D)
  • Rapidly progressive lung disease
  • Cutaneous ulcers
  • Clinically amyopathic
Anti-NXP-2 (option B)
  • Subcutaneous edema
  • Calcinosis
  • Severe muscle weakness
  • Associated with cancer
Anti-TIF1-γ or Anti-p155/140
  • Severe skin manifestations
  • Associated with cancer
Anti-PM-SCL, Anti-Ro, Anti-U1-3 RNP (option A) Polymyositis/ dermatomyositis overlap
Anti-SAE
  • Rash and high prevalence of dysphagia
  • Associated with cancer


Pearl PM0185: Antibodies in Dermatomyositis

* Anti-Mi2 antibodies (directed against a helicase implicated in nucleosome remodeling) show a strong association with prominent Gottron papules and heliotrope rash.

* Anti-Jo1 antibodies (directed against the enzyme histidyl t-RNA synthetase) are associated with interstitial lung disease, nonerosive arthritis, and a skin rash described as “mechanic’s hands.”

* Anti-P155/P140 antibodies (directed against several transcriptional regulators) are associated with paraneoplastic and juvenile cases of dermatomyositis.

questions.text:
51. Match the causative organism to the type of toxin:

Organism  Toxin 
1. Vibrio cholerae a. Neurotoxin 
2. Shigella dysenteriae   b. Enterotoxin
3. Rotavirus c. Cytotoxin
4. Clostridium botulinum d. Enterotoxin
questions.solution:
The correct match is - 

Organism  Toxin 
1. Vibrio cholerae d. Enterotoxin 
2. Shigella dysenteriae c. Cytotoxin
3. Rotavirus b. Enterotoxin
4. Clostridium botulinum a. Neurotoxin 


Vibrio toxin is an enterotoxin with two peptide fragments: B binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors on intestinal epithelial cells, allowing entry of fragment A. Fragment A ADP-ribosylates G proteins, activating adenylate cyclase and increasing intracellular cAMP. Elevated cAMP inhibits sodium absorption and promotes chloride secretion, causing sodium chloride and water accumulation in the intestinal lumen, leading to watery diarrhoea.

Shiga toxin is a cytotoxin. It is structurally and functionally similar to verocytotoxin of EHEC. It inhibits protein synthesis by inhibiting the 60S ribosome. It enhances local vascular damage of the intestine as well as internal organs, such as the kidney and brain.

Rotavirus involves the non-structural protein NSP4 acting as an enterotoxin and inducing secretion by altering epithelial cell function and permeability.

The botulinum toxin released by Clostridium botulinum is a neurotoxin, which causes flaccid paralysis by blocking the release of acetylcholine by inhibiting synaptobrevin.

Examples of various types of toxins -

Enterotoxin Cytotoxin  Neurotoxin 
Cholera toxin     Shigella dysenteriae type 1   Staphylococcus aureus enterotoxin  
Vibrio parahaemolyticus Enterohemorrhagic E. coli Bacillus cereus (emetic) toxin

E. coli

  •  LT and ST of ETEC
  • EAST of EAEC
  • VT of EHEC 
 Clostridioides difficile (toxin B) Clostridium botulinum toxin
Clostridioides difficile (toxin A)    
Rotavirus (NSP4)    
Campylobacter jejuni    


Pearl PM2032: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

* Bordetella pertusis

* Bacillus anthracis

* Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin

* Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

* Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

* Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)

* Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)

* Clostridium difficile

* Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S

* Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: 52. What is the possible diagnosis for a patient with the ECG findings as shown below?
questions.solution:
The ECG image shows diffuse ST-segment elevation characteristic of acute pericarditis.

Acute Pericarditis has four principal diagnostic features: 

* Chest Pain: Sharp, retrosternal or left precordial pain, often pleuritic, aggravated by inspiration or coughing, and relieved by sitting forward.

* Pericardial Friction Rub: Best heard at end-expiration with the patient upright and leaning forward. The rub is rasping, scratching, or grating.

* ECG Findings: Stage 1: Widespread ST elevation, reciprocal depression in aVR, PR segment depression (a sign of atrial involvement) Stage 2: ST segments return to normal Stage 3: T wave inversion Stage 4: ECG normalises after several weeks

* Pericardial Effusion: It can lead to cardiac tamponade and can be diagnosed using echocardiography

Treatment includes NSAIDs (ibuprofen, indomethacin) for pain and inflammation, with gastric protection. Colchicine (for 3 months) can be given to reduce recurrence. Azathioprine or Anakinra may be used in severe and refractory cases.

Other options:

Option A: Inferior wall MI will show ST elevations in leads II, III, aVF

Option C: The ECG findings for pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade are sinus tachycardia, electrical alternans, and low QRS voltages

Option D: The ECG changes of hypothyroidism will include bradycardia with low-voltage complexes.

questions.text: 53. A 55-year-old patient with COPD presents with a persistent chronic cough despite optimal bronchodilator therapy. He is prescribed gefapixant. Which of the following best describes the mechanism by which gefapixant reduces cough?
questions.solution:
Gefapixant is a novel antitussive that reduces chronic cough in COPD by ATP receptor antagonism.

Adenosine triphosphate (ATP) is a potent tussive agent that stimulates cough in patients with asthma and COPD by activating P2X3 receptors on afferent sensory nerves. Gefapixant, a P2X3 receptor antagonist (ATP-gated ion channel blocker), is effective in reducing chronic idiopathic cough. A common side-effect is abnormal taste (dysgeusia).

Transient receptor potential (TRP) antagonists are another novel class of antitussives that target ion channels on airway sensory nerves. TRPV1 is activated by capsaicin, H⁺, and bradykinin, and blocking it can reduce induced cough.

Other options:

Option A: Dextromethorphan is a centrally active N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor antagonist that suppresses the cough reflex by acting on the cough center. However, its exact receptor mechanism remains unclear.

Option C: Moguisteine acts peripherally and opens ATP-sensitive K⁺ channels, thereby inhibiting action potentials involved in the cough reflex.

Option D: Opioids such as codeine and morphine exert their antitussive action by medullary opioid receptor agonism.

questions.text: 54. An investigating officer collects a bullet from the crime scene and compares it with a bullet from the firearm suspected to be used. Which of the following characteristic features will determine the specific firearm that was used?

choices.text: Make and model of the gun
Direction of twist of the rifling

questions.solution:
The secondary markings will determine the specific firearm that was used.

These markings, also known as individual or accidental characteristics, refer to the irregularities on the inner surface of the barrel itself, which are specific to that particular firearm. These markings are caused by the sticking of the particles of the bullet to the bore when shots are fired and are known as "metallic fouling." 

Secondary markings are used to identify a specific gun to the exclusion of all others by the process called bullet fingerprinting.

The class characteristics or the primary markings in a fired bullet are useful in identifying the make and model of the gun involved and are determined before the manufacture of the gun. These markings result from manufacturing specifications, design, and dimensions. They are formed when a bullet passes through a barrel, and the sides are marked by the rifling of the barrel. 

Primary markings are based on the following factors:

* Caliber

* Number of lands and grooves

* Direction of twist of the rifling

* Rate of the twist of the rifling

* Width of the lands and grooves 

The bullet found at the crime scene is known as a crime bullet or exhibit bullet. It is compared with a bullet fired from the suspected weapon, known as a test bullet. The suspected weapon is fired using the same brand and type of ammunition, into a box filled with cotton waste (bullet traps), a bag of rags, a sandbag, oiled sawdust, blocks of ice, water tanks (bullet recovery tank), or against white blotting paper. Cleanly shaven, fresh pork skins are used for comparison with patterns on human skin.

From the fired cartridge case, the caliber and type of cartridge can be determined. From the shape and size of the case and the stampings on the case head, its manufacturer can be determined. The marks left on the fired cartridges by the weapon can also help in the identification.

questions.text: 55. A 45-year-old man with newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of bloating, flatulence, and abdominal discomfort for the past week. He was recently started on dietary modifications and oral anti-diabetic medications. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient’s gastrointestinal symptoms, like bloating, flatulence, and abdominal discomfort, are most likely caused by Acarbose.

Acarbose is a complex oligosaccharide that reversibly inhibits α-glucosidase enzymes, which are responsible for the final step in carbohydrate digestion at the brush border of the small intestinal mucosa. As a result, undigested carbohydrates reach the colon, where they undergo fermentation by gut bacteria, leading to flatulence, abdominal discomfort, and loose stools. This is the main reason for poor patient acceptability of the drug.

Other options:

Option B: Dapagliflozin is an SGLT-2 inhibitor that lowers blood sugar by causing glucosuria. It can cause urinary and genital infections, electrolyte imbalances, ketoacidosis, and frequent urination. Gastrointestinal symptoms are rare, and flatulence and bloating are not typical side effects.

Option C: Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione that activates PPAR-γ receptors, improving insulin sensitivity and reducing circulating insulin levels. It can cause weight gain, fluid retention, and may precipitate heart failure. Long-term use is associated with increased risk of bladder cancer and worsening of diabetic macular edema. It is not responsible for bloating or flatulence, as gastrointestinal side effects are uncommon with this drug.

Option D: Sitagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor that potentiates the action of GLP-1. It is orally absorbed, undergoes minimal metabolism, and is largely excreted unchanged in the urine. Sitagliptin is generally well tolerated. Nausea may occur, but it is not a prominent side effect.

questions.text: 56. A 35-year-old female receiving isoniazid for the treatment of tuberculosis develops tingling sensations in both her upper and lower limbs. The vitamin deficiency responsible for this condition can cause which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the history of treatment with isoniazid indicate vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency, which can increase susceptibility to hormone-dependent cancers such as uterine, breast, and prostate cancers.

Isoniazid, a commonly used anti-tuberculous drug, inhibits pyridoxal kinase, thereby reducing the formation of pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), the active coenzyme form of vitamin B6. The resulting deficiency impairs the activity of multiple PLP-dependent enzymes. This manifests as peripheral neuritis, presenting with tingling sensations in both upper and lower limbs. Therefore, pyridoxine supplementation is routinely given to patients receiving isoniazid.

When vitamin B6 is deficient, the body becomes more sensitive to low levels of estrogens, androgens, cortisol, and vitamin D. This enhanced sensitivity to steroid hormones could promote the formation of hormone-dependent cancers in the uterus, breast, or prostate, and vitamin B6 levels may play a role in determining the prognosis.

Other drugs that can lead to a deficiency of vitamin B6 include oral contraceptives, cycloserine, and ethanol.

Other options:

Option A: Vitamin B6 plays an important role in heme biosynthesis, as ALA synthase, the rate-limiting enzyme of heme biosynthesis, is PLP-dependent. Thus, B6 deficiency can lead to impaired heme production. This impaired heme production manifests as microcytic hypochromic anemia and not macrocytic anemia.

Option C: PLP plays a crucial role in methionine and cysteine metabolism. Cystathionine synthase, the enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine and serine into cystathionine, requires PLP as a cofactor. Hence, B6 deficiency leads to elevated (not reduced) homocysteine levels.

Option D: Dorsal column demyelination is seen in vitamin B12 deficiency, and not B6 deficiency. Vitamin B6 deficiency leads to neurological conditions such as convulsions (due to reduced synthesis of GABA, an inhibitory neurotransmitter) and peripheral neuritis.

questions.text: 57. A patient is posted for an elective procedure under general anesthesia. Being an intern in the anesthetist's team, you are asked to monitor the bispectral Index. What will be the bispectral index (BIS) reading if the patient is still in a state of sedation and not under adequate general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
The range of bispectral index reading if the patient is still in the state of sedation and not under adequate general anesthesia is 65-85.

BIS is a monitoring technique used to check the depth of anesthesia and prevent intraoperative awareness. It processes the EEG and provides an index value between 0 and 100 that indicates the patient’s level of consciousness. BIS monitors examine four components within the EEG that are associated with the anesthetic state.

* Low frequency, as found during deep anesthesia.

* High-frequency beta activation, found during light anesthesia.

* Suppressed EEG waves.

* Burst suppression.

It has numerical values from 0 to 100, with 0 representing isoelectric EEG and 100 being awake CNS. Recommended range of Bispectral index (BIS) for general anesthesia is 40-65.

 BIS 
value		    Interpretation
     80-100    Awake(Respond to normal voice)
     65-85 sedation
     40-65 General anesthesia
      <40  Deep hypnosis(Cortical suppression)
0  Coma (Flatline EEG)


Monitors used to assess the depth of anesthesia are: 

* Electroencephalography (EEG)

* Bispectral index (BIS)

* Entropy

* Evoked responses (EP) - Motor EP, sensory EP (Auditory, visual, brain stem evoked potential)

* Patient state index

* Narcotrend.

questions.text: 58. A 15-year-old boy presented with complaints of paroxysmal sneezing, nasal obstruction, and itching in the nose. Which of the following is false regarding the treatment of his condition?

choices.text: Intranasal cromolyn sodium is recommended for mild disease
Intranasal steroids is recommended for moderate disease
Oral steroids is recommended for severe persistent disease
Immunotherapy is recommended for severe persistent disease for at least a period of 1 month

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of allergic rhinitis. In allergic rhinitis, immunotherapy is recommended for severe persistent disease for a period of at least 1 year, along with a short course of oral steroids.

Allergic rhinitis is an IgE-mediated immunological response of the nasal mucosa to allergens in the environment.

Patients typically present with recurrent bouts of sneezing, nasal obstruction, watery nasal discharge, and itching, and clinical signs include allergic shiners (dark circles around the eyes) and allergic salute (black transverse nasal crease on the dorsum of the nose due to repeated upward rubbing).

Allergic rhinitis can be classified into intermittent and persistent, based on the duration of the disease:

* Intermittent- Symptoms are present for less than 4 days a week, or less than 4 weeks

* Persistent- Symptoms are present for more than 4 days a week, or more than 4 weeks

It can be classified as mild, moderate, or severe based on the severity of the disease:

* Mild- None of the following symptoms are present: sleep impairment, impairment of daily activities, school, or work, or troublesome symptoms.

* Moderate-severe: If at least one of the symptoms mentioned above is present.

Treatment options include:

* Avoidance of the allergen

* Treatment with drugs like oral antihistamines, intranasal corticosteroids, and intranasal cromolyn sodium

* Immunotherapy is through the delivery of allergen in gradually increasing doses till the maintenance dose is reached. It suppresses the development of IgE. It has to be given for a year to see a significant improvement in symptoms.

A step-care approach is recommended for allergic rhinitis and its impact on asthma (ARIA). The treatment of allergic rhinitis includes the following:

* Oral antihistamines or intranasal cromolyn sodium are recommended for mild, intermittent disease(Option A).

* Intranasal corticosteroids are used for moderate disease as monotherapy(Option B).

* Oral antihistamines and intranasal steroids can be used in combination to treat severe diseases(Option C).

* A short course of oral corticosteroids and immunotherapy can be used for severe, persistent disease in case the above intervention fails.

questions.text:
59. Match the following: (Consider only the cell indicated by the arrow)

* Russel body

* Dutcher body

* Howell Jolly Body

* Dohle body
questions.solution:
The correct match is

* - D. Dohle Body

* - C. Howell-Jolly body

* - A. Russel Body

* - B. Dutcher Body

Döhle bodies are patches of dilated endoplasmic reticulum seen in neutrophils that appear as sky-blue cytoplasmic puddles. In sepsis or severe inflammatory disorders (Ex, Kawasaki disease), leukocytosis is often accompanied by morphologic changes in the neutrophils, such as toxic granulations, Döhle bodies, and cytoplasmic vacuoles.

Peripheral blood smear preparation with standard Wright-Giemsa stain shows smooth, round basophilic (purple) particles in eosinophilic erythrocytes, suggestive of Howell-Jolly bodies. Howell-Jolly bodies persist in those with functional hyposplenism or asplenia:

* Autosplenectomy due to sickle cell anemia

* Hereditary spherocytosis

* Megaloblastic anemia

* Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS)

* Radiation therapy

* Severe hemolytic anemia

* Splenectomy following trauma

Russell bodies are eosinophilic, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing cytoplasmic inclusions found in a plasma cell with an excessive synthesis of immunoglobulin. Similar inclusion in the intranuclear area is known as a Dutcher body.

Pearl PM0608: Pathological Cells/Bodies in Multiple Myeloma

* Dutcher bodies - pale-staining, PAS-positive intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). 



Russell bodies - They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig). Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.



* Flame cells - Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm due to vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections

questions.text: 60. A 4-year-old child is brought to the pediatric OPD with complaints of abdominal pain and loose stools for the last 2 days. His mother reports that the stools contain blood and mucus. Antibiotics should be avoided for which of the following causative agents?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette points towards a diagnosis of dysentery (diarrhea with blood and mucus in stool), which can be caused by any of the organisms mentioned above. The use of antibiotics is avoided in cases of dysentery caused by Escherichia coli O157:H7 due to the increased risk of developing Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS).

E. coli O157:H7 is the most pathogenic strain of Shiga toxin–producing E. coli (STEC), which may initially cause asymptomatic infection or mild diarrhea, later progressing to severe hemorrhagic colitis. Diarrhea generally starts watery and becomes bloody over time. Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) is a severe complication associated with STEC, the risk of which increases with the use of antibiotics or antimotility drugs like loperamide.

Management of dysentery caused by Shiga toxin–producing E. coli (STEC) is mainly supportive, focusing on intravenous fluid resuscitation with 0.9% normal saline or Ringer’s lactate after hospitalization. NSAIDs are avoided to prevent further renal injury, and blood or platelet transfusions are reserved only for patients who are hemodynamically unstable, have severe thrombocytopenia, or have active bleeding due to HUS.

Other options:

Option A: For Campylobacter spp., macrolides such as Azithromycin or Erythromycin are indicated in dysentery, moderate to severe gastroenteritis, or in patients at risk of developing severe disease.

Option B: For Shigella dysenteriae, treatment using fluoroquinolones, macrolides, or cephalosporins is indicated in cases of moderate to severe disease or in those with immunocompromised status.

Option C: Entamoeba histolytica causes amoebic dysentery, which is treated with metronidazole along with a luminal agent (e.g., paromomycin).

questions.text: 61. A 40-year-old female patient came to the breast OPD with complaints of a lump in her right breast for 6 months. On inspection, the skin over the breast shows characteristic changes as shown below, involving approximately one-quarter of the breast, and the skin was not pinchable away from the lump. On palpation, the lump was mobile over the underlying chest wall, with no fixation to ribs or pectoral muscles. What is the T staging of the breast malignancy according to TNM staging?
questions.solution:
The breast malignancy in this patient corresponds to the T4b stage. 

The image shows a breast with skin thickening and tiny puckered depressions resembling an orange peel, known as the Peau d’orange appearance. According to the TNM staging for breast malignancy, skin changes such as peau d’orange correspond to the T4b stage. Skin not being pinchable away from the lump is another clinical sign of tumor involvement of the skin, consistent with T4b staging.

According to the TNM staging criteria, T4b includes any of the following skin changes:

* Oedema of the skin, including peau d’orange appearance (due to obstruction of dermal lymphatics)

* Ulceration of the overlying skin  Macroscopic satellite nodules on the ipsilateral breast skin 

Note: Dimpling of skin due to infiltration of the ligament of Cooper and retraction of the nipple due to infiltration of the lactiferous duct are not considered signs of skin involvement. 

Other options:

Option B and D: Stage T4a is defined by tumor extension to the chest wall. Stage T4c requires both T4a (chest wall involvement) and T4b (skin involvement) features. In this case, on palpation, the lump was mobile over the underlying chest wall, with no fixation to ribs or pectoral muscles, suggesting that the chest wall is not involved. Since the chest wall is not involved here, T4a and T4c are not applicable. 

Option C: Stage T4d corresponds to inflammatory carcinoma, where erythema and edema affect more than one-third of the breast. The image and clinical findings show only localized Peau d’orange affecting about one-quarter of the breast, which is less than one-third of the breast, so T4d is excluded.

Pearl PM0877: TNM Staging of Carcinoma Breast

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered a benign condition and not included under Tis.



Prefixes for TNM staging:

* c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)

* p: pathological (histological) staging

* y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)

* r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

* m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

Pearl PM0869: Risk Factors and Protective Factors for Breast Carcinoma

Risk factors:

* Age: Incidence increases with increasing age.

* Sex: more common in females.

* Family history of breast cancer

* Race, ethnicity (white women have increased risk compared to women of other races)

* History of radiation exposure

* Mammographically dense breast

* Genetic factors:

* Mutations in tumor suppressor genes:

* BRCA 1

* BRCA 2

* TP53

* CHEK2

* Hereditary syndromes:

* Li Fraumeni syndrome

* Cowden’s syndrome

* HNPCC syndrome

* Peutz-Jegher’s syndrome

* Ataxia telangiectasia

* Hormonal factors (hyperestrogenemia is the risk factor):

* Early menarche

* Late menopause

* First full-term pregnancy >30 years

* Nulliparity

* Obesity (postmenopausal)

* Higher socioeconomic status, high fat diet, alcohol intake

Protective factors:

* Early age at first pregnancy

* Multiparity

* Breastfeeding

* Oophorectomy

* Exercise

* Tamoxifen and Aromatase inhibitors

*Update: Claudin low-molecular subtype is a triple-negative breast cancer with low expression of E-cadherin, with a poor prognosis. It is frequently associated with lymphocyte infiltration.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

* ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.

* HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.

* ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: 62. A 24-year-old male patient came with complaints of nausea, vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness for one day. On further inquiry, you find out there is a history of similar complaints in the family members. They recently consumed food prepared from the contaminated grains shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image showing wheat grains infested with blackish fungal mass are suggestive of ergotism.

Ergot or Claviceps purpurae is a field fungus. Food grains like bajra, rye, sorghum, and wheat have a tendency to get contaminated with this ergot fungus. It grows as a blackish mass and the seeds become black and irregular. These get harvested along with the food grains and consumption of this ergot-infested grain leads to ergotism.  

Acute cases present with nausea, vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness for a period of up to 24 to 48 hours after the ingestion of ergot grain. In cases of chronic consumption, they present with painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene due to vasoconstriction of capillaries. 

Ergot-infested grains can be removed easily by floating them in 20 percent saltwater. Floatation and handpicking can also be used in the removal of them. 0.05 mg per 100 grams of food material is the upper safe limit for ergot alkaloids. 

Disease   Food Substance  Toxic Principle  Clinical features
Neurolathyrism Lathyrus sativus /Khesari dal  BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine) Gradual spastic paralysis of lower limbs
Epidemic dropsy  Argemone oil  Sanguinarine  Acute bilateral non-inflammatory swelling of legs, diarrhea, dyspnea, cardiac death
Ergotism Bajra, wheat/ Claviceps purpurea Clavine alkaloids Acute- Nausea, vomiting, drowsiness
Chronic- Painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene
Endemic ascites  Crotalaria/Jhunjhunia  Pyrrolizidine alkaloids  Rapidly developing ascites, jaundice

questions.text: 63. Which of the following statements is true for the Meister Cycle?

choices.text: It is responsible for the absorption of neutral amino acids
It is the pathway involved in the formation of Glutathione
It involves reactions catalysed by glutathione reductase
It leads to the conversion of glutamate to γ-carboxyglutamate

questions.solution:
The Meister Cycle, also known as the γ-glutamyl cycle, is a pathway that facilitates the absorption of neutral amino acids in the intestines, kidney tubules, and brain.

In this cycle, the central role is played by glutathione, which acts as a carrier molecule. This cycle is not the pathway responsible for the synthesis of glutathione (Option B).

Glutathione reacts with the incoming amino acid to form a γ-glutamyl-amino acid conjugate, a reaction catalyzed by γ-glutamyl transferase (GGT) (not glutathione reductase, Option C).

This γ-glutamyl–amino acid is then transported into the cell and further cleaved to release the free amino acid, resulting in the net transfer of one amino acid across the membrane.

Other options:

Option C: Glutathione reductase is involved in the glutathione redox cycle, where it reduces oxidized glutathione (GSSG) back to its reduced form (GSH) using NADPH. It is not involved in the Meister Cycle.

Option D: γ-carboxylation of glutamate is a vitamin K-dependent reaction. It is involved in blood coagulation and is not part of the γ-glutamyl cycle.

questions.text: 64. A 60-year-old patient has asymmetrical weakness and fasciculations in the left lower limb, leading to difficulty in walking, with hyperactive biceps reflex and stiffness in the upper limbs, which suggests the diagnosis of?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette, showing symptoms of both upper motor neuron (UMN) and lower motor neuron (LMN) involvement, suggests a diagnosis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).

ALS is a progressive motor neuron disease involving corticospinal neurons and lower motor neurons in the brainstem and spinal cord. Initially, it may have LMN weakness of UMN signs, but eventually it progresses to involve both LMN and UMN neurons.

Clinical manifestations of ALS include:

* LMN signs: Asymmetrical weakness in distal limbs (upper or lower), muscle wasting, atrophy, fasciculations, and reduced or absent reflexes. Extensor muscles in the hand are commonly affected more than flexors.

* Bulbar/pseudobulbar involvement: Dysphagia, dysarthria, facial and tongue weakness, and emotional incontinence. Rarely, early respiratory muscle involvement can be life-threatening.

* UMN signs: Brisk reflexes, spasticity, loss of dexterity, and difficulty performing complex movements

Sensory, bowel, bladder, and ocular functions are typically preserved until late, and cognitive functions are usually unaffected, though familial ALS can be associated with frontotemporal dementia.

Tofersen is an antisense oligonucleotide indicated for treating ALS in adults with a mutation in the superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1) gene. It acts by causing degradation of SOD1 mRNA after binding to it, which results in a reduction of SOD1 protein synthesis. Riluzole and edaravone are other drugs used in the management of ALS.

Other options:

Option A. Multiple sclerosis presents with symptoms of sensory loss, optic neuritis, diplopia, and UMN signs, often exacerbated by exercise.

Option C. Guillain-Barré syndrome presents with lower motor neuron type of ascending areflexic paralysis that may have sensory involvement, usually following an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection.  

Option D. Ischemic stroke presents with contralateral hemiparesis, sensory loss, aphasia, homonymous hemianopia, and other neurological deficits depending upon where the ischemic lesion is.

Pearl PM0840: Features of Motor Neuron Lesions

Upper Motor Neuron Lesion

Lower Motor Neuron Lesion

Upper motor neuron typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons

Lower motor neurons are those whose axons terminate on skeletal muscles

Little or no muscle wasting → weakness of relatively large group of muscles

Muscle atrophy → muscle weakness of an individual and specific muscle

Hypertonia

Hypotonia

Increased or exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (hyperreflexia)

Hyporeflexia or areflexia

Spasticity

Flaccidity

Positive Babinski sign (abnormal plantar extensor reflex)

Fasciculations

questions.text: 65. Which of the following is true about lipoprotein metabolism and its disorders?

choices.text: HDL has maximum cholesterol and cholesterol ester
Molecular defect in familial hypercholestrolemia is lipoprotein lipase
Abetalipoproteinemia is due to mutation in Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) gene

questions.solution:
Abetalipoproteinemia is due to loss of function mutation in gene encoding Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP).

MTP transfers lipids to nascent chylomicrons and VLDL's in the intestine and liver, respectively. Therefore, when MTP gene is mutated, chylomicrons, VLDL and LDL are not produced.

Other options:

LDL has maximum cholesterol and cholesterol ester.

HDL has maximum electrophoretic mobility, least diameter and maximum protein content.

Molecular defect in familial hypercholesterolemia is in LDL receptors. Whereas molecular defect in familial chylomicronemia syndrome is in lipoprotein lipase or Apo CII.

questions.text: 66. A patient was started on evolocumab for the treatment of familial hypercholesterolemia. What is the primary mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
Evolocumab is a monoclonal antibody used to decrease elevated serum LDL levels by inhibiting PCSK9 (proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9), a protease that degrades LDL receptors on hepatocytes.

PCSK9 is a serine protease that causes lysosomal degradation of the LDL receptors present on hepatocytes. Monoclonal antibodies against PCSK9 such as alirocumab and evolocumab, counter this and cause persistence of LDL receptors on hepatocytes. This leads to more LDL uptake from the circulation, bringing down the LDL-cholesterol levels in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia.

PCSK9 inhibitors are indicated only as adjunctive therapy in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease who have elevated LDL-cholesterol levels despite being on maximum statin therapy.

Familial hypercholesterolemia is an autosomal dominant disorder caused due to mutations that reduce the functioning of LDL receptors, the most common being a mutation in the LDLR gene itself. Physical findings present in some of the patients include tendon xanthomas (especially  Achilles tendons) and corneal arcus. These patients may have a myocardial infarction at a young age. Diagnosis is usually established based on biochemical tests. LDL cholesterol >190 mg/dL or total serum cholesterol >300 mg/dL without any secondary etiology should point to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia. Homozygotes for the disease might have total serum cholesterol as up to 1000 mg/dL. 

Treatment includes restriction of saturated and trans fats in the diet and high-intensity statin therapy. If adequate control is not achieved with statins alone, a cholesterol absorption inhibitor (Ezetimibe) or a PCSK9 inhibitor (Alirocumab, Evolocumab) can be added to the treatment. 

Other options:

Option B: Statins decrease LDL cholesterol synthesis by inhibiting the activity of HMG-CoA reductase.

Option C: Ezetimibe interferes with a specific cholesterol transport protein, NPC1L1, in the intestinal mucosa and reduces the absorption of both dietary and biliary cholesterol.

Option D: Bile acid sequestrants such as cholestyramine bind bile acids in the intestine and also decrease their reabsorption.

questions.text: 67. A 25-year-old woman presents with visible dilated veins over her right leg that become more prominent on standing. The surgeon wishes to assess whether her deep veins are patent before surgery. Which of the following clinical tests is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
The patient has visible dilated veins that worsen on standing, indicating varicose veins. To assess whether her deep veins are patent before surgery, the most appropriate test is the Modified Perthes Test, which evaluates deep venous patency 

In the Modified Perthes Test, a tourniquet is applied around the upper part of the thigh to compress the superficial veins while keeping the deep veins patent. The patient is then asked to walk around.

* If the deep veins are patent, the superficial varicose veins collapse as blood is drained through the deep system.

* If there is deep venous obstruction (e.g., DVT), the superficial veins become more distended and painful during walking due to impaired deep venous flow.

In the Perthes test, an elastic bandage is applied to the affected leg, and the patient is asked to exercise. If there is deep venous obstruction, the patient may experience severe crampy pain. The modified version adds a tourniquet to prevent reflux, making the test more reliable than the original Perthes Test.

Other options: 

Option A: Fegan’s test is used to identify incompetent perforator veins in varicosities. The patient lies down, and the varicose veins are emptied by limb elevation. The examiner then palpates along the marked veins to detect gaps or pits in the fascia, which could indicate perforator incompetence.

Option C: Morrissey’s Cough Impulse test assesses saphenofemoral valve competence. The limb is elevated to empty superficial veins and then lowered. The patient is asked to cough forcibly, and an expansile impulse felt at the saphenous opening indicates valve incompetence. A bruit may sometimes be heard on auscultation during coughing.

Option D: Brodie-Trendelenburg Test evaluates superficial and perforator vein competence. The limb is elevated to empty veins, and a tourniquet is applied below the saphenofemoral junction.

* Trendelenburg I: Tourniquet released → rapid filling from above downward → saphenofemoral incompetence.

* Trendelenburg II: Tourniquet not released → gradual filling from below upward → perforator incompetence.

Pearl PM2507: CEAP Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

* The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.

* Telengiactesia refers to tiny intradermal venules <1 mm in diameter.
