questions.text: 68. As a paramedic, you examine a G2P1 lady in the ambulance, who is in labour. Her vitals are stable, her uterus is term-sized, and the fetus is in cephalic presentation. On further evaluation, you discover an unusual finding, which prompts you to change her position to the exaggerated Sim's position and insert a Foley's catheter to fill her bladder with 500 mL of saline before clamping it. However, on reaching the hospital, the baby was found dead. What is the most likely cause of death in this baby?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a G2P1 lady in labour, the sudden postural change to the exaggerated Sim's position and the insertion of a foley catheter to fill her bladder with 500 mL of saline before clamping it (Vago's method) is highly suggestive of cord prolapse. The fetus is at a high risk of developing anoxia from the moment the cord is prolapsed due to vasospasm of the umbilical vessels on exposure to cold or irritation. 

The management algorithm of cord prolapse is based on three important factors:

* Living or dead baby

* Maturity of the baby

* Degree of cervical dilatation

The definitive treatment for cord prolapse is delivery by cesarean section when the baby is alive and mature as in this clinical scenario. Reconfirming if the baby is alive before the incision is important to prevent unnecessary trauma of surgery.

First aid management of cord prolapse where vaginal delivery is not possible, aims at minimizing the pressure on the cord till the patient is transferred to an equipped hospital. It includes:

* Vago's method, also known as the bladder filling method is done to alleviate pressure on the cord. It is. Here, the bladder is distended with  400–750 mL of normal saline with a Foley’s catheter to push the presenting part higher up, thereby preventing compression in case of cord prolapse. Then, the balloon is inflated and the catheter is clamped.

* Postural treatment includes exaggerated and elevated Sims’ position, Trendelenburg or knee-chest position

* To lift the presenting part of the cord.

The management algorithm for cord prolapse is given below:



Given below are the images of Trendelenburg's position, exaggerated Sim’s position, and knee-chest position, respectively:







Other options:

Option B: Umbilical cord entanglement occurs when either one or more loops of the umbilical cord encircle any part of the fetal body. The condition may produce sufficient compression on the cord vessels so as to produce fetal distress or rarely death but Vago's method as mentioned in the above scenario is not associated with the management of cord entanglement.

Option C: False knot is a bulge in the cord caused by excessive Wharton's jelly or looping of the cord vessels, not associated with the death of the fetus.

Option D: True knot forms when the umbilical cord loops or interweaves around itself. However, the fetal vessels are protected from compression, by the Wharton’s jelly and are unlikely to cause death.

questions.text: 69. A 1-day-old newborn presents with red, watery eyes after having received povidone-iodine eye drops shortly after birth. The eyelids are mildly swollen with minimal clear discharge and hyperemic conjunctiva. Which of the following is the likely outcome if left untreated?
questions.solution:
This newborn baby presenting with conjunctival hyperemia, swollen eyelids and clear discharge following prophylactic povidone-iodine eye drops is likely suffering from chemical ophthalmia neonatorum. The likely outcome if left untreated will be self-limited resolution.

Ophthalmia neonatorum, also called neonatal conjunctivitis, is inflammation of the conjunctiva occurring in an infant <30 days after birth. It should be ruled out in any infant having discharge or watering within the first week of birth. 

Chemical conjunctivitis is a toxic response to topical chemicals. It is a self-limiting condition and does not require any treatment. Recent studies suggest the use of topical tetracycline and erythromycin ointment in the prevention of ophthalmia neonatorum, given the higher risk of chemical conjunctivitis with povidone-iodine.

Causes of ophthalmia neonatorum include:

* Chlamydia: neonatal inclusion conjunctivitis caused by serotypes D-K is at present the most common cause in developed countries.

* Gonorrhoea: effective prophylaxis against gonococcal infection and its subsequent decline has almost eliminated its incidence in developed countries.

* Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus species, Streptococcus haemolyticus, and Streptococcus pneumoniae are other less commonly seen causes of ophthalmia neonatorum.

* Herpes simplex ophthalmia neonatorum rarely occurs and is caused by Herpes simplex type 2 virus from the mother.

* Chemical conjunctivitis is caused by the application of prophylactic antibiotics, povidone-iodine or silver nitrate at the time of birth.

Time of presentation Causative agent
Within 48 h Chemical, Gonorrhoea
48–72 h Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae
5–7 days Herpes simplex II
>1 week Chlamydia

questions.text: 70. Which of the following events of the cardiac cycle occurs at the point marked by the pointer in the given pressure–time diagram?
questions.solution:
The marked point corresponds to the second heart sound (S2) due to closure of the aortic valve.

The point marked in the given pressure–time graph represents the moment when left ventricular pressure falls below aortic pressure, reversing the pressure gradient. This reversal causes the semilunar (aortic and pulmonary) valves to close, producing the second heart sound (S2). This event marks the end of the ventricular ejection phase and the beginning of isovolumetric relaxation.

The Wiggers diagram given below shows the phases of the cardiac cycle with corresponding changes in pressure and volume over time.



Other options:

Option B: Closure of the mitral valve causes the first heart sound (S1) and is followed by isovolumetric contraction, which increases left ventricular pressure.

Option C: 'a' wave of jugular venous pressure (JVP) corresponds to atrial systole, leading to a rise in atrial pressure. The marked point aligns with the 'v' wave, which represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at S2.

Option D: The peak ventricular volume occurs at the end of ventricular diastole, just before isovolumetric contraction. The marked point shows the end of ventricular ejection, corresponding to the lowest ventricular volume, not the peak.

questions.text: 71. Desmoid tumors are associated with _________.
questions.solution:
Desmoid tumors are associated with colonic polyps.

Desmoid tumor, also known as fibromatosis, aggressive fibromatosis, or desmoid-type fibromatosis, is an uncommon neoplasm that occurs sporadically or as part of an inherited syndrome. It is most notably associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and Gardner syndrome, an autosomal dominant syndrome of GI adenomatous polyps or adenocarcinoma, osteomas, and skin and soft tissue tumors.

These tumors arise from fibro-aponeurotic tissue and typically are manifested as a slowly growing mass. They present as firm, non-painful, non-tender masses in the abdominal wall, shoulder, hip and limbs, mesentery, and pelvis. They are also associated with trauma, pregnancy, and oral contraceptive usage.

Magnetic resonance imaging is the preferred modality of imaging for diagnosis.  

Core needle biopsy is required to establish the diagnosis. It reveals well-differentiated bundles of spindle cells with an abundant collagenous matrix. The tumors typically stain positive for β-catenin.

Tumor resection with wide margins is the standard care. Radiation therapy is used as adjuvant therapy after surgical resection.

Tamoxifen and NSAIDs are used as first-line medical therapy. Other systemic treatment options are low-dose chemotherapy, tyrosine kinase inhibitors, and full-dose chemotherapy. 

Cytotoxic chemotherapy has also been used to treat patients with aggressively growing, symptomatic, or life-threatening desmoid tumors.

Pearl PM1259: Features of Familial Adenomatous Polyposis

Gastrointestinal manifestations:

* Colon and rectum: Multiple adenomatous polyps usually >100

* Gastric and duodenal polyps are present

* Gastric polyp: fundal gland polyp, gastric adenoma

* Duodenal polyp usually in the ampullary region: Adenomatous and premalignant

Extraintestinal manifestations

* Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) is seen. It is detected by indirect ophthalmoscopy.

* Epidermoid cysts

* Desmoid tumors in the abdomen

* Osteoma in the skull, mandible, and tibia

* Brain tumors

* Tumors of the thyroid, adrenal, liver, pancreas, gallbladder, and bile duct

questions.text:
72. A final-year medical student, during his clinical examination, was asked to assess the nutritional status of a 4-month-old infant. Which of the following indicators, if used by him, would lead to an inaccurate classification of Severe Acute Malnutrition?

MUAC - Mid-upper arm circumference
questions.solution:
In infants less than 6 months of age, MUAC < 11.5 cm (mid-upper arm circumference) would lead to an inaccurate classification of Severe Acute Malnutrition.

In an infant less than 6 months of age, the following criteria are used to define SAM:

* Weight-for-height/length < –3 SD, or

* Bilateral pedal edema, or

* Visible severe wasting

In a child between 6 and 59 months of age, the following criteria are used to define SAM:

* Weight-for-height/length< –3 SD, or

* Bilateral pedal edema, or

* MUAC < 11.5 cm

Pearl PM1776: World Health Organization (WHO) classification of nutritional status of infants and children

Nutritional status
Criteria (from birth to 5 years)

Obese

Weight-for-height/length >3 SD

BMI-for-age >3 SD
Overweight

Weight-for-height/length >2 SD and ≤3 SD

BMI-for-age >2 SD and ≤3 SD
Moderately underweight Weight-for-age <–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely underweight Weight-for-age <–3 SD
Moderate acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

BMI-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference ≥115 mm and <125 mm
Severe acute malnutrition

Weight-for-height/length <– 3 SD

BMI-for-age <– 3 SD

Mid-upper arm circumference <115 mm

Bilateral pitting edema
Moderately stunted (or) moderate chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely stunted (or) severe chronic malnutrition Height/Length-for-age <–3 SD
Moderately wasted Weight-for-height/length ≤–2 SD and ≥–3 SD
Severely wasted Weight-for-height/length <-3 SD


SD - Standard deviation (from the median)

questions.text: 73. The anti-cancer drug that can cross blood-brain barrier is ______.
questions.solution:
Lomustine can cross the blood-brain barrier.

Lomustine belongs to a class of nitrosoureas anti-cancer drugs. They are highly lipophilic and can cross the blood-brain barrier.

Anti-cancer drugs that can cross the blood-brain barrier:

* Nitrosoureas: Lomustine, carmustine, semustine

* Procarbazine

* Temozolomide

Nitrosoureas cause interstrand DNA cross-linking, which is responsible for the cytotoxicity of the tumor. The use of nitrosoureas is presently limited to brain tumors due to their lipophilicity. They are effective in meningeal leukemia and brain tumors.

Side effects of nitrosoureas include profound and delayed myelosuppression. They are also highly carcinogenic and mutagenic. 

Apart from this, streptozocin is another nitrosourea compound that has a high affinity for islets of Langerhans.

questions.text: 74. Identify the ocular test performed in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an optical coherence tomography cross-sectional view of a healthy macula.  

Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) is a diagnostic tool used to create cross-sectional or tomographic images of biological tissues with an axial resolution of less than 10 µm. This technique is based on the principles of interferometry and utilizes low-coherence light in the near-infrared range. 

Applications of anterior segment OCT:

* Anterior chamber angle imaging

* Pachymetry

* Trabeculectomy blebs imaging

* Iris and ciliary body tumor assessment

Applications of posterior segment OCT:

* Macular Disorders: OCT is very useful for confirming various macular pathologies, including macular holes, cystoid macular edema, age-related macular degeneration (ARMD), central serous retinopathy (CSR), and epiretinal membranes (ERM).

*  Glaucoma Diagnosis: Optic disc scans are highly effective in diagnosing and monitoring glaucomatous changes.

Other options: 

Option A: Ocular ultrasonography based upon a pulse-echo technique with 10 MHz ultrasonic frequencies, short bursts of energy are directed into the eye. Reflected echoes are amplified and displayed visually in either A-scan or B-scan mode(shown below).



Option B: Visual evoked responses (VER) are changes in the visual cortex recorded by electroencephalography (shown below) from the occipital lobe. VER is the only clinically objective method to evaluate the visual system's function beyond the retinal ganglion cells.



Option D: Electroretinography (ERG) measures changes in the eye’s resting potential in response to a flash of light. It is conducted on a dark-adapted eye using an active electrode on the cornea and a reference electrode on the forehead. The image given below shows an electroretinogram.

questions.text: 75. A 65-year-old female patient presented with ulceration of the nipple areolar complex of the right breast for 10 days. No similar complaints have been seen in the past. On examination, the nipple areolar complex anatomy was destroyed. Biopsy showed large pale vacuolated cells. What is the most common malignancy associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis of the above given condition is Paget’s disease. The most common malignancy associated with Paget’s disease is DCIS.

Paget’s disease, which typically presents in elderly females, involves the nipple areolar complex. It clinically presents as a chronic, eczematous eruption of the nipple, which may progress to an ulcerated, weeping lesion. It is often associated with an underlying malignancy, most commonly ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), and less frequently invasive ductal carcinoma.The underlying carcinomas are usually poorly differentiated, ER-negative, and overexpress HER2. The prognosis of Paget's disease depends on the features of the underlying carcinoma.

An image showing Paget's disease of the nipple is shown below:



Investigations include a biopsy, which shows the presence of large, pale, vacuolated cells (Paget cells) in the rete pegs of the epithelium, which are pathognomic for Paget's disease (as shown in the image below). They do not breach the basement membrane; they rather extend via the lactiferous sinuses into the nipple skin. Paget cells may resemble the cells of superficial spreading melanoma, but they are periodic acid Schiff (PAS) positive and diastase resistant (i.e., stain is present after diastase predigestion), unlike melanoma cells.



CEA levels are elevated. Triple assessment ( clinical, pathological, and radiological) of the breast is required to check for underlying malignancy. Treatment is by central core excision of the lesion followed by radiotherapy. If an underlying malignancy is present, a simple mastectomy with axillary node excision is done.

questions.text: 76. As per the diagram related to glucose transport given below, which of the following is matched incorrectly?
questions.solution:
The wrongly marked pair is 4 - GLUT 4.

The correct pairs are:

* 1 -SGLT 1 

* 2-GLUT 5

* 3-GLUT 2

* 4-GLUT 2



Glucose transporters (GLUTs) transport glucose across the cell membrane via facilitated diffusion. They are of 7 different types (GLUT 1 to GLUT 7). Each transporter has a unique role where they are present.

* GLUT 4 is present in skeletal, cardiac muscles, and adipose tissues. This is an insulin-sensitive transporter that causes glucose uptake in these cells when acted upon by insulin

* GLUT 2 is involved in the transport of glucose from the enterocyte into the interstitium (or out of the enterocytes). It also transports glucose into hepatocytes and acts as a glucose sensor, helping stimulate the release of insulin

* GLUT 5 is present in the sperm and the small intestine. It is the only transporter that transports fructose    

Sodium-dependent glucose cotransporter (SGLT) transports glucose across the cell by secondary active transport. There are 2 types: SGLT 1 is present in both the small intestine & renal tubules, and SGLT 2 is present in just the renal tubules.

Pearl PM1497: Glucose Transporters

 

Function

Major sites of expression

Secondary active transport

(Na + -glucose cotransport)

    

SGLT 1

Absorption of glucose

Small intestine, renal tubules

SGLT 2

Absorption of glucose

Renal tubules

Facilitated diffusion

    

GLUT 1

Basal glucose uptake

Placenta, blood-brain barrier, brain, red cells, kidneys, colon, many other organs

GLUT 2

β-cell glucose sensor; transport out of intestinal and renal epithelial cells

β cells of islets, liver, epithelial cells of small intestine, kidneys

GLUT 3

Basal glucose uptake

Brain, placenta, kidneys, many other organs

GLUT 4

Insulin-stimulated glucose uptake

Skeletal and cardiac muscle, adipose tissue, other tissues

GLUT 5

Fructose transport

Jejunum, sperm

GLUT 6

 Function not known Brain, spleen, leucocytes
GLUT 7 Glucose-6-phosphate transporter in the endoplasmic reticulum Liver

questions.text: 77. A 36-year-old P2L2 woman visits the OPD requesting sterilization surgery. Of the many methods available, the doctor suggests the procedure described in the image given below. Identify this method of tubal sterilization.
questions.solution:
The method of tubal sterilization shown in the image is the Uchida technique.

In this method, the serosa over the mid segment of the fallopian tube is stripped off exposing the muscular layer. The exposed part is ligated and excised. The proximal end is buried in the broad ligament and the distal end is left open outside the mesosalpinx. An advantage of this method is that the minimal excision of the tube provides scope for tuboplasty in the future.

An image showing the Uchida technique is given below.



Option A - Irving procedure involves ligating and excising the mid-portion of the tube after which the proximal stump is buried into the myometrium and the distal stump is buried in the broad ligament. It is an irreversible technique and may require a laparotomy incision.

The procedure described in the image below is the Irving procedure.



Option B - Pomeroy procedure is the most popular technique of tubal sterilization. In this method, the fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision, and the middle portion is formed into a loop which is tied at the base with catgut and excised as shown in the image below.



Option D - Madlener procedure is a simple procedure but is associated with high rates of failure. In this procedure, the fallopian tube is identified on each side, brought out through the incision. A loop is made, and is crushed and ligated with a nonabsorbable suture as shown below.



Other methods of sterilization:

* Laparotomy/Minilaparotomy:

* Kroener's technique: It refers to the excision of fimbriae (fimbriectomy). 

* Aldridge method: A hole is made in the anterior leaf of the broad ligament and the fimbrial end is buried into this.

* Cornual resection: The cornual part of the tube is resected where it is attached to uterus.

* Laparoscopic techniques:

* Using Falope ring, Hulka clip, and Filshie clip.

* Hysteroscopic sterilization with the Essure permanent device: It causes a benign local fibrous tissue growth that occludes the fallopian tube. It takes 3 months to occlude the tube, which is confirmed with hysterosalpingography. During this period of 3 months, other methods of contraception should be used. It is an irreversible technique.

questions.text:
78. A 19-year-old boy was brought to the casualty with fever, pruritus, wheezing, jaundice and colicky abdominal pain which did not subside with analgesics. USG showed an dilated common bile duct with an echogenic structure. An ERCP later performed shows the following. What is the most likely diagnosis?

USG - ultrasonography; ERCP - Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio Pancreaticography
questions.solution:
The patient exhibits clinical manifestations consistent with cholangitis. An ultrasound of the abdomen detects a dilated common bile duct as well as an echogenic structure, and an ERCP reveals a linear filling defect. These findings provide evidence in favor of the patient's intraluminal ascaris infection.

The given Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio Pancreaticography (ERCP) shows linear filling defect characteristic of worm in the biliary tree. One of the commonly found worms in the biliary tree is Ascaris. The worm may also be seen as parallel filling defects - railway track sign. The same image has been marked with arrows to help appreciate the presence of this worm in the bile duct.



ERCP stands for Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangio Pancreaticography. A side-viewing endoscope is passed through the pylorus of the stomach into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla. It is then cannulated, and dye is injected into the pancreatic or bile duct to visualize the pancreatic or biliary tree. It can be both therapeutic and diagnostic.

Ascaris lumbricoides is an intestinal nematode that causes ascariasis. Infection occurs through food or water contaminated with nightsoil or human feces having eggs of Ascaris. These eggs contain the infective rhabditiform larva. The image given below depicts the life cycle of Ascaris lumbricoides.



Other options:

Option A: Bile duct strictures are areas where the intrahepatic or extrahepatic biliary ductal system narrows. The constriction blocks the usual forward flow of bile, leading to widening upstream and causing serious health issues due to the effects of bile duct blockage. Below is an ERCP showing the presence of a distal bile duct stricture.



Option B: Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic biliary tree. They are 4 times more common in females. They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable right upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain. However, they may remain minimally symptomatic and may escape detection. Below is an ERCP image depicting a type 1B choledochal cyst.



Option C: Choledocholithiasis or common bile duct stones are classified based on their point of origin. Choledocholithiasis is mostly clinically silent but may present with biliary colic and even obstructive jaundice. The following ERCP image shows a round filling defect (marked with an arrow) within the common bile duct indicative of choledocholithiasis.

questions.text:
79. A 28-year-old G2P1L1 woman is diagnosed with monochorionic monoamniotic twin gestation. Which of the following complications is unique to this type of gestation, and what is the ideal mode of delivery?

TTTS - Twin-twin transfusion syndrome TRAP - Twin reversed arterial perfusion
questions.solution:
Cord entanglement is unique to monochorionic monoamniotic (MCMA) twins, where both fetuses share the same amniotic sac. Elective caesarean delivery at 32–34 weeks is recommended for monoamniotic twins to minimize the risk of cord accidents.

MCMA twins are a rare type of identical (monozygotic) twin pregnancy, occurring when the embryo splits after day 8 post-fertilization, once both the chorion and amniotic membrane have differentiated.

Since there is no membrane separating the twins, the cords can get entangled with each other. This complication is not seen in diamniotic twins, as there is always a membrane separating the two fetuses, making cord entanglement unique to monochorionic monoamniotic gestation.

Cord entanglement may cause sudden cord compression, fetal bradycardia, and even intrauterine demise. Since cord entanglement can cause sudden fetal death and cannot be reliably predicted or monitored, elective delivery via caesarean at 32–34 weeks is the recommended management.

Other options:

Option A: TTTS (Twin-Twin Transfusion Syndrome) is a complication of monochorionic twins (more commonly seen with monochorionic diamniotic twins) in which there is a shared chorion, allowing for anatomical sharing of fetal circulations through anastomoses of placental arteries and veins. This leads to a transfusion from the donor twin to the recipient twin. The mode of delivery can be either vaginal or cesarean, depending on fetal status and gestational age.

Option C: Vasa previa is a condition in which the membrane with the vessels lies in front of the presenting part, over the internal os, risking rupture and fetal hemorrhage during labor. This is not unique to monochorionic twins and can occur in singleton or any other type of twin gestation. It does require caesarean delivery, but is not specific to monoamnionicity.

Option D: TRAP (Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion) sequence can be seen in both monochorionic monoamniotic and monochorionic diamniotic twins, which is caused by a large artery-to-artery or vein-to-vein placental shunt. This most often requires intrauterine intervention, and the delivery route depends on fetal status.

questions.text: 80. A 26-year-old woman and her younger brother present with severe burning pain in their feet, progressive weakness in the legs, and patchy hair loss for the past 3 weeks. Their mother reports that they both have become irritable and complain of tingling in their hands and feet. On examination, both have transverse white bands on their fingernails. Which of the following antidotes would be most appropriate in this situation?
questions.solution:
The cluster of signs with burning pain in feet, progressive weakness, patchy alopecia, behavioural changes, along with Mees' line point towards thallium poisoning, and the specific antidote is Prussian blue.

Thallium poisoning occurs due to an overdose or idiosyncrasy. Thallium sulfate and thallium acetate are the two salts of thallium used in dyes, in the glass industry, and as rodenticides and pesticides. Thallium interferes with cellular potassium channels and sulfhydryl enzymes, damaging hair follicles, nerves, and the GI tract. 

Mild cases of poisoning have features of joint pain, loss of appetite, and drowsiness. Severe cases present with colic, vomiting, muscle pain, convulsions, psychosis, tremors, delirium, and coma are seen in severe cases. Hair loss is seen after 2 weeks, and a characteristic feature is the loss of the outer third of the eyebrows. Mees' lines can also be seen on the nails. Maculopapular rashes in a butterfly pattern on the face are characteristic. In chronic poisoning, alopecia, skin rashes, peripheral neuropathy, and mental confusion are present.

While both arsenic and thallium poisoning share some clinical features, arsenic poisoning is more likely to cause early severe gastrointestinal manifestations, including profuse vomiting and watery diarrhoea reminiscent of “rice water” stools, leading to fluid loss and decreased urine output (oliguria). Thallium poisoning typically presents with neurological and dermatological symptoms.

Other options:

Option A. Dimercaprol (BAL) is a traditional chelating agent effective in arsenic, lead, bismuth, copper, mercury, and gold poisoning. It works by binding metals through its sulfhydryl groups and preventing their interaction with cellular enzymes.

Option B. EDTA is primarily used in lead poisoning and can also chelate cadmium, cobalt, copper, nickel, and iron. It acts by forming stable, water-soluble complexes with divalent and trivalent metals, which are then excreted renally.

Option D. Penicillamine is mainly used for copper poisoning and Wilson’s disease, and also has activity against lead and mercury. It acts as a chelator, forming soluble complexes that are renally excreted

Pearl PM0648: Specific antidotes for poisoning

questions.text: 81. A field entomology team collects mosquito eggs from breeding sites and finds eggs that are singly laid, boat shaped with lateral floats, floating on clean water. Which vector is associated with this type of egg?
questions.solution:
Anopheles eggs are laid singly, shaped like a small boat, and have lateral floats that keep them afloat on clean water surfaces. This unique boat shape with floats is a classic identification point for Anopheles in entomology. It is a vector for malaria and filariasis.

Other options:

Option A: Eggs of the aedes mosquito are laid singly without floats, usually just above the water line on the walls of artificial containers (tires, flower pots, tanks). They hatch when flooded.

Option B: Eggs of the culex mosquito are cigar-shaped, laid together in rafts that float on dirty/stagnant water. They do not have lateral floats.

Option D: Mansonia lay eggs in clusters or star-shaped masses attached to aquatic plants; not boat-shaped and have no lateral floats.

Image of egg of anopheles showing their distinctive side floats .



Given below is the image of larvae of mosquitoes.



Pearl PM1668: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

* Mosquitoes are global in distribution

* The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia

* Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters

* The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days

* Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen

* The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 


 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.



 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.



Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: 82. A 32-year-old woman develops an itchy, eczematous rash on her face, neck, and upper chest 36 hours after using a new sunscreen and spending time outdoors. She reports similar episodes in the past with other cosmetics. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a delayed-onset, itchy, eczematous eruption confined to sun-exposed areas, following application of a topical product (sunscreen) and subsequent UV exposure. These findings are classic for photoallergic contact dermatitis (PACD).

PACD is a cell-mediated delayed-type (Type IV) hypersensitivity reaction triggered by UV light modifying a chemical into a photoallergen (hapten). This hapten binds with other proteins to form a complete antigen and elicits a T-cell–mediated response, leading to an eczema-like rash on sun-exposed areas appearing 24–72 hours after sun exposure.

Sensitization to the offending agent is essential. Prior exposure to the substance (or to cross-reactive compounds) results in immune priming, so that re-exposure triggers a characteristic photoallergic reaction.

Common sensitizing agents include chemicals found in cosmetics, fragrances, and sunscreens, such as musk ambrette, bergamot oil, and PABA derivatives.

Other options:

Option A: Phototoxic reaction is a non-immunologic direct photochemical injury that resembles an exaggerated sunburn. It occurs on first exposure and is dose-dependent, with redness, blistering, and burning, not an itchy, eczematous rash. 

Option B: Allergic contact dermatitis is also Type IV hypersensitivity, but is not UV-dependent. It can occur in both covered and exposed skin.

Option D: Irritant contact dermatitis (ICD) is non-immunologic, results from direct chemical damage to the skin barrier, and does not need prior sensitization or UV exposure. It typically affects all areas in contact, not only sun-exposed parts.

questions.text: 83. A patient presented with complaints of vomiting, abdominal distension, and obstipation. On examination, high-pitched bowel sounds were heard. An X-ray erect abdomen is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with an X-ray showing gas in the biliary tract (pneumobilia) and multiple air-fluid levels indicating small bowel obstruction is suggestive of gallstone ileus.

Gallstone ileus is a condition caused by the obstruction of the intestinal lumen by a gallstone, leading to a mechanical blockage. Big gallstones will not be able to pass through the normal cystic duct. This causes inflammation of the gallbladder and results in pressure necrosis. This in turn leads to biliary-enteric fistula formation. The condition is characterized by a triad of features known as Rigler’s triad. It comprises small bowel obstruction, pneumobilia, and atypical mineral shadow on the abdominal radiographs (ectopic gall stone).

Penumobilia refers to the presence of air within the biliary tree which suggest that there is an abnormal communication between the intestine and the biliary tract. Other conditions associated with pneumobilia include incompetent sphincter of Oddi and biliary-enteric anastomosis.

CT scan is helpful in the diagnosis.

Gall stone ileus is managed by

* Milking the stone proximally away from the site of impaction

* Crushing the stone

* Removal of the stone.

The surgical procedures that can be performed are: simple enterolithotomy, enterolithotomy, cholecystectomy, and fistula closure (one-stage procedure) and enterolithotomy with cholecystectomy performed later (two-stage procedure).

Given below is a plain X-ray of the erect abdomen showing air in the biliary tract (pneumobilia).



Option A: Cecal volvulus presents with features of obstruction. Ischaemia can be seen and the midline or a left-sided swelling can be present. On radiograph, it will show a dilated and air-filled cecum. Other clinical features such as dilated small bowel and absence of gas in the distal colon are seen. 

Option B: In large bowel obstruction, the presence of haustrations is a feature. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

Option C: Crohn's disease on small bowel enema shows narrowing of involved areas and is often irregular. Features include colicky postprandial abdominal pain, diarrhea, and palpable and tender right iliac fossa mass. Other less common features like fever, anemia and weight loss can be seen.

questions.text: 84. Which of the following activities is a core component of the MAA Programme?

choices.text: Promotion of exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months of age
Providing free care for sick neonates up to 28 days of age
Cash incentive for donation of breast milk to the milk bank
Provision of free transport for institutional delivery

questions.solution:
The core component of the MAA Programme is the promotion of exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months of age.

The central goal of the MAA (Mothers’ Absolute Affection) Programme is to promote, protect, and support optimal breastfeeding practices. A major focus is on ensuring early initiation within one hour of birth and promotion of exclusive breastfeeding for the first 6 months, supported through skilled counselling and community awareness.

Key features under MAA:

* IEC (Information, Education, and Communication) and BCC (Behavior Change Communication) activities to address cultural myths about breastfeeding

* Training health workers for lactation management

* Establishing lactation support centres (e.g., lactation management units, breastfeeding corners)

* Mobilising community support through ASHAs and ANMs

Other options:

Option B: Providing free care for sick neonates up to 28 days is not a direct mandate of MAA; this is covered under JSSK (Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram).

Option C: Cash incentives for donation of breast milk to the milk bank are not covered under MAA; breastfeeding and human milk bank donations are promoted as voluntary, non-commercial activities.

Option D: Free transport for institutional delivery is an entitlement under Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK), not under MAA, which focuses purely on IYCF (Infant and Young Child Feeding) promotion.

questions.text: 85. A 60-year-old obese woman presents with upper right abdominal pain. The pain is dull and associated with fatty food ingestion. A CT scan was done which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and CT scan showing calcification in the gall bladder wall is suggestive of a porcelain gallbladder.



Porcelain gallbladder refers to dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall. The mechanism behind its pathophysiology is thought to be the same as that of gallstone formation.

It has a 5:1 preponderance in women when compared to men. Age > 60 years and obesity are risk factors for this condition. Symptoms are similar to chronic cholecystitis. 

Diagnosis can be made by X-ray or CT scan. Abdominal ultrasound and MRI can also help in the diagnosis. 

It is considered a premalignant lesion for gallbladder carcinoma. Hence, treatment is advised in all cases with laparoscopic cholecystectomy. 

Option A: On USG, a gallbladder polyp is fixed, and does not cast any acoustic shadow. A polyp is more of an incidental finding and is often asymptomatic



Option C: In emphysematous cholecystitis, intraluminal gas appears as a bright curvilinear echogenic band with ‘dirty’ shadowing. CT scan shows gas within the wall of the gallbladder (shown below).



Option D: In cholelithiasis, the gallstones appear as echogenic foci, which cast an acoustic shadow on USG. Stone mobility may be demonstrated if it is not impacted.

questions.text: 86. An elderly male patient in ICU with history of altered sensorium and confusion is suspected to have intensive care unit psychosis. Which of the following is not a feature that can be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Acute confusion lasting for brief duration

questions.solution:
In a patient with intensive care unit psychosis/delirium, the symptoms worsen at night, not in the morning. Worsening of symptoms at night is known as sundowning, which is a feature of delirium.

The characteristic presentation of delirium is:

* Acute onset with a brief duration of days to weeks (Option D)

* Unpredictable fluctuations in severity and other clinical manifestations

* Worsening of symptoms at night, known as sundowning

* Rapid improvement when the underlying cause is treated

Other characteristics may include asterexis and carphologia, which are picking movements on cover sheets and clothes (Option A). Delirium is more commonly associated with visual hallucinations (Option C). There is a decline in the level of consciousness, which is considered the hallmark symptom of delirium.

questions.text: 87. A patient with increasing tremors as he attempts to touch your finger also finds it difficult to place his finger onto your finger, as he often overshoots past your finger several times before successfully touching your finger. Which part of the brain is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of intention tremors and overshooting of movements, which is suggestive of a pathology in the cerebellum.

Intention tremors occur due to a cerebellar lesion. Most body movements are naturally pendular due to momentum. When the cerebellum is damaged, it can't dampen this motion, causing the limb to overshoot the target. The cerebrum sends corrective signals, but these also overshoot, leading to a back-and-forth motion until the limb gradually settles at the intended position.

When the cerebellum is functional, it sends learned, unconscious signals that stop movement precisely, acting as a natural damping system. This damping is essential for controlling pendular movements with inertia.

Features of cerebellar disease include:

* Ataxia - Incoordinated, intermittent jerky movements with a drunken gait

* Hypotonia or atonia - Reduced or absence of muscle tone

* Dysmetria - Inability to judge the force and range of movement, resulting in past pointing

* Dysdiadochokinesia - Failure to perform rapid alternating movements

* Decomposition of movement - Lack of smooth flow of movement

* Speech defect - Staccato speech or slurring speech

* Pendular knee jerk (a feature of hypotonia)

* Intention tremors

* Nystagmus (jerky movements of the eye)

* Rebound phenomenon

Other options:

Option A: Lesions of the basal ganglia typically produce resting tremors, which are most noticeable when the limb is at rest and usually diminish or disappear with voluntary movement, as seen in Parkinson’s disease.

Option C and D: Lesions in the midbrain and thalamus do not produce a pure intention tremor with overshooting of movements, which is characteristic of cerebellar dysfunction.

Pearl PM0915: Functional divisions of the cerebellum

  Dorsal Spinocerebellum Ventral Spinocerebellum Cerebrocerebellum (neocerebellum) Vestibulocerebellum (flocculonodular lobe) 
Constituents Vermis (except the nodulus) The adjacent medial portion of the hemisphere The lateral portion of hemispheres Nodulus and flocculus 
Afferent (input) Somatosensory from the trunk, visual, auditory, and vestibular Somatosensory input from the limbs From the cerebral motor cortex, premotor, and somatosensory cortex  Vestibular input, visual input, somatosensory from the neck
Efferent (output) Via Fastigial nucleus to the medial descending system Via interposed nucleus to lateral corticospinal and rubrospinal systems Via dentate nucleus to motor, premotor and prefrontal cortex  To vestibular nuclei in the brain stem (direct projection)
Functions    

Maintains posture and helps in the execution of gross movements

It controls the interplay between agonist and antagonist group of muscles

 Controls the  distal muscles of the limbs (smoothens and coordinates movements) Planning the sequence of voluntary movements    

 Participates in maintaining equilibrium and posture

 

Controls ocular movements

It is responsible for regulating the stability of the head and body in space

questions.text: 88. An 8-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents. The mother says that she has been measuring his height and he has only increased in height by 4 cms over the last two years. On further investigations, a diagnosis of short stature is made. What is the expected growth velocity in this child?
questions.solution:
The growth velocity expected in an 8-year-old child is 6 cms/ year. The given scenario suggests that the child is suffering from pathological short stature, as he has grown only by 4 cms over the last two years. 

Height velocity is the rate of increase in height over a period of time. It is normal in physiological short stature. The average height velocity is 25 cms/ year in the first year and will be 75 cms tall at 1 year. At 2 years, the height is 90 cms, and at 4 years, the child is 100 cm. After this, the child gains about 6cms every year until 12 years. If height velocity is lower than expected for age (as in this scenario), the child is likely to be suffering from a pathological cause of short stature.

Short stature is defined as the height below the third centile or less than two standard deviations (<-2SD) in a given population. Short stature may be physiological or pathological. Physiological short stature may be familial or constitutional.

Pathological short stature can be attributed to nutritional causes and systemic illnesses like congenital heart diseases, cystic fibrosis, and asthma.

Pearl PM2090: Short stature: Familial vs Constitutional

Feature Constitutional Delay Familial Short Stature  
Height Short Short
Final Height Normal Short  
Family history Delayed puberty Short stature  
Bone age Less than chronological age Normal  
Puberty Delayed Normal  
Height velocity Normal Normal

questions.text: 89. A patient admitted to the medical intensive care unit is found to have non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis. Further investigations reveal a serum potassium level of 3.2 mmol/L, low urinary ammonium ions, and a positive urine anion gap. The pH of the urine is found to be 5.7. No other substances were found to be abnormally excreted in the urine. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has type 1 renal tubular acidosis. The points that favour the diagnosis are hypokalemia, non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis, positive urine anion gap, low urine ammonium ions, and a pH of the urine of more than 5.5.

Type 1 renal tubular acidosis (RTA) occurs due to impaired acid excretion in the distal tubule. Patients will have hypokalemia, a non-anion-gap metabolic acidosis, positive urine anion gap, low urine [NH4+], and high urine pH (pH > 5.5). Most patients also have hypocitraturia and hypercalciuria, so nephrolithiasis, nephrocalcinosis, and bone disease are common.

Type 2 renal tubular acidosis occurs due to impaired reabsorption of bicarbonate ions in the proximal tubule. In addition to hypokalemic metabolic acidosis, patients also have glycosuria, generalised aminoaciduria, and phosphaturia (Fanconi syndrome). Since the acidification in the distal tubule is functioning normally, the pH of the urine is less than 5.5

Type 3 renal tubular acidosis has mixed features of both type 1 and type 2 RTA.

Type 4 renal tubular acidosis is common in patients with diabetes mellitus, tubulointerstitial disease, or chronic kidney disease. It occurs as a result of decreased aldosterone. The patients will have hyperkalemic metabolic acidosis along with hypertension.

questions.text: 90. A patient presents with fatigue, breathlessness, paresthesias, and a stomping gait. The peripheral blood smear shows a megaloblastic picture. The lifecycle of the causative organism is shown below. Which of the following can be responsible for this deficiency?
questions.solution:
The above clinical picture is suggestive of Vitamin B12 deficiency, which can be caused by the broad or fish tapeworm - Diphyllobothrium latum.

Diphyllobothrium latum infection usually causes vitamin B12 deficiency by absorbing large quantities of vitamin B12 and interfering with the ileal absorption, thereby making it unavailable to the host.

The first intermediate host is a freshwater crustacean, while the second intermediate host is a freshwater fish. The definitive hosts are man, dog, and cat. The infective form to humans is the third stage plerocercoid larvae. It possesses a rudimentary scolex.

The adult worm lives inside the small intestine and lays operculated eggs. These freshly passed eggs contain an immature embryo surrounded by yolk granules. This hexacanth embryo with 6 hooklets inside the egg is called oncosphere.

The pernicious anaemia caused by the infection is called bothriocephalus anaemia.

Treatment is praziquantel in a single dose of 10 mg/kg. In severe B12 deficiency, parenteral vitamin B12 should be given. 

Beef tapeworm(Option A) is Taenia saginata, and pork tapeworm (Option B) is Taenia solium. Both of them live in the adult small intestine. Man is the definitive host for both species, while cattle and pigs are the intermediate hosts for T. saginata and T. solium, respectively. 

Manifestations include:

* Intestinal taeniasis is characterised by vague abdominal discomfort, indigestion, nausea, diarrhoea and weight loss. 

* Cysticercosis in subcutaneous tissues (nodules), muscles (acute myositis), and brain (neurocysticercosis)

The image below shows the life cycle of T. saginata and T. solium



Dwarf tapeworm (Option C) is the common name for Hymenolepis nana, which manifests as nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and irritability in severe cases.

The image below shows life cycle of Hymenolepis nana.

questions.text: 91. A 10-year-old boy presents with a generalized rash. He reports pruritus over the affected areas. Physical examination reveals multiple small papules and plaques as shown in the image below. The lesions are primarily present over the trunk and proximal extremities. Which of the following preceding infections might have precipitated this patient's current findings?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with physical examination findings showing numerous small, erythematous papules and plaques, which are pruritic, represents a case of guttate psoriasis. Streptococcal tonsillitis is a common preceding infection for guttate psoriasis.

Guttate psoriasis is characterised by the acute eruption of numerous small, erythematous papules and plaques. The term "guttate" refers to the discrete, drop-like appearance of skin lesions. It is usually seen in children and young adults and is preceded by streptococcal tonsillitis. The infection can also precipitate chronic plaque psoriasis, but to a lesser extent. Additionally, perianal streptococcal infections may also cause guttate psoriasis in children.

The lesions are from 2 or 3 mm to 1 cm in diameter, round or slightly oval. They are scattered more or less evenly over the body, particularly on the trunk and proximal part of the limbs.

The diagnosis is made from the nature of the scaling, the general distribution, and the evidence of preceding streptococcal infection.

First-line management for guttate psoriasis involves UV light phototherapy and the use of topical corticosteroids and topical vitamin D analogues such as calcipotriol or calcipotriene.

The image below shows Guttate psoriasis.

questions.text: 92. A 15-year-old girl presented with fever, hypotension, and skin rash with a tampon in situ for more than 1 week. A bacterial cause is suspected. The factor responsible for this disease is produced during which of the following phases in the bacterial growth curve?
questions.solution:
The above presentation of fever, hypotension, skin rash and presence of a retained vaginal tampon points towards a likely diagnosis of toxic shock syndrome, which mainly occurs due to toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1), produced during the stationary phase (3) of the bacterial growth curve.

Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products, such as exotoxins and antibiotics, during the stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve.

When a bacterium is seeded into a suitable liquid medium and incubated, its growth follows a definite course. If bacterial counts are made at intervals after inoculation and plotted in relation to time, a growth curve is obtained. The curve shows the following phases:



* Lag phase (Marked as 1)

* Occurs immediately after the seeding of a culture media.

* Cell size increases without increase in cell number. 

*  Enzymes and metabolic intermediates required for multiplication are produced.

* Log phase or exponential phase (Marked as 2)

* In this phase, cells start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially or by geometric progression with time.

* Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. 

* Stationary phase (Marked as 3)

* Cell division stops due to depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products.

* It is a state of equilibrium.

* Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins and antibiotics.

* Cells are gram variable and show irregular staining.

* Phase of decline (Marked as 4)

* In this phase, the population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation, and action of autolytic enzymes.

* Involution forms are common.

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) can occur as a result of several toxins. Toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1) is known as a superantigen produced by Staphylococcus aureus which binds to MHC class II molecules and causes T-cell stimulation leading to the overactivation of cytokines and inflammatory cells leading to toxic shock syndrome.

The clinical criteria required to diagnose TSS include fever >102 °F, erythroderma with desquamation after 1-2 weeks, hypotension, and the involvement of >3 organ systems. The laboratory diagnosis of staphylococcal TSS can be made with a Gram stain of the infected site, which would show gram-positive cocci in clusters.

Treatment of shock is the mainstay of therapy for TSS. Both fluids and pressors may be necessary. Tampons or other packing material should be promptly removed. A combination of clindamycin and semisynthetic penicillin or vancomycin is used as clindamycin is a protein synthesis inhibitor which helps reduce toxin production.

questions.text: 93. A middle-aged female is a known case of diabetes, having frequent changes in her presbyopic glasses. What investigation would help in the diagnosis of primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG), early in the course of suspected POAG?
questions.solution:
A diurnal variation test would favor the diagnosis in the early course of primary open-angle glaucoma. 

Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is a chronic, progressive optic neuropathy. It is mostly seen in people older than 40 years of age, and it runs in families. The major risk factors are diabetes mellitus and myopia. It occurs due to reduced aqueous outflow facility, which is caused by trabecular meshwork stiffening. This leads to an elevated intraocular pressure (IOP).

In early glaucoma stages, intraocular pressure (IOP) may not be consistently elevated, but there is increased diurnal variation. Therefore, IOP should be measured every 3 to 4 hours over 24 hours. Generally, IOP decreases in the evening, which contrasts with the pattern seen in angle-closure glaucoma. This is known as the diurnal variation test.

A variation in intraocular pressure (IOP) of over 5 mmHg is suspicious, and a change of more than 8 mmHg indicates glaucoma. In advanced stages, IOP remains above 21 mmHg, usually between 30 and 45 mmHg.

Other options:

Option A: Gonioscopy involves examining the angle of the anterior chamber and reveals that it is wide open in primary open-angle glaucoma. Its main utility in POAG is to rule out other forms of glaucoma.

Option C: Slit-lamp examination may reveal a normal anterior segment in POAG in early stages. In later stages, some signs are sluggishness of the pupil reflex, haziness of the cornea, and it is also used to rule out causes of secondary open-angle glaucoma. 

Option D: Perimetry is used to detect visual field defects that become noticeable after about 40% of axons are damaged and align with changes at the optic nerve head, progressing if intraocular pressure (IOP) is not controlled.

Pearl PM0707: Visual field Defects in Open-Angle Glaucoma

questions.text: 94. A 50-year-old man presented with shortness of breath and substernal chest pain two days ago. He was diagnosed with myocardial infarction and, unfortunately, passed away before receiving any treatment. Which of the following cellular changes is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Myocardial infarction is a type of coagulative necrosis in which ischemia caused by the obstruction in a vessel leads to necrosis of the supplied tissue. The cellular change associated with coagulative necrosis is fragmentation of the nucleus, known as Karyorrhexis.

Necrosis disrupts the cell membrane, leading to the leakage of cellular contents, local inflammation, and enzymatic digestion. Cellular swelling (hydropic change) is the earliest manifestation of all forms of injury to cells. 

Nuclear changes in necrosis include:

* Pyknosis: Nuclear shrinkage with condensation of chromatin.

* Karyorrhexis: Fragmentation of the pyknotic nucleus.

* Karyolysis: Complete dissolution of the nucleus, leaving behind only the cell membrane or empty cells.

Coagulative necrosis is an enzymatic degradation of necrotic cells that preserves the architecture of dead tissues, and the localized area of this necrosis is known as an infarct. It occurs in all solid organs except the brain. Myocardial infarction is a type of coagulative necrosis in which ischemia caused by the obstruction in a vessel leads to necrosis of the supplied tissue. 

The various types of necrosis are: 

Type of necrosis  Examples
Coagulative necrosis Infarcts in all organs except the brain
Caseous necrosis Tuberculosis
Liquefactive necrosis Abscesses, Brain infarct, Wet gangrene
Fat necrosis Pancreatitis, Breast
Fibrinoid necrosis Aschoff bodies, Malignant hypertension, Polyarteritis nodosa


Other options:

Options A and B: Cellular membrane blebs and chromatin condensation are the characteristic features of apoptosis. 

Option D:  Sequestration of organelles is a feature of autophagy in which the cell eats its own contents. Autophagosomes (cytoplasmic autophagic vacuoles) are formed that fuse with lysosomes and digest the material enclosed.

questions.text: 95. A 1-month-old male baby was brought to you with complaints of a left-sided flank mass. The mother reported that the child cries while urinating and had been treated with antibiotics for urinary tract infection. Ultrasonography was done and revealed dilation of the pelvicalyceal system, with a normal-looking distal urinary tract. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the ultrasonograph showing hydronephrosis of the affected kidney indicate a likely diagnosis of ureteropelvic junction obstruction (UPJ) associated with UTI.

Hydronephrosis may be detected on antenatal ultrasound; it can, however, be transient or mild and resolve on its own. Re-evaluation should be done after birth and in cases presenting with symptoms of recurrent UTI, palpable flank mass or pain, urinary obstruction, and in cases of failure to thrive.

If the hydronephrosis is persistent, its severity is graded by the extent of the dilatation of the pelvicalyceal system and parenchymal thickness. It needs to be ascertained whether the other kidney is involved, the lower ureter is dilated, the bladder wall is thickened, and whether emptying of the bladder is incomplete. Based on these findings, a diagnosis can be made.

In cases of hydronephrosis, long-standing urine stasis and pressure may damage the kidneys.

The causes of UPJ obstruction are

* Intrinsic (due to an adynamic or stenotic segment of the proximal ureter) or 

* Extrinsic (e.g. compression by accessory renal arteries). This needs to be corrected primarily.

The renal anatomy and function can be assessed using radioscintigraphy studies. The investigation of choice for UPJ obstruction is 99mTc-MercaptoAcetyl-triGlycine (MAG3) scan. Micturating cystourethrogram is the investigation of choice in vesicoureteric reflux. 99mTc-dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan is used for assessing renal scarring.

Treatment of intrinsic UPJ obstruction is done surgically if renal function is compromised or if there is bilateral involvement of the kidneys. In other cases, serial follow-up with ultrasonography is done to assess the spontaneous resolution of hydronephrosis.

Other options:

Option B: Vesicoureteral reflux is the second most common cause of hydronephrosis after UPJ obstruction. In vesicoureteric reflux, the valve that prevents the backflow of urine from the bladder into the ureter is defective; hence, abnormal backflow of urine occurs from the bladder into the ureter. It may also present with hydronephrosis; however, the distal ureter is also involved, unlike in this case.

Option C: Ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter, thought to result from the persistence of the membrane between the ureteral bud and urogenital sinus. Since the distal urinary tract is normal-looking in this case, this diagnosis is unlikely.

Option D: Posterior urethral valve is an obstructing membrane in the posterior male urethra as a result of abnormal in-utero development. It is the most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male newborns. As a result, bilateral hydronephrosis and bladder dilatation is seen, unlike the unilateral involvement in this case.

Pearl PM2252: Causes of Hydronephrosis

Unilateral hydronephrosis

Extramural obstruction

* Tumor from adjacent structures, e.g., cervix, prostate, rectum, colon, or cecum

* Retrocaval ureter

* Aberrant renal vessels

* Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond’s disease)

Intramural obstruction

* Congenital PUJ obstruction - most common congenital cause

* Congenital stenosis

* Ureterocele

* Ureteric stricture - iatrogenic/ inflammatory

* Neoplasm of the ureter or bladder involving the ureteric orifice

Intraluminal obstruction

* Renal stones - most common acquired unilateral cause

* Sloughed papilla in papillary necrosis (especially, in patients with diabetes, analgesic abuse, or sickle cell disease)

Bilateral hydronephrosis

Congenital

* Posterior urethral valves (associated with pulmonary hypoplasia)

* Urethral atresia

* PUJ obstruction

Acquired     

* Benign prostatic hypertrophy or carcinoma of the prostate

* Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond's disease)

* Postoperative bladder neck scarring

* Urethral stricture

* Phimosis

questions.text: 96. Fertilization takes place within how many days of ovulation?
questions.solution:
Fertilization takes place within 0-1 day of ovulation. It occurs in the distal portion of the fallopian tube, the ampulla.

Fertilization involves the following steps: 

* Chemoattraction of the sperm to the ovum. It occurs due to substances produced by the ovum

* Spermatozoa undergoes the following changes to fertilize the ovum: 

* Capacitation: It involves epithelial interactions between the sperm and the mucosal surface of the fallopian tube. During this process, the glycoprotein coat and seminal plasma proteins are removed.

* Acrososmal reaction: It involves the release of enzymes such as acrosin, required to penetrate the zona pellucida. 

* Adherence of the sperm head to the cell membrane of the ovum

* Release of the sperm nucleus into the cytoplasm of the ovum

questions.text: 97. Which of the following translocations is seen in Diffuse Large B cell Lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Translocation seen in Diffuse Large B Cell Lymphoma (DLBCL) is t(14:18).

DLBCL is the most common form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. 10-20% tumours are associated with t(14:18), which leads to the overexpression of the antiapoptotic protein BCL2.

Dysregulation of BCL6 is a frequent pathogenic event. Mutations similar to those found in BCL6 are also seen in multiple other oncogenes, including MYC, suggesting that somatic hypermutation in DLBCL is mistargeted to a wide variety of loci.

BCL2 rearrangements usually lack BCL6 rearrangements, suggesting that these rearrangements define two distinct molecular classes of DLBCL.

Immunophenotyping shows mature B-cells that express CD19 and CD20 and show variable expression of CD10 and BCL6. High-level expression of both MYC and BCL2 proteins is seen in some cases and may predict more aggressive behaviour.
