questions.text: 98. A 32-year-old G2P1L1 with a previous Caesarean section presents at 39 weeks of gestation with a single live intrauterine fetus of estimated fetal weight 2.6 kg in vertex presentation. On per vaginal examination, Bishop’s score is favourable for the induction of labour. Which of the following methods of induction of labour has the least risk of uterine rupture in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the intracervical balloon catheter carries the least risk of uterine rupture and is therefore a safe method for the induction of labour in women with a previous Caesarean section.

In such women, the main concern during induction is the risk of uterine rupture due to the uterine scar. Agents that increase uterine contractility should be avoided or used with extreme caution, while mechanical methods are relatively safer.

The intracervical balloon catheter is a mechanical method of labor induction that gently dilates the cervix and causes cervical ripening without directly inducing uterine contractions or increasing uterine tone. This makes it one of the preferred methods for induction in women with a previous Caesarean scar, although it is less effective than pharmacologic agents.

The following selection criteria must be met for vaginal birth after a previous cesarean (VBAC):

* One or two previous lower-segment transverse scars.

* Non-recurring indication for prior cesarean section 

* Pelvis - adequate for the fetus

* Continuous monitoring of labour.

* Informed consent of the woman

* Sufficient personnel and equipment

Other options:

Option A: Oxytocin carries a risk of uterine rupture in women with a previous Caesarean scar. Low doses can be used cautiously and under strict monitoring, as excessive stimulation can cause uterine hyperstimulation, further increasing this risk.

Options B and D: Prostaglandins such as misoprostol and dinoprostone are potent uterotonics that can cause uterine hyperstimulation and increase intrauterine pressure. They are contraindicated in women with a prior Caesarean section due to the high risk of rupture.

questions.text: 99. Salivary gland tumour with a propensity for perineural invasion:
questions.solution:
Adenoid cystic carcinoma has a propensity for perineural invasion and an indolent growth pattern.

It is the second most common malignant tumour of the parotid gland. The histological types are tubular, cribriform, and solid. The tubular type has the best prognosis, and the solid type has the worst. Clinical features are parotid swelling and pain due to perineural invasion.

The investigation of choice is Fine needle aspiration cytology. Swiss cheese pattern is seen on histopathological examination. Treatment is the removal of the gross tumour with radiation therapy for microscopic disease.

Other Options:

Option A: Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumour of the parotid gland. It presents as a slow-growing parotid swelling that commonly involves the superficial lobe

Option B: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common salivary gland malignancy in children and young adults. It presents as a soft to firm, painless mass.

Option D: Acinic cell carcinoma is composed of neoplastic acinar cells. They are generally slow-growing, painless, mobile, solitary tumours.

Pearl PM1674: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

* Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma

* Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

* Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma

* Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

* Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma

* Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland

* Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma

* Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: 100. What is the procedure performed in the image?

choices.text: Single anastomosis duodenoileal bypass with sleeve gastrectomy (SADI-S)

questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the image is a Biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (BPD/DS).

Biliopancreatic diversion with duodenal switch (BPD/DS) is a bariatric surgery in which a sleeve gastrectomy, followed by division of the duodenum just distally to the pylorus, followed by a duodenoileostomy and ileoileostomy is performed.

The length of the common channel is 75–125 cm, and the alimentary channel is 100–250 cm. Its advantage is significant weight loss when compared to sleeve gastrectomy. A high-protein diet and regular vitamin and mineral supplements with lifelong monitoring and patient commitment, to avoid malnutrition, is essential postoperatively.

Other Options: 

Option A: In Sleeve Gastrectomy, a narrow tubular stomach is created along the lesser curvature. This restrictive procedure reduces gastric volume, accelerates gastric emptying, and alters satiety hormones and bile salt metabolism. Potential complications include leak, long-term gastroesophageal reflux, and de novo Barrett’s esophagus. The image below shows a sleeve gastrectomy:



Option B: In Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, the Roux limb is a ‘Y’ jejunojejunostomy, placed retrocolic or antecolic. The biliary limb is kept short to minimise nutrient deficiencies, while the Roux limb typically ranges from 100–150 cm. Weight loss occurs mainly due to reduced appetite, driven by changes in satiety hormones. The image below shows a Roux-en-Y gastric bypass:



Option D: Single-anastomosis duodeno-ileal bypass with sleeve gastrectomy (SADI-S) is a bariatric procedure in which sleeve gastrectomy is followed by an end-to-side duodenoileal anastomosis. The length of the common channel–alimentary limb is 250–300 cm. Potential advantages include the preservation of the pylorus and only one anastomosis being done. The image showing a single-anastomosis duodeno-ileal bypass with sleeve gastrectomy (SADI-S) is given below:

questions.text: 101. A middle-aged man who presented with proximal muscle weakness was diagnosed with Lambert-Eaton Myasthenia syndrome. Attack at which of the following sites causes this condition?
questions.solution:
Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) is an autoimmune disorder affecting the presynaptic membrane at the neuromuscular junction. It is caused by autoantibodies against the P/Q-type voltage-gated calcium channels, represented by point 1 in the image.

In LEMS, the autoimmune attack reduces calcium influx into the nerve terminals, impairing the release of acetylcholine (ACh) into the synaptic cleft. This results in proximal muscle weakness, especially in the lower limbs, along with ptosis and diplopia, which may improve after brief exercise. Deep tendon reflexes are diminished or absent, and patients often exhibit autonomic dysfunction, presenting with dry mouth and impotence. The repetitive nerve stimulation test typically shows an incremental response at higher stimulation rates.

LEMS is frequently associated with malignancies, particularly small-cell lung cancer, as well as lymphosarcoma, thymoma, and cancers of the breast, stomach, colon, prostate, kidney, or gallbladder.

Treatment includes plasmapheresis, immunotherapy, and medications such as 3,4-diaminopyridine (3,4-DAP) and pyridostigmine.

Other options:

Option B: Point 2 shows ACh-containing synaptic vesicles in the presynaptic terminal. These are affected in botulism, where botulinum toxin prevents ACh release by cleaving SNARE proteins.

Option C: Point 3 represents ACh in the synaptic cleft, which binds nicotinic receptors. This is affected in organophosphate poisoning, where acetylcholinesterase is inhibited, leading to ACh accumulation and cholinergic symptoms.

Option D: Point 4 shows postsynaptic ACh receptors, targeted in myasthenia gravis, an autoimmune disorder causing ptosis, skeletal muscle weakness and fatigability.

questions.text: 102. A ligament is marked in red in the given image below. According to the Denis three-column concept of spinal stability, the given ligament comes under which column?
questions.solution:
The given ligament marked in red is the posterior longitudinal ligament. It is a component of the middle column.

Denis three-column concept of spinal stability. This was used to describe the classification of spinal injuries.

* Anterior column:

* Anterior half of the vertebral body

* Anterior part of the intervertebral disc

* Anterior longitudinal ligament

* Middle column:

* Posterior half of the vertebral body

* Posterior part of the intervertebral disc

* Posterior longitudinal ligament

* Posterior column

* Pedicles

* Facet joints

* Posterior bony arch

* Interspinous ligament

* Supraspinous ligament

Fractures involving the middle column and at least one other column are regarded as unstable injuries, i.e., there is a significant risk of displacement of the vertebral components, leading to damage to the neural tissues.

The images below show the three spinal columns.

questions.text: 103. A 28-year-old woman, 7 weeks pregnant, presents for medical termination of pregnancy. She has a past medical history of primary adrenal insufficiency and is on hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone replacement therapy. Which of the following drugs should not be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Mifepristone should not be given to this patient with primary adrenal insufficiency.

Mifepristone (RU-486) is a competitive antagonist of progesterone receptors, leading to decidual breakdown, cervical softening, and increased uterine sensitivity to prostaglandins, leading to termination of pregnancy.

At higher doses, it antagonizes cortisol action by competitively inhibiting glucocorticoid receptors. In patients with adrenal insufficiency, this can precipitate adrenal crisis, a potentially life-threatening condition. Hence, mifepristone is contraindicated in patients with primary adrenal insufficiency and chronic corticosteroid therapy requiring replacement.

Other options:  

Option A: Misoprostol is a prostaglandin E1 analog that causes uterine contractions. It does not interfere with steroid pathways and is safe in adrenal insufficiency.

Option B: Methotrexate is a folate antagonist used in ectopic pregnancies and first-trimester MTP. It has no glucocorticoid receptor interaction and is safe in patients with Addison’s disease.

Option D: Oxytocin stimulates uterine smooth muscle contraction via oxytocin receptors. It is not typically used in early MTP, but it is safe concerning adrenal function.

questions.text:
104. A 75-year-old woman with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes presents with lethargy, polyuria, and polydipsia for 1 week. Her blood pressure on arrival was 90/68 mmHg, which increased to 118/78 mmHg following the administration of 3 liters of 0.9% normal saline for 3 hours. What is the next step in management?

Lab values (on arrival):

* pH: 7.36

* Plasma Glucose: 760 mg/dL

* Serum Sodium: 145 mEq/L

* Serum Osmolality: 325 mOsm/kg

* Urine Ketones: Negative
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and laboratory values indicate a diagnosis of Hyperglycemic Hyperosmolar State (HHS). In HHS, the initial fluid of choice for management is 0.9% normal saline (NS), which is typically switched to 0.45% saline after achieving hemodynamic stability, usually 2–3 hours following initial resuscitation.

HHS is a severe complication of type 2 diabetes mellitus characterized by extreme hyperglycemia (glucose >600 mg/dL), along with hyperosmolality (>300 mOsm/L), dehydration, and pH >7.3 in the absence of significant ketosis. Serum sodium levels may be normal or low, but the corrected sodium, which is calculated by adding 1.6 mEq/L for every 100 mg/dL increase in serum glucose above 100 mg/dL, is usually elevated. Patients often present with hypotension due to severe dehydration.

In HHS, hypovolemia and hyperglycemia need proper fluid resuscitation and insulin therapy, respectively.

* Fluid resuscitation:

* Initial fluid resuscitation: 1–3 liters of 0.9% normal saline (NS) over 2–3 hours to restore hemodynamic stability.

* Next step: Switch to 0.45% saline to correct the free water deficit once blood pressure is normalized, particularly if corrected sodium is elevated.

* Subsequent step: Add 5% dextrose once plasma glucose falls to 200–250 mg/dL.

* Insulin therapy:

* IV bolus: 0.1 unit/kg

* IV infusion: 0.1 unit/kg/hour (can be increased if the serum glucose level does not reduce) initially followed by a reduction to 0.02–0.1 unit/kg/hour once the glucose level falls to 200–250 mg/dL.

* Insulin infusion is stopped, and the patient is shifted to subcutaneous insulin after the patient can take food orally.

Other options:

Option B: Continuing 0.9% NS is inappropriate as the patient is already hemodynamically stable. Further administration may worsen hypernatremia.

Option C: Switching to 5% dextrose is usually done after the management of fluid deficit by 0.45% saline, and when the blood glucose reaches 200–250 mg/dL.

Option D: Ringer's lactate is usually avoided in this patient due to its electrolyte composition and the conversion of lactate into glucose that can exacerbate the already present hyperglycemia.

questions.text: 105. A 25-year-old contact lens user presents with complaints of mucopurulent discharge from his left eye associated with photophobia. Slit-lamp examination of his tarsal conjunctiva shows circular red elevations with apical infiltrates. Which of the following term is used to describe this slip lamp finding?
questions.solution:
The term 'papillae' is used to describe the above-mentioned slit-lamp finding.

The presence of papillae is one of the clinical signs of conjunctivitis. It has the following features

* They are the hyperplasia of the normal vascular system with glomerulus-like bunches of capillaries growing into the epithelium. Hence, they appear as red elevations.

* Infiltrates represent the cells recruited to the site of inflammation, and they typically accompany a papillary response.

* Size less than 1mm is macropapilla; whereas the size greater than 1mm is the giant papilla.

* Causes for this include bacterial conjunctivitis, allergic conjunctivitis, chronic blepharitis, and wearing contact lenses.

Other Options:

Option A: Granulomas are fleshy, sessile or pedunculated lesions with inflammatory tissue. They usually result from some form of chronic local irritation, such as the presence of a foreign body. 

Option B: Follicles are multiple, discrete, yellowish-white, round elevations, 1-2 mm in diameter. They are due to localised aggregations of lymphocytes in the sub-epithelial adenoid layer. Follicles are most prominent in the fornices. The common causes are viral and chlamydial conjunctivitis.

Option D: Chemosis is used to describe the conjunctival oedema.

The images below show the papillae and follicles, respectively.

questions.text: 106. A patient with central diabetes insipidus is treated with desmopressin, and the effect on urine osmolality is illustrated in the graph. Later, the patient is started on Drug X for another condition, without considering its interaction with desmopressin. The subsequent urine osmolality is also depicted in the graph. Drug X is most likely:
questions.solution:
The drug ‘X’, responsible for blunting the antidiuretic action of desmopressin, as shown in the graph, is lithium.

Desmopressin, a vasopressin analogue, is a selective V2 receptor agonist and is the drug of choice for central diabetes insipidus. Stimulation of V2 receptors, located on the basolateral membrane of principal cells in the collecting ducts, increases intracellular cAMP, which activates protein kinase A, leading to the insertion of aquaporin-2 water channels into the apical membrane. This enhances water reabsorption by increasing membrane permeability. Prolonged V2 stimulation also promotes aquaporin-2 gene expression, further increasing water retention.

Several drugs, such as lithium, demeclocycline, and ethanol, can attenuate the antidiuretic response to desmopressin. Lithium reduces V2 receptor-mediated activation of adenylyl cyclase, lowering cAMP and impairing aquaporin-2 insertion. It also raises plasma PTH, which partially antagonizes vasopressin, further blunting desmopressin’s effect.

In contrast, drugs including carbamazepine, chlorpropamide, morphine, tricyclic antidepressants, and NSAIDs can potentiate the antidiuretic effects of these peptides.

Pearl PM1488: Types of vasopressin receptors and their functions

Receptor Localization Functions
V1a
  • Vascular smooth muscle
  • Platelets
  • Hepatocytes
  • Myometrium
  • Vasoconstriction
  • Platelet aggregation
  • Glycogenolysis
  • Uterine contraction
V3/V1b 
  • Anterior pituitary
  • ACTH release
V2
  • Basolateral membrane of collecting tubule
  • Vascular endothelium
  • Vascular  smooth muscle
  • Upregulation of Aqp2
  • vwF & factor 8 release
  • Vasodilation

questions.text: 107. A middle-aged woman complains of urine dribbling from the vagina. On further examination and investigation, she is diagnosed with a vesicovaginal fistula. Which of the following is false about the management of her condition?

choices.text: Latzko procedure is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula, caused by cancer cervix
Following a failed attempt, a second attempt can be made after 4 weeks
Continous bladder drainage required for 14 days postoperatively
Sexual abstinence for 3 months is advised after the surgery

questions.solution:
In case the fistula repair fails, a second attempt is made only after 3 months.

Vesicovaginal fistula(VVF) is a type of genital fistula, which is an abnormal communication between the genital tract and the urinary tract. It occurs mostly due to obstetric injuries such as prolonged labor, and instrumental or manipulative deliveries. Patients present with true incontinence characterised by constant dribbling of urine.

Small fistulas due to difficult childbirth can heal spontaneously. In the case of an established fistula, it is better to wait for about 3 months for all tissue inflammation to subside, before surgery is undertaken. Most vesicovaginal fistulas are repaired per vaginally. The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF are as follows:

* Latzko procedure: It is done by denudation of vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges and approximation of raw surface with absorbable sutures. This technique is suited for a post-hysterectomy fistula that is caused by cancer cervix (Option A). It can lead to narrowing of the vagina or vaginal atresia. Fistula located at the vaginal vault, post hysterectomy is the most difficult to treat; this technique is suited for such cases.

* Chassar-Moir technique: Here, the vagina and bladder are separated and sutured into two layers, taking care to avoid tension and overlapping suture lines. 

* Ureteric implantation into the sigmoid colon in case previous surgeries fail.

Post-operatively, continuous bladder drainage for 14 days (Option C) along with antibiotics is recommended. Vaginal or speculum examination and intercourse are not advised for 3 months after surgery (Option D). Avoiding pregnancy for a year is also recommended. A cesarean section is usually done for future pregnancies.

Pearl PM1135: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section
Clinical features

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is unable to micturate

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is able to micturate
Methylene blue 3-swab test Middle swab stains with methylene blue   Uppermost swab stains with urine, but not with methylene blue
Intravenous pyelography Normal Hydronephrosis and hydroureter present on the affected side


Pearl PM1134: Methylene blue - 3 swab test

In the methylene blue 3-swab test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus. A diluted solution of methylene blue dye is injected into the bladder using a transurethral catheter. After 15 to 30 minutes, the swabs are removed serially and inspected for dye.

Interpretation:

* Upper swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter: Ureterovaginal fistula

* Middle swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder: Vesicovaginal fistula

* Lower swab gets stained - the leak is from the urethra: Urethrovaginal fistula

The given image shows the 3-swab test.

questions.text: 108. You are a resident doctor who tends to a patient brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. He has an open fracture of the tibia, his limbs are cold and clammy and his BP is 90/50 mmHg, and pulse 130 beats/min. You start the patient on IV Plasma-Lyte. The true statement about this IV fluid is that:

choices.text: It is an isotonic electrolyte preparation
It does not have buffer action

questions.solution:
The true statement about Plasma-Lyte is that it is a crystalloid fluid with isotonic electrolyte composition.

The type of fluid administered to a patient depends on his/her volume status and the type of compositional abnormality present. Plasma- Lyte is isotonic and is useful in replacing gastrointestinal losses and correcting extracellular volume deficits.

Plasma-Lyte is an isotonic crystalloid preparation; it resembles the electrolyte composition of the human plasma very closely. In addition, Plasma- Lyte contains a number of additional buffers that create a favourable profile for helping with acidosis.

It consists of 140 mEq/L of sodium, 98 mEq/L of chloride, 5 mEq/L of potassium, 27 mEq/L of bicarbonate and 3 mEq/L of Magnesium.

These properties have resulted in Plasma-Lyte becoming one of the most popular isotonic fluids for use, especially in surgery. However, Plasma- Lyte contains small quantities of potassium; and though the likelihood of inducing hyperkalemia is very low, care should be taken when using Plasma-Lyte in patients at risk for renal impairment.

questions.text: 109. Which of the following is false regarding the deposits that would be seen in amyloidosis?

choices.text: Deposits look like amorphous eosinophilic material under normal light with H&E stain.
Congo red stain imparts green birefringence when viewed under polarized light.
Perl's Prussian blue gives the deposits a dark blue color.
Congo red stain imparts pink color to deposits under normal light.

questions.solution:
Perl's Prussian blue stain is used in hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue, which shows hepatocellular iron. Iron is stained blue with this stain.



Amyloidosis refers to extracellular deposits of fibrillar proteins. 

Abnormal fibrils are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits bind a wide variety of proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, including heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, and plasma proteins, notably serum amyloid P component (SAP). Amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

It could be classified as systemic, localized, and hereditary amyloidosis. Microscopically, all types of amyloid deposits are made up of continuous, nonbranching fibrils. A characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation is visualized on X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy.

The stain used for amyloid deposits is congo red staining, which imparts pink to red color to the amyloid under ordinary light and apple-green birefringence under polarised microscopy.

The image shows a congo-red stained biopsy specimen with the following:

(A) focal positive staining (orange-red) of amorphous extracellular material

(B) apple-green birefringence under polarized light 

The next best step is to determine the type of precursor protein by immunohistochemistry, immunoelectron microscopy, or extraction and biochemical analysis using mass spectrometry.



Amyloid deposits and Paget cells observed in Paget disease are stained by Alcian blue.

questions.text: 110. A person posted for nephrolithotomy was placed in a surgical position as shown in the image below. Traction injury of which of the following structures is a potential complication of this position?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the lateral or kidney position used in urological and retroperitoneal procedures. Traction injury of the brachial plexus is a potential complication of this position.

The modified lateral position, called the kidney position, is used in urological and retroperitoneal procedures. Here, the lower leg of the patient is slightly flexed at the knee. A pillow is placed between both legs, and the upper leg is flexed in a more exaggerated position. Arms are fixed in the stirrups.

Complications associated with this procedure are:

* Respiratory complications due to more ventilation of one lung over the other.

* Traction injury of the brachial plexus and ulnar nerve.

* Corneal abrasions and ocular trauma.

Other Options:

Option A: Entrapment of the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh is seen with the lithotomy position, prone position and beach chair position.

Option B: Common fibular nerve can be injured in the lithotomy position if the legs are not supported properly.

Option C: Intercostobrachial nerve is injured in axillary surgeries, particularly with arm abduction.

questions.text: 111. A 2-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with a history of recurrent abscesses secondary to staphylococcus aureus infection. Primary immunodeficiency was suspected. The nitro-blue tetrazolium test was performed which was negative. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this patient with a suspected primary immunodeficiency, repeated infections with Staphylococcus aureus (catalase-positive organisms) and a negative nitro-blue tetrazolium test is suggestive of Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD).

It is due to a defect in NADPH oxidase, the enzyme responsible for the generation of superoxide during the respiratory burst. Defective inherent production of reactive oxygen species leads to increased susceptibility to life-threatening infections- pulmonary, cutaneous, lymphatic, hepatic, and osteomyelitis. These patients are susceptible to catalase-positive organisms like Staphylococcus and Coliforms.

The nitro blue tetrazolium test can be used for the diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease. The leukocytes fail to reduce nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) during phagocytosis in chronic granulomatous disease.

Other options: 

Option A: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is a disorder of T-lymphocytes(cellular immunity) and is characterised by the triad of recurrent severe infections, thrombocytopenia, and eczema.

Option C: Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a primary immunodeficiency due to a disorder of the phagolysosome function of leukocytes, leading to delayed microbial clearance. In addition, there is a disorder of melanin(albinism), nerve defects, and bleeding disorders.

Option D: Severe combined immunodeficiency is a primary immunodeficiency with a disorder of both cellular and humoral immunity. Persons with SCID are susceptible to recurrent severe infections caused by a wide variety of pathogens and usually do not survive beyond the first year of life without a stem cell transplant.

questions.text:
112. A 32-year-old woman, G2P0A1, presents with 7 weeks of amenorrhea, severe lower abdominal pain, and dizziness. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Transvaginal ultrasound shows an empty uterus and a complex adnexal mass. Free fluid is also visualized in the hepatorenal (Morison) pouch. What is the most likely approximate volume of intraperitoneal bleeding in this case?

Vitals: Pulse: 124 beats per minute Blood pressure: 90/60 mmHg
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy in which approximately 400-600 mL of intraperitoneal bleeding is present.

An ectopic pregnancy occurs when a fertilized ovum implants outside the normal endometrial cavity, most commonly in the fallopian tube. It typically presents in reproductive-age women with amenorrhea, a positive pregnancy test, and acute lower abdominal pain. 

The classic triad includes abdominal pain, missed periods of 6–8 weeks, and vaginal bleeding. Pain may radiate to the shoulder tip, particularly after rupture, and can be associated with vomiting, fainting, or pallor. On examination, the uterus is normal or slightly bulky, the vaginal mucosa may be blanched, and fornix tenderness may be present.

Transvaginal sonography (TVS) aids diagnosis, showing an empty uterus, echogenic fluid in the pouch of Douglas, and an adnexal mass separate from the ovary. Color Doppler may reveal a ring-of-fire pattern with increased blood flow outside the uterus.

Rupture of the ectopic gestation, often in the fallopian tube, can cause significant intra-abdominal bleeding, leading to tachycardia, hypotension, cold, clammy extremities, and shock. Reflex vasomotor disturbances may result in syncope, making prompt recognition and management critical

Morison's pouch, a dependent area in the right upper quadrant, often collects blood from a ruptured ectopic pregnancy via the right pericolic gutter. On ultrasound, free fluid is usually detected only after at least 400–600 mL of blood has accumulated. In a hemodynamically unstable woman, fluid in Morison's pouch indicates significant hemoperitoneum and typically warrants emergency surgical intervention.

questions.text: 113. A pathologist is examining slides of renal tissue to study glomerular pathology. Which of the following will she not observe on H & E staining or electron microscopy findings?

choices.text: Spike and dome appearance on electron microscopy is seen in membranous nephropathy
Podocyte effacement on light microscopy is seen in Minimal Change disease
Crescents and necrosis are seen on light microscopy in Goodpasture syndrome
Basket-weave appearance of GBM on electron microscopy in Alport syndrome

questions.solution:
The effacement of the foot process can only be observed on electron microscopy. Effacement of the podocyte foot processes is characteristically seen in minimal change disease (MCD), which is also called lipoid nephrosis. Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.

It is also seen in other conditions such as membranous nephropathy and focal segmental glomerulosclerosis. Since the podocytes are affected in these diseases, they are also known as podocytopathies.

Other options:

Option A: Spike and dome appearance on electron microscopy is characteristically seen in membranous nephropathy. Membranous nephropathy is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. 

Option C: Extracapillary proliferation with crescents and necrosis is seen on light microscopy in Goodpasture syndrome. Linear deposits along the basement membrane, along with disruptions in the glomerular basement membrane, are seen on electron microscopy.

Option D: Basket-weave appearance of glomerular basement membrane on electron microscopy in Alport syndrome. Light microscopy is normal.

questions.text: 114. A woman underwent a routine PAP smear, which showed a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL). On colposcopy, the entire squamocolumnar junction was not visible. Biopsy from the visible part suggested a cervical intraepithelial neoplasia 3 (CIN 3) lesion with suspected microinvasion. What is the preferred treatment modality in this case?
questions.solution:
Conization is the preferred treatment modality when microinvasion is suspected in a patient with CIN 3 lesion and when the entire squamocolumnar junction is not visible.

Cone biopsy involves a wide cone excision that includes the entire outer margin of the lesion and the entire endocervical lining, by using the cold-knife technique under general anesthesia. Disadvantages include bleeding, infection, cervical stenosis, and cervical incompetence.

Indications of conization

*

* Endocervical dysplasia

* Transformation zone not completely visualized

* Discrepancy between cytology, colposcopy, and biopsy findings

* Suspected microinvasion

Other options:

Option A: Cryotherapy is done in CIN lesions not extending into the endocervical canal and in ectocervix lesions not associated with unsatisfactory colposcopic examination or abnormal glandular cytology. It is generally not favoured in CIN 3 because of the high risk of disease persistence after treatment and because it does not allow for the collection of a histologic specimen, which would help rule out occult invasive cancer.

Option B: Laser ablation is done in low-grade lesions, where the entire transformation zone is visible by colposcopy with no evidence of microinvasive, invasive, or glandular disease. The cytology and histology should correlate positively.

Option D: Hysterectomy is not preferred in CIN lesions, except in cases with recurrent or persistent lesions, where repeat excision is not feasible technically, in older and parous women who have completed families after ruling out invasive cancers.

questions.text: 115. A 28-year-old primigravida at 41 weeks of gestation is admitted for induction of labor. She is given an intravenous infusion of an agent that mimics physiological uterine contractions. Which of the following best describes the mechanism by which this agent induces uterine contractions?

choices.text: Stimulates adenylate cyclase via Gs protein to increase cAMP
Opens ligand-gated calcium channels to depolarize the myometrium
Activates phospholipase C via Gq protein to increase intracellular calcium
Inhibits myosin light-chain phosphatase to promote actin-myosin binding

questions.solution:
The agent used for the induction of labor that mimics physiological uterine contractions is oxytocin. It acts via Gq protein-coupled receptors, activating phospholipase C and increasing intracellular calcium.

The signal transduction process following the binding of oxytocin, a nonapeptide to its receptors is given below:

Oxytocin binds to Gq protein-coupled receptors on uterine smooth muscle cells ↓ Activation of phospholipase C (PLC) ↓ Generation of inositol triphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG) ↓ IP3 causes the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum ↓ Increase in intracellular calcium ↓ Calcium binds to calmodulin ↓ Activation of myosin light-chain kinase (MLCK) ↓ Phosphorylation of myosin ↓ Smooth muscle contraction

The smooth muscle contraction seen with the use of oxytocin is physiological, i.e., it causes fundal contraction and cervical relaxation that helps in the delivery of the fetus, and makes oxytocin a good agent for the induction of labor.

The following are some other uses of oxytocin:

* Cervical ripening before induction

* Augmentation of labor

* Uterine inertia

* Acceleration of abortion

* Active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL)

* Control of postpartum hemorrhage.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors, as they bind and become activated in the nucleus, as mentioned above. However, they have two primary sites of action: the cytoplasm and the nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: 116. A neonate presents with multiple congenital anomalies. The clinician suspects a chromosomal disorder, but no specific gene or chromosome locus has been identified. Which of the following diagnostic modalities would be the most appropriate in this scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given case, there is no specific chromosomal region or DNA sequence that could be targeted. Therefore, the most suitable diagnostic approach is a Single-Nucleotide Polymorphism (SNP) genotyping array.

Microarray technology enables the detection of genomic abnormalities without requiring prior knowledge of the affected gene or chromosomal region, as it performs a comprehensive genome-wide analysis. Earlier platforms focused on comparative genomic hybridization (CGH), while newer ones also include SNP genotyping for enhanced analysis.

FISH, Southern blotting, and RT-PCR rely on the use of specific probes or primers designed for known sequences. Since a particular target cannot be identified in this scenario, these techniques are not particularly useful.

questions.text:
117. The stain used for the preparation of the blood smear shown below is?

H&E - Hematoxylin and eosin
questions.solution:
The given peripheral blood smear shows ring forms of Plasmodium falciparum inside red blood cells, prepared using Giemsa stain.

Giemsa stain is a polychromatic Romanowsky stain commonly used for staining peripheral blood smears. After Giemsa staining, erythrocytes appear pink to pale grey, providing contrast that highlights the parasite’s intracellular morphology.

A thin blood smear helps identify the species of malaria parasite, whereas a thick smear is used primarily for detection. Thus, a Giemsa-stained peripheral smear aids in malaria diagnosis by revealing asexual stages of Plasmodium within red cells.

Other options: 

Option A: Albert stain is used to demonstrate the volutin granules (metachromatic/Babes-Ernst granules) of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. After Albert staining, green rods with blue-black polar granules are seen, as shown in the image below.



Option B: H&E stain is mainly used for tissue sections in histopathology. When used on blood, erythrocytes appear intensely red, as shown in the image below.



Option D: Papanicolaou stain is commonly used for cytological specimens, such as Pap smears. It imparts dark blue to black nuclei, while the cytoplasm takes variable colors (pink, blue-green, or orange) depending on the cell type. The image given below shows papanicolaou staining of a cervical pap smear.

questions.text: 118. While calculating the dependency ratio for a certain demographic population, an epidemiologist concludes that the particular population is at a demographic bonus. Which of the following is true about the population under evaluation?

choices.text: Decline in dependency ratio and increase in life expectancy
Rise in dependency ratio and decrease in fertility
Rise in dependency ratio and increase in life expectancy
Decline in dependency ratio and decrease in fertility

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, demographic bonus refers to the decline in dependency ratio due to declining fertility.

Dependency ratio:

In any given population, persons above the age of 65 years and children below the age of 15 years are considered as dependents. The total dependency ratio is the ratio of the combined dependent population to those in the age group of 15 – 65 years and is calculated using the formula given below:

Total dependency ratio = (Total population below 15 years and above 65 years) x 100/Total population in the age group of 15 – 64 years.

It is also called societal dependency ratio.

The total dependency ratio can also be divided into young age dependency ratio and old-age dependency ratio. Potential support ratio is the number of persons aged 15 to 64 years per older person aged 65 or more. This is the inverse of the old age dependency ratio.

Other important terms based on dependency ratio:

* The term demographic bonus denotes the decline in dependency ratio due to declining fertility.

* The term demographic burden is used to denote the increase in total dependency ratio during any period of time mostly caused by increased old-age dependency ratio.

questions.text: 119. A 28-year-old woman with dysmenorrhoea and dyspareunia is suspected to have endometriosis. On what basis would this condition be staged?
questions.solution:
Endometriosis is staged according to the American Society of Reproductive Medicine (ASRM) system based on the extent of the disease as directly visualised on surgery/laparoscopy.

According to the ASRM system, based on the intra-operative findings, endometriosis of the ovaries, fallopian tubes, cul-de-sac and peritoneum is scored according to the surface area involved, depth, morphology and adhesions, and endometriosis is staged as Stage I (minimal), Stage II (mild), Stage III (moderate) and Stage IV (severe). 

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrium at a site outside the uterine cavity. It can be found in ectopic sites such as the ovary, pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligaments, appendix, pelvic lymph nodes, lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) scar endometriosis, umbilicus, and lung.

Dysmenorrhea is the most common presenting symptom, associated with abdominal and pelvic pain, menorrhagia, dyspareunia and infertility. Laparoscopy is the gold standard modality for the diagnosis and treatment of endometriosis. Typical characteristics include 'powder-burn' - puckered black spots, red vascular, bluish, blackish cysts, chocolate cysts, and dense adhesions in the pelvis.

For minimal disease, medical management with NSAIDs and oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) is given if associated menstrual complaints are present. OCPs inhibit gonadotropin release and decrease the menstrual flow. For moderate to severe diseases, oral progestogens, GnRH agonists or danazol that antagonise estrogenic effects on the endometrium, causing endometrial atrophy, are used.

Surgery is preferred in patients with infertility. Endometrial deposits are destroyed by electrocautery/laser, and resection of endometrioma can be done. Total hysterectomy with bilateral oophorectomy is a definitive and most effective therapy for women with endometriosis who do not wish to retain fertility.

Pearl PM1005: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

* Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.

* Rectovaginal endometriosis.

* Ovarian endometriosis.

* Chocolate cyst of the ovary.

* Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.

* Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

* Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.

* Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.

* Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).

* Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.

* Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: 120. A 6-month-old infant is diagnosed with growth failure, pancreatic insufficiency, and macrocytic anemia. Bone marrow examination reveals ringed sideroblasts. What is the most likely diagnosis for this condition?
questions.solution:
Pancreatic insufficiency accompanied by macrocytic anemia and bone marrow showing ringed sideroblasts is characteristic of Pearson Syndrome.

Pearson syndrome, also called marrow-pancreas syndrome, arises from defects in mitochondrial DNA. Infants are mainly affected, and they present with severe macrocytic anemia and varying degrees of thrombocytopenia. In the bone marrow, vacuolization is observed in erythroid and myeloid precursor cells, along with the presence of ringed sideroblasts. The disease leads to severe bone marrow dysfunction and impaired growth due to pancreatic insufficiency. Mutations may be inherited from the mother or arise de novo.

Other options:

Option A: Fanconi anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder marked by pancytopenia and congenital abnormalities. However, it is not commonly linked to pancreatic insufficiency or the presence of ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow.

Option C: Diamond-Blackfan syndrome is a rare inherited bone marrow failure syndrome that presents with anemia and low reticulocyte levels, and the bone marrow demonstrates a significant reduction or absence of erythroid precursors while maintaining normal overall cellularity.

Option D: Congenital sideroblastic anemia is typically an X-linked condition caused most often by mutations in the erythroid-specific ALA synthase gene. Affected red blood cells are microcytic and hypochromic, and pancreatic involvement is absent. Pearson syndrome is regarded as a variant of congenital sideroblastic anemia, though the anemia in Pearson syndrome is macrocytic.

questions.text: 121. A body is recovered from a river after three days. Autopsy shows heavy, waterlogged lungs but no froth at the mouth, and the diatom test is negative in bone marrow. Which of the following best explains these lung findings?
questions.solution:
Hydrostatic lung best explains these findings.

If a dead body is immersed in water, hydrostatic pressure can cause water to enter the lungs, making the lungs heavy and waterlogged,producing what is known as a hydrostatic lung, which closely resembles a true drowning lung.

A body left submerged at a depth of about 2 metres for around 20 hours may develop such a lung appearance. The absence of fine, persistent froth, and a negative diatom test in bone marrow points towards postmortem drowning (Drowning after death). The presence of a true drowning lung along with frothy fluid is considered diagnostic of drowning. 

Other options:

Option A. Edema aquosum occurs due to the accumulation of fluid in the lungs due to increased vascular permeability; lungs are heavy and wet without froth. It occurs when a person is alive and unconscious. Diatom test is positive with no paltauf's haemorrhage (Antemortem drowning).

Option C. Emphysema aquosum is a condition where alveolar walls are destroyed and replaced by fluid-filled cystic spaces, resembling emphysema but with fluid. Froth is also present. The diatom test is positive along with Paltauf's haemorrhage (Antemortem drowning).

Option D. Paltauf sign/haemorrhages are subpleural hemorrhagic spots seen on the anterior and lower lobes of the lungs, usually 1–2 cm in diameter, pale pink or bluish-red in colour. They result from rupture of intra-alveolar walls due to forced expiration against water-filled lungs during antemortem drowning

Pearl PM1454: Differentiating features between Antemortem amd Postmortem drowning

Feature        Antemortem drowning       Postmortem drowning

questions.text: 122. A young male was brought to the hospital following a bike accident. Maxillary fractures were present, associated with CSF rhinorrhea. A CT scan reveals fracture line passing through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, the floor of the orbit, the upper part of the maxillary sinus, and the pterygoid plate. What type of Le Fort fracture is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
A Le Fort-II fracture is seen in the above given clinical scenario.

Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture.

* Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of orbit, upper part of maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates.

* X-ray or CT appears like a hanging maxilla.

* It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

The image below shows a Le Fort II fracture.



Pearl PM0946: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla

* Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates

* It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate

* Also called Guerin’s fracture. 

Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture

* Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates

* X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla

* It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment

* Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates

* It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: 123. Which of the following is most likely to amplify the gastrocolic reflex in a newborn baby, leading to frequent defecation after meals?

choices.text: Cholecystokinin response to fat in breast milk
Gastrin release after distention from the stomach
Lactose induced fermentation and gas production
Triggering of rectal stretch receptors by milk caesin

questions.solution:
The gastrocolic reflex is amplified by the action of gastrin, which is released on distension of the stomach after feeds.

GIT reflexes, which are mediated by prevertebral sympathetic ganglia, include:

* Gastrocolic reflex- Distension of the stomach and digestive byproducts in the small intestine activates afferents to the prevertebral sympathetic ganglia. This results in stimulation of the colon and an urge to defecate. 

* Enterogastric reflex- signals from the colon and small intestine inhibit stomach motility and secretion

* Colonoileal reflex- signals from the colon to inhibit the emptying of ileal contents into the colon

GIT reflexes, which are mediated by the brain stem and spinal cord, include:

* Pain reflexes that cause inhibition of the whole gastrointestinal tract

* Long-distance vagal reflexes regulating gastric motor and secretory activity

* Defecation reflex- Distension of the rectum and colon results in powerful contractions of the rectum, colon, and abdominal wall, which are required for defecation.

Other options:

Option A: While cholecystokinin (CCK) plays a role in digestion, it is not directly involved in initiating the reflex. CCK is more involved in gallbladder and pancreatic enzyme secretion, not directly related to colonic motility. Lactose fermentation may increase colonic motility in some people, but it's not the main driver of the immediate post-feeding reflex in infants.

Option C: Lactose fermentation may increase colonic motility in some people, but it's not the main driver of the immediate post-feeding reflex in infants.

Option D: While stretch receptors play a role in defecation, they are primarily located in the sigmoid colon and rectum, not directly activated by stomach distension and are part of the colonoileal reflex.

questions.text: 124. A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic after experiencing a sudden, sharp pain in his right ankle while playing badminton. He reports hearing a distinct popping sound at the time of injury. He is unable to bear weight on the affected leg and is limping. X-ray of the right ankle and foot is unremarkable. Which of the following clinical tests will help to reach a clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
As described in the clinical vignette, the most probable diagnosis here is acute Achilles tendon rupture, and the Thompson test can be used to reach a clinical diagnosis. 

Achilles tendon rupture most commonly occurs at the vascular watershed area, approximately 5 cm above its insertion on the calcaneum, typically seen in individuals engaged in sports requiring vigorous thrust. Patients often report a popping or snapping sensation (which can also be heard) at the back of the heel, followed by sudden, sharp pain and an inability to bear weight or walk properly on the affected limb.

The Thompson test (squeeze test) is a provocative test used to demonstrate the continuity of the Achilles tendon with the gastrosoleus complex. The examiner squeezes the calf muscles and observes for plantar flexion of the foot.

* Positive test: Absence of plantar flexion → indicates complete rupture of the Achilles tendon.

* Negative test: Presence of plantar flexion → indicates intact tendon.

A palpable gap may also be felt in complete rupture.

The image below shows the Thompson test with a negative result:



Ultrasound can be used to confirm the clinical diagnosis. Management options include:

* Non-operative: Functional bracing and physiotherapy (fewer complications but higher re-rupture rate).

* Operative: Open/percutaneous repair or V-Y plasty of the tendon (lower re-rupture rate but higher risk of complications).

Other options: 

Option A: The Thessaly test is used in cases of meniscal injuries. In this test, the affected knee is flexed at a 20-degree angle, and the patient places the foot flat on the ground. The examiner provides support, and the patient bears their full weight on that leg. They are then instructed to twist their body to one side and then the other, repeating this movement three times, while maintaining the knee flexed at 20 degrees. Individuals with meniscal tears will complain of pain along the medial or lateral joint line and may also sense a locking in the knee



Option C: The tiptoe test, also known as the tiptoe standing test, is a clinical assessment used to evaluate the nature of flatfoot (pes planus). It helps differentiate between flexible and fixed flatfoot conditions. On toe standing, the medial arch of the foot forms, and the heels can be seen to invert, as shown in the image below. This indicates that the subtalar joints are mobile, pointing towards a flexible flatfoot.



Option D: The Thomas test is used to diagnose fixed flexion deformity of the unilateral hip masked by exaggerated lumbar lordosis. While lying supine, the unaffected hip of the patient is flexed over the abdomen until the lumbar lordotic curve disappears. The affected hip then assumes a position of flexion, and the degree of fixed flexion deformity is calculated by the angle formed between the affected thigh and the bed.

questions.text: 125. Subcutaneous administration of somatropin in a child with growth retardation will be beneficial in all of the following cases except:
questions.solution:
Administration of subcutaneous somatropin (GH analogue) will not be beneficial in a child with Laron dwarfism.

Laron dwarfism is caused by a loss-of-function mutation in the growth hormone (GH) receptors. As a result, GH is unable to exert its physiological effects despite normal or elevated levels in circulation. This leads to significantly reduced levels of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1). The condition is therefore also referred to as growth hormone resistance. Administration of a GH analogue is not beneficial in this case, as the receptors are defective.

Mecasermin (recombinant human IGF-1) is approved for patients with impaired growth secondary to mutations in the growth hormone receptor.

The following are the indications for GH administration:

* GH deficiency

* Turner syndrome 

* Noonan syndrome 

* Prader-Willi syndrome 

* Chronic renal insufficiency

* Children born small for gestational age (SGA)

* Idiopathic short stature

* AIDS-associated wasting

* Short-bowel syndrome with malabsorption

Other options:

Option A: Turner syndrome (45, XO) results from the loss or structural abnormality of one X chromosome in females. They have short stature, but their GH receptors are fully functional. Administration of somatropin improves height and is beneficial. 

Option B: Noonan syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition, characterized by short stature, short webbed neck, cystic hygroma, tall forehead, low posterior hairline, and dental malocclusion. GH therapy is effective because the GH receptor pathway is intact, allowing children to achieve better growth outcomes.

Option D: Prader-Willi syndrome occurs due to the deletion of band 15q12 on the paternal chromosome and the silencing of the same set of genes derived from maternal chromosomes, which ends up causing mental retardation, obesity, hyperphagia, hypogonadism, short stature, small hands and feet, and abnormal facial features. Because GH receptors are functional, subcutaneous somatropin improves growth in these children.

questions.text: 126. Name the type of joint shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The interosseous membrane between the middle part of the radial and ulnar shafts shown in the image is a syndesmosis type of joint. 

A syndesmosis is a type of fibrous joint. This type of joint can be represented by an interosseous ligament, such as the interosseous membrane found between the radial and ulnar shafts.

The proximal and distal radioulnar joints are examples of a Pivot joint (synovial joint).

The types of fibrous joints are as shown below:



Structural Classification of joints includes fibrous, cartilaginous and synovial joints.

* Fibrous Joints: Bones united by dense fibrous connective tissue. No joint cavity present. Mostly immovable (synarthroses), e.g., Sutures (skull), syndesmosis (distal tibiofibular joint, middle radioulnar joint), gomphoses (tooth in socket).

* Cartilaginous Joints: Bones united by cartilage (hyaline or fibrocartilage). No joint cavity. Allow slight movement (amphiarthroses). They have two types: Synchondrosis (primary cartilaginous Joints, e.g., epiphyseal plate) and Symphyses (secondary cartilaginous joints, e.g., pubic symphysis, intervertebral discs).

* Synovial Joints: Have a synovial cavity with articular cartilage and a fibrous capsule. Freely movable (diarthroses). Most common and varied joint types, e.g., shoulder, knee, hip.

Other options: 

Option A: Synchondrosis or primary cartilaginous joint occurs where advancing centres of ossification remain separated by an area of hyaline cartilage. They are temporary joints because the cartilaginous plate gets replaced by bone. 

Option C: Secondary cartilaginous joints, or symphyses, consist of a fibrocartilage pad between the articular (hyaline) cartilage of two bones. Intervertebral discs and pubic symphysis are key examples. 

Below is the image showing primary (a) and secondary (b) cartilaginous joints are shown below:



Option D: Synovial joints are freely moving joints where the bony surfaces are covered with smooth hyaline articular cartilage and are separated by a layer of viscous synovial fluid, which acts as a lubricant.



Pearl PM2388: Types of Synovial Joints

Classification of Synovial Joints
Type Articular surfaces Movement Examples
1. Plane Almost flat Minimal sliding movements Intercarpal, intermetacarpal, carpometacarpal (except first), intertarsal, intermetatarsal, tarsometatarsal, joints between articular processes of vertebrae, cricothyroid joint, cricoarytenoid joint, superior tibiofibular, interchondral joint (5-9 ribs), costovertebral, costotransverse, acromioclavicular, chondrosternal (except first) joints
2. Hinge Pulley shaped Uniaxial - flexion & extension Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints
3. Pivot Central pivot (peg) surrounded by osteoligamentous ring Uniaxial - rotation (supination and pronation) Superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint
4. Condylar (bicondylar) 2 convex condyles articulate with concave or flat surfaces on the other side Biaxial - but predominantly one axis movement (flexion & extension) with limited rotation Knee joint, temporomandibular joint
5. Ellipsoid Oval convex surface fitting into an elliptical concavity Biaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction Radiocarpal (wrist), metacarpophalangeal joints
6. Saddle Each articular surface has a concave and convex region fitting the convex and concave regions of the other surface Biaxial - mainly 2 axis, flexion & extension,  abduction & adduction; very limited coupled axial rotation (conjunct rotation)  First carpometacarpal joint (of thumb), calcaneocuboid joints, incudomalleolar joint, sternoclavicular joint
7. Ball & Socket Globular head fitting into a cup-shaped socket Multiaxial - flexion & extension, abduction & adduction, circumduction, and rotation Shoulder, hip, talocalcaneonavicular, incudostapedial joint

questions.text: 127. What kind of host does a fish serve for the plerocercoid larva of Diphyllobothrium latum?
questions.solution:
A fish serves as a paratenic host for the plerocercoid larva of Diphyllobothrium latum. A paratenic host is a host in which the larval stage of the parasite remains viable without further development. Such a host transmits the infection to another host. 

In the life cycle of Diphyllobothrium latum, humans are the optimal definitive host where the adult tapeworm resides and produces eggs. The first intermediate host is a freshwater copepod (mainly of the genera Cyclops or Diaptomus), which harbours the procercoid larva. When a freshwater fish such as salmon or trout consumes the infected copepod, the larva develops into a plerocercoid within the fish tissues, making it the second intermediate host.

Here, the fish also act as paratenic hosts, where the plerocercoid larva remains viable without further development. These paratenic hosts play a crucial role in transmission, as humans become infected by consuming raw or undercooked infected fish.

The following image depicts the life cycle of Diphyllobothrium latum:



Other options :

Option A: A definitive host is the host in which the adult stage of the parasite lives and sexual reproduction occurs. For Diphyllobothrium latum, humans act as the definitive host.

Option C: A reservoir host is a type of host that continuously harbours a parasite in an endemic area, serving as a key source of infection for other susceptible hosts. For example, the dog is the reservoir host for hydatid disease.

Option D: An accidental host is one in which the parasite does not normally complete its life cycle. For example, humans can act as accidental hosts for cystic Echinococcosis.

questions.text: 128. The sign seen in the following sonography is suggestive of which fetal anomaly-
questions.solution:
The lemon sign is suggestive of spina bifida.

This is called the lemon sign, as at the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of the frontal bones (indicated by the arrow). It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.



Another sign called banana sign can also be seen in spina bifida in which at the level of posterior fossa, anterior curvature of cerebellum with effacement of cisterna magna can be seen.

questions.text: 129. A middle aged male presents with complaints of difficulty to breath and cough. Contrast-enhanced CT imaging was advised and is shown below. Which of the following is not usually associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows aortic arch aneurysm in a patient with history of dyspnea. Polyarteritis nodosa is a type of vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels of the kidneys and other viscera. It does not involve the pulmonary vasculature or large vessels like the aorta.

Aortic aneurysm refers to the dilatation of the aorta which can occur in any part. It can be a true aneurysm involving all three layers of the vessel or a false aneurysm, involving only the outer adventitial layer, with blood escaping through the intima. Circumferential involvement is referred to as a fusiform aneurysm while it is called a saccular aneurysm if only part of the circumference is involved.

The most common cause is atherosclerosis, but this pathology is also closely associated with several connective tissue disorders such as:

* Marfan's syndrome

* Tertiary syphilis (syphilitic aortitis)

* Ehlers-Danlos syndrome

* Osteogenesis imperfecta

These aneurysms are often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally, but if they progressively enlarge, it can lead to symptoms suggestive of compression of the surrounding tissue (dysphagia, dyspnea, hoarseness of the voice, etc.). Aneurysm of the aortic root can cause dilatation of the aortic valve annulus and result in aortic regurgitation. Rupture can occur into the pericardium or the left pleural space, producing hypotension and dyspnea.

The diagnosis can be made with the help of a contrast-enhanced CT or MRI scan. Indications for surgery include any symptomatic aneurysm, rupture, progressive aortic valve insufficiency, symptomatic Marfan's related aneurysms of 4.5-5 cm, and descending symptomatic aneurysms >6 cm. Surgery can also be considered if the aneurysmal diameter is increasing at >1 cm per year.
