questions.text: 130. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the procedure shown in the given image?

choices.text: Patient should be asked to sit upright after the procedure
Post-procedure IV albumin has been shown to be beneficial
Lower abdominal quadrants are preferred for the procedure

questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the given image is paracentesis. Following paracentesis, the patient should be asked to lie in the supine position for a few hours. 

Paracentesis, which refers to the removal of ascitic fluid, is valuable for evaluating patients with new-onset ascites or ascites of unknown etiology. It is also indicated in patients who have a decompensation in their clinical status. Relative contraindications include bleeding diathesis, prior abdominal surgery, distended bowels, or loculated ascites. Any severe bleeding diathesis should be corrected before the procedure. Bowel distention should be relieved by placement of an NG tube, and the bladder should also be emptied before beginning the procedure.

During the procedure, the patient should be instructed to lie supine with the head end of the bed elevated. This position should be maintained for around 15 minutes so that the fluid accumulates in the dependent portion of the abdomen. The preferred entry sites for paracentesis include right or left lower quadrants of the abdomen or even a midline puncture halfway between pubic symphysis and umbilicus. To prevent leaking of the ascitic fluid, Z-tracking of the needle is helpful. The needle is advanced slowly while performing continuous aspiration. Fluid should flow freely into the syringe soon after that. For large volume paracentesis, direct drainage into large vacuum containers is commonly utilized. 

Peritoneal fluid is sent for total and differential cell count, Gram stain and bacterial cultures. Patient should be monitored following the procedure and should be asked to lie supine for a few hours. If persistent fluid leakage occurs, continued bedrest and pressure dressings are useful. For patients with decompensated liver disease undergoing large-volume paracentesis, the sudden reduction in intravascular volume can precipitate hepatorenal syndrome. Use of IV albumin in such a scenario has been shown to decrease the incidence of postprocedure renal failure.



Pearl PM2049: Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG)

The serum ascites albumin gradient is calculated as follows:

SAAG = Serum albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin

It can be used to determine the cause of ascites following ascitic fluid analysis.

questions.text:
131. A patient with HIV is initiated on HAART. There are several drugs that a physician can choose from. Which of the following options correctly matches the mechanism of action, as depicted in the image?

HAART: Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the correctly matched pairs are 2 (entry inhibitor) with Maraviroc and 4 (reverse transcriptase inhibitor) with Zidovudine.

In the given image, 

* 1 represents integrase inhibitors like Raltegravir

* 2 represents entry inhibitors like Maraviroc

* 3 represents protease inhibitors like Saquinavir

* 4 represents reverse transcriptase inhibitors like Zidovudine

Maraviroc is an entry inhibitor that acts by targeting the CCR5 receptor, preventing the viral gp120 envelope protein from binding and thereby inhibiting fusion and entry into macrophages and CD4⁺ T cells. Zidovudine, on the other hand, is a reverse transcriptase inhibitor. It is phosphorylated intracellularly to zidovudine 5′-triphosphate, which is incorporated by reverse transcriptase into viral DNA and terminates DNA chain elongation due to the absence of a 3′-hydroxyl group.

Antiretroviral drugs are classified by the phase of the retrovirus life cycle that the drug inhibits, as follows:

Antiretroviral Drug Mechanism of Action Example
Nucleotide/Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Inhibits reverse transcriptase Zidovudine, Stavudine, Lamivudine, Abacavir, Emtricitabine, Didanosine, Tenofovir
Non-Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Inhibits reverse transcriptase by binding to an allosteric site of the enzyme Nevirapine, Efavirenz, Delavirdine, Etravirine
Protease Inhibitors Inhibits the viral protease enzyme necessary to produce mature virions upon budding from the host membrane Saquinavir, Indinavir, Ritonavir, Nelfinavir, Lopinavir, Atazanavir, Tipranavir, Darunavir
Entry Inhibitors Interferes with the binding, fusion, and entry of HIV-1 into the cell by blocking a target.  Enfuvirtide, Maraviroc
Integrase Inhibitors Inhibits the viral enzyme integrase, which is responsible for the integration of viral DNA into the DNA of the infected cell Raltegravir, Elvitegravir, Dolutegravir


The illustration given below shows the mechanism of action of various antiretroviral drugs:

questions.text: 132. Which of the following is true regarding parenteral administration of alteplase?

choices.text: It increases the formation of plasminogen
It is indicated in hemorrhagic stroke
It can cause bleeding, which can be counteracted by aminocaproic acid
Alteplase has the advantage of activating free plasminogen

questions.solution:
All thrombolytics can cause bleeding, which may be counteracted by the administration of antifibrinolytics, such as aminocaproic acid and tranexamic acid.  

Alteplase is a recombinant tissue plasminogen activator and activates plasminogen bound to fibrin, and catalyses the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, resulting in increased formation of plasmin(Option A). This results in fibrinolysis of formed thrombus(thrombolysis). It is indicated in pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic instability, severe deep vein thrombosis, ascending thrombophlebitis, acute ischemic stroke and acute myocardial infarction.  

Alteplase has the advantage of only activating plasminogen bound to fibrin (clot specific) but not free plasminogen (option D). 

Contraindications of alteplase:

* Risk of bleeding(including intracranial hemorrhage (Option B), subarachnoid hemorrhage, and those with active internal bleeding)

* Recent intracranial, intraspinal surgery or head trauma in the previous 3 months

* Intracranial neoplasm, arteriovenous malformation, or aneurysm

* Bleeding diathesis

* Severe uncontrolled hypertension

Pearl PM0603: Plasminogen activators (classification of fibrinolytics)

Fibrin non-specific plasminogen activators

* Streptokinase - least fibrin specific and has the lowest incidence of intracranial hemorrhage

* Anistreplase

* Urokinase

Fibrin specific plasminogen activators

* Alteplase - has the shortest half-life

* Tenecteplase - most fibrin specific and given as a single bolus dose

* Reteplase

questions.text: 133. Laparoscopic examination of a female patient with chronic pelvic inflammatory disease showed the uterus and appendages densely adherent to each other forming a fixed hard mass along with pelvic cellulitis. The best term to describe this is _______
questions.solution:
The given description best defines Frozen pelvis, which is seen in chronic PID.

Chronic PID:

The previous history of pelvic infection indicates the diagnosis of chronic PID. Symptoms can include low backache, abdominal pain, deep dyspareunia, rectal irritation, congestive dysmenorrhea, etc. Sometimes, infertility is due to blockage of the fallopian tubes. When the uterus and appendages are densely adherent to each other, forming a fixed mass along with pelvic cellulitis, it can be termed as the Frozen pelvis.

Other options:

Option B: Asherman syndrome is due to adhesions formed inside the uterine cavity secondary to Dilation and Curettage procedures.

Option C: Tubo-ovarian mass is seen in stage 3 of pelvic inflammatory disease, where there is a unilateral mass formed involving the fallopian tube and ovary.

Option D: Endometriosis is a disorder where endometrial tissue is found outside the uterine cavity.

questions.text:
134. A 50-year-old patient presents with extreme fatigue and syncope. On examination, his heart rate was 40 beats/min. The resident ordered an ECG, which is shown below. Interpreting the given ECG, what would be the treatment of choice?

ECG- electrocardiogram
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of symptomatic bradycardia with an electrocardiogram showing no relationship between QRS complexes and P waves suggests the diagnosis of complete heart block, for which a permanent pacemaker is the treatment of choice. 

Complete heart block (CHB) presents with clinical features directly related to bradycardia, such as syncope and fatigue, worsening of heart failure, and angina. An electrocardiogram (ECG) shows no relationship between QRS complexes and P waves, and P waves are more numerous than QRS complexes, indicating complete AV dissociation. Permanent pacing is the treatment of choice in CHB

A permanent pacemaker is indicated in:

* Third-degree heart block (complete heart block)

* Acquired Mobitz type II

* Symptomatic bradycardia

Symptomatic bradycardia includes symptoms directly related to bradycardia, such as syncope and fatigue, worsening of heart failure, angina, or intolerance to essential medications.

Other options: 

Option A: An implantable cardioverter defibrillator(ICD) is indicated in patients with ventricular arrhythmias, not in heart block.  ICD detects sustained ventricular tachycardia, based on heart rate, and then terminates the arrhythmia. 

Option C: Adenosine is an antiarrhythmic drug used for the treatment of supraventricular arrhythmias as an intravenous bolus dose.  It acts by activating the acetylcholine-sensitive potassium current in atrium, sinus, and AV nodes, resulting in shortening of action potential duration. 

Option D: Amiodarone is also an antiarrhythmic that acts by inhibiting the sodium and potassium channels mainly and is administered intravenously for life-threatening arrhythmias. It is contraindicated in second and third-degree heart block.

Pearl PM1204: Types of Heart block



Pearl PM2440: ECG patterns of various ventricular arrhythmias

Ventricular tachycardia



 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia associated with QTc prolongation- Torsades de pointes



 

Ventricular flutter



 

Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: 135. A known patient of Meniere’s disease experienced a sudden drop attack without loss of consciousness. There is no vertigo or fluctuations in the hearing loss. What is the given condition?
questions.solution:
The given condition is Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis.

It occurs in patients with Meniere’s disease, where the patient develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness. It is an uncommon manifestation. It is due to the change in the endolymphatic pressure leading to the deformation of the otolithic membrane of the utricle or saccule.

Meniere's disease (endolymphatic hydrops) is an inner ear disorder where the endolymph distends the endolymphatic system. It usually affects males between the ages of 35 to 60. Clinical features include episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. It is generally a unilateral condition. The symptoms appear in clusters with remission periods lasting from weeks to years. Nystagmus may also be seen during acute attacks.

Other Options:

Option A: Tullio phenomenon is a condition seen with some cases of Meniere's disease, where loud sounds or noise produce vertigo. This phenomenon is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

Option C: Lermoyez syndrome, here symptoms of Meniere's disease are seen in reverse order. Initially, there is a progressive deterioration of hearing, followed by an attack of vertigo.

Option D: In Vestibular Hydrops, the patient gets typical attacks of episodic vertigo while cochlear functions remain normal.

questions.text: 136. A P2L2 woman underwent a difficult vaginal delivery with forceps. On examination, there was a perineal tear involving the skin, perineal muscles, and approximately 70% of the external anal sphincter. The internal anal sphincter and anal epithelium were intact. Identify the type of perineal tear.
questions.solution:
The given case scenario aligns with a third-degree (grade 3b) perineal tear.

Perineal tears are classified based on the extent of injury during vaginal delivery and have been divided into four degrees:

* First-degree: Injury to the skin of the perineum and/or the vaginal mucosa.

* Second-degree: Injury to the perineum and perineal muscles without the involvement of the anal sphincter (option A).

* Third-degree: Injury to the perineum and the anal sphincter complex. It is further classified as:

* Grade 3a: Less than 50% of the external anal sphincter (EAS) thickness is torn.

* Grade 3b: More than 50% of the EAS thickness is torn (option C).

* Grade 3c: Both the EAS and internal anal sphincter (IAS) are torn (option B).

* Fourth-degree: Injury to the perineum, the anal sphincter complex (EAS and IAS), and the anorectal mucosa (option D).

In case of a complete tear, the rectal and anal mucosa are sutured first with 3-0 Vicryl using interrupted stitches. The external anal sphincter is then reconstructed using an end-to-end or overlapping technique with PDS or polyglactin, followed by the internal anal sphincter, which is repaired end-to-end with 3-0 PDS or 2-0 Vicryl.

Perineal muscles are sutured with 0 PDS or polyglactin, and vaginal wall and skin are closed with Vicryl Rapide. A recent perineal tear should be repaired immediately after placental delivery to reduce blood loss and infection risk.

If more than 24 hours have passed, repair should be delayed, and antibiotics should be started. Definitive repair of a complete tear is then done after 3 months.

Pearl PM1823: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: 137. Which of the following statements is true regarding cefepime?

choices.text: It is less stable against plasmid mediated beta-lactamase
It possesses anti-pseudomonal action comparable to that of ceftazidime
It has gram-negative activity similar to that of ceftriaxone
Its dose need not be reduced in renal pathology

questions.solution:
Cefepime possesses anti-pseudomonal action comparable to that of ceftazidime. 

Cefepime, a fourth-generation cephalosporin, is more stable against plasmid-mediated beta-lactamase. It is relatively resistant to AmpC chromosomally encoded beta-lactamases. Thus, they are active against many organisms, such as Enterobacter and Pseudomonas, that are resistant to other cephalosporins via overexpression of chromosomally encoded AmpC beta-lactamases.

It possesses anti-pseudomonal activity comparable to that of ceftazidime and gram-positive activity similar to that of ceftriaxone. Other mechanisms, such as active reflux in Pseudomonas, may still confer cefepime resistance. 

All cephalosporins, except cefoperazone and ceftriaxone, are eliminated primarily by the kidneys; thus, dose adjustment is required in renal insufficiency. Cefepime has a short t1/2 (2 hours) and needs to be given 8 hourly.

questions.text: 138. A patient with right lower quadrant pain and fever was diagnosed with acute appendicitis. On physical examination, the patient winces with pain on flexion of the hip against resistance. Which muscle is implicated in eliciting this sign?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of acute appendicitis highlights the iliopsoas sign, which affects the iliopsoas muscle.

The iliopsoas sign is elicited in a supine position by testing the iliacus and psoas major muscles (iliopsoas) against resistance during hip flexion, which produces pain. This sign indicates the presence of an inflammatory retrocecal appendix. It can also be performed by hyperextension of the right hip which causes pain in retrocecal appendix.

Physical examination tests in acute appendicitis: 

McBurney's tenderness        McBurney's point, located one-third of the way between the anterior superior iliac spine and the umbilicus. 
 Rovsing’s  sign  Right lower quadrant pain after release of pressure on the left lower quadrant. 

Dunphy’s sign 

 

 Pain with coughing (retrocecal appendix)
Obturator sign  Pain with internal rotation of the hip (pelvic appendix)

 Iliopsoas sign 

 

 Pain with flexion of the hip against resistance (retrocecal appendix) or hyperextension of the right hip (retrocecal appendix)


Other options:

Option B: Adductor magnus action is tested clinically along with other adductors as a group by adduction of the thigh against resistance, in the supine position with the knee extended.  

Option C: Obturator externus and other short rotators are tested as a group by lateral rotation of the extended hip and abduction of the flexed hip against resistance. 

Option D: Gluteus maximus is tested clinically by extension of the hip against resistance, in the prone position with the knees held flexed.

questions.text: 139. Which of the following best describes the activities of ford foundation in India?

choices.text: Focused on global child welfare and nutrition programs
Contribution in the establishment of the National Institute of Health Administration and Education, Delhi
Provided specialized support for tuberculosis elimination Programme
Primarily involved in global health policies and disease control

questions.solution:
Contribution in the establishment of the National Institute of Health Administration and Education, Delhi is done by ford foundation in India.

Ford foundation is a US-based private, non-profit philanthropic agency whose contributions include setting up National Institute of Health Administration Education (NIHAE) at Delhi for senior health administrator training. It is well-known for its contribution to community development and extension education in India.

Key contributions in India include:

* Orientation Training Centres for medical and paramedical staff in public health

* Pilot health projects that integrated community health and rural development.

* Research-cum-Action Projects: Developed practical solutions for rural sanitation

* Master plan for Calcutta Water Supply & Drainage

* Establishment of NIHAE (National Institute of Health Administration and Education, Delhi)

* Family Planning & Reproductive Research

Other options:

Option A: UNICEF involved in global child welfare and nutrition programs.

Option C: The primary international organization supporting the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) is the World Health Organization (WHO). WHO provides technical assistance, guidance on policies and strategies, capacity building, and supports monitoring and evaluation aligned with the global End TB Strategy. Other major international partners include The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, United States Agency for International Development (USAID).                                                                               

Option D: WHO focusses on global health policies and disease control.

Pearl PM0148: GOBI–FFF Strategy

This strategy was proposed by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF)

* G – Growth monitoring with growth charts

* O – Oral rehydration therapy for diarrhoea and dehydration

* B – Breastfeeding

* I – Immunization of children

* F – Family planning and birth spacing

* F – Food supplementation

* F ­– Female literacy promotion

questions.text: 140. Which of the following is the engaging diameter in brow presentation?
questions.solution:
The engaging diameter of the fetal skull in brow presentation is mento-vertical diameter (2).



Mento-vertical diameter is the largest diameter of the fetal skull, at 14 cm.

On per vaginal examination, the palpation of frontal sutures, anterior fontanelle, and supraorbital ridges indicate that the fetus is in the brow presentation. However, neither the mouth nor the chin can be palpated on per vaginal examination.

The etiology of brow presentation includes:

* Maternal: Multiparity with pendulous abdomen, lateral obliquity of the uterus, contracted pelvis.

* Fetal: Congenital malformations with the most common being anencephaly, congenital goiter, dolichocephalic head

The brow presentation is unstable and usually converts to a face or occipital presentation. Management is easy in the case of a small fetus and a large maternal pelvis. However, in the case of a large fetus, delivery by cesarean section is usually indicated.

Pearl PM1403: Fetal Skull Dimensions



Note: 

Shortest diameters of fetal skull: Bimastoid - 7.5 cm (doesn't engage) < Bitemporal - 8 cm

Longest diameter of fetal skull: Mentovertical 14 cm > Submentovertical / occipitofrontal - 11.5cm

questions.text: 141. A female patient presented with painful swelling and watering in her left eye for a few weeks. Examination revealed the following finding. Which of the following treatment is not preferred for her condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of painful swelling and watering of eyes along with the image showing a reddish swelling in the lid with edema is suggestive of hordeolum externum or stye. Intralesional injection of triamcinolone is not useful in its management. Injection of triamcinalone into and around the lesion is done for chalazion.

Hordeolum externum or stye is the staphylococcal infection of the Zeis gland or Moll gland. It presents as a collection of pus usually pointing at the base of a single cilium. The entire lid may be edamatous. Treatment is with antibiotics and a warm compress. The abscess may also be drained by pulling out the affected cilia. Incision and drainage may also be done. 

A chalazion is a sterile chronic lipogranulomatous inflammation of the meibomian gland due to retained sebaceous secretion. It is also called a tarsal or meibomian cyst. Complete spontaneous resolution occurs rarely. Oral antibiotics are only required for lesions with significant bacterial infections. Daily hot compression can help in the resolution of early lesions. Treatment includes incision and curettage, which is conventional and effective. Intralesional injection of steroid into and around the lesions give a similar resolution to incision and curettage.

An image of chalazion is shown below.

questions.text: 142. A chronic bedridden patient with spinal cord injury presents with the following finding. What is the minimum external pressure required for this ulcer to form?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and given image point toward the diagnosis of pressure sore or decubitus ulcer. The blood flow stops if external pressure exceeds the capillary occlusive pressure over 30 mmHg leading to tissue anoxia, necrosis, and ulceration.

Pressure sores can be defined as tissue necrosis with ulceration due to prolonged pressure. The common sites are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, heel, malleolus (lateral than medial) and occiput 

The prevention and management includes:

* Good skincare

* Special pressure dispersion cushions or foams

* Use of low air loss and air-fluidized beds and urinary or fecal diversion in selected cases.

* The bed-bound patient should be turned at least every 2 hours, with the wheelchair-bound patient being taught to lift themselves off their seat for 10 seconds every 10 minutes.

* Preoperative management of the pressure sore involves adequate debridement, and the use of vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) may help to provide a suitable wound for surgical closure

* The aim is to fill the dead space and to provide durable sensate skin. Large skin flaps that include muscle are best and, occasionally, an intact sensory innervated area can be included (e.g. extensor fascia lata flap with the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh)

Pearl PM0476: Staging of Pressure Sores

 

Stage

Description
1 Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis
2

Partial thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis
3

Full thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia
4 Full thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon or joint

questions.text: 143. An 8-month-old child presents with loss of motor milestones and an exaggerated startle reflex. On examination, the head is disproportionately large, the fundus shows a cherry red spot, and hepatomegaly is present. Which of the following enzymes are absent in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with loss of motor milestones, exaggerated startle reflex, cherry red spot, and hepatomegaly suggests a diagnosis of Sandhoff disease, which is caused due to the deficiency of both β-hexosaminidase A and β-hexosaminidase B.

Similar signs and symptoms are present in Tay-Sachs disease, but there is no visceral involvement (such as hepatosplenomegaly), unlike in Sandhoff disease, where visceral organs are affected.

The table below shows a comparison between Tay-Sachs disease and Sandhoff disease:

Tay-Sachs disease Sandhoff disease
Mental retardation, blindness, and muscular weakness Muscle weakness, seizures, exaggerated startle response, developmental delay, myoclonus, blindness, macrocephaly, mental retardation, cardiac involvement, mild bony abnormalities, Hepatosplenomegaly
Fundoscopy shows a cherry red spot at the macula Fundoscopy shows a cherry red spot at the macula
Positive for gangliosides Positive for both gangliosides and globosides
β-hexosaminidase A isozyme is deficient Both β-hexosaminidase A and B isozymes are deficient


Other options:

Option C: Gaucher disease is caused by a deficiency of β-glucosidase (glucocerebrosidase). This leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide in cells of the reticuloendothelial system. The affected cells display a characteristic crumpled tissue paper appearance on microscopy. A cherry red spot is not seen in Gaucher disease, helping to differentiate it from Tay-Sachs and Sandhoff disease.

questions.text: 144. The suprascapular nerve is the content of which of the following triangles marked in the neck region?
questions.solution:
The suprascapular nerve (C5, C6) arises from the upper trunk of the brachial plexus. The nerve is a component of the subclavian triangle.

In the given image:

* 1 – Carotid triangle

* 2 – Occipital triangle 

* 3 – Subclavian triangle

* 4 – Muscular triangle

Contents of the subclavian triangle are:

* 3rd part of Subclavian Artery and vein

* Suprascapular artery and vein, transverse cervical artery

* Supraclavicular lymph node

* Trunks of Brachial plexus

* Nerve to Serratus anterior

* Branches from upper trunk – N to Subclavius, Suprascapular nerve





Pearl PM2407: Triangles of the Neck

questions.text: 145. On suddenly dropping an infant’s head in relation to her trunk, you notice the response seen in the image. Which of the following is incorrect regarding different components of this response?

choices.text: Hand opening is present by 28 weeks
Upper limb extension and abduction is present by 32 weeks
Anterior flexion with audible cry appears by 40 weeks

questions.solution:
The given image demonstrates Moro’s Reflex. In Moro's reflex, anterior flexion with an audible cry appears at 37 weeks.

 The different components of Moro's reflex appear as follows:

* Hand opening appears at 28 weeks (Option A).

* Upper Limb extension and abduction appear at 32 weeks (Option B).

* Anterior flexion with audible cry appears at 37 weeks

Moro’s reflex disappears by 5-6 months of age (Option C).

An asymmetrical Moro's reflex is indicative of root plexus injury. Moro’s is considered to be the only unlearned fear in human newborns.

According to Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 10th edition, the tonic neck reflex disappears by 4 months of age. According to Nelson Paediatrics, 22nd edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 6 months of age. Hence, the answer depends on the reference chosen by the examiner.

questions.text: 146. Which among the following is not a premalignant condition for oral carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Oral hemangioma is not a pre-malignant condition for oral carcinoma. Oral hemangioma is a benign vascular lesion of the oral cavity that has no known risk of malignant transformation.

Oral cancers can arise from premalignant (potentially malignant) lesions, which are mucosal abnormalities with a risk of malignant transformation. These lesions include leukoplakia, erythroplakia, erythroleukoplakia, proliferative verrucous leukoplakia (PVL), oral submucous fibrosis, oral lichen planus, lupus erythematosus, and rare inherited conditions such as dyskeratosis congenita and epidermolysis bullosa. 

Leukoplakia presents as a white patch or plaque that cannot be scraped off, whereas erythroplakia appears as a bright red, velvety lesion. A speckled leukoplakia, or erythroleukoplakia, combines features of both (as shown in the image below) and carries the highest risk of malignant transformation.



Factors that influence risk include lesion size (>200 mm²), non-homogeneous appearance, location (lateral tongue or floor of mouth), presence of multiple lesions, sex, and exposure to known carcinogens like tobacco, alcohol, and areca nut. Such lesions should be biopsied to confirm the diagnosis and to evaluate the severity of dysplasia or to identify any malignant changes.

Other options: 

Option A: Erythroplakia is a bright red, velvety plaque that cannot be classified as any other condition. It carries a high risk of malignant transformation.

Option B: Oral submucous fibrosis is a chronic fibrotic condition of the oral mucosa, strongly associated with increased risk of oral carcinoma.

Option C: Oral lichen planus is also considered potentially malignant, though the overall risk is lower than erythroplakia or PVL.  The following image shows oral lichen planus:

questions.text: 147. A pure motor type of hemiparesis involving the marked area of the brain is due to infarction of which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the posterior limb of the internal capsule, infarction of which causes pure motor hemiparesis due to the lateral striate arteries.

The lateral striate arteries/lenticulostriate/Charcot's are small central branches of the middle cerebral artery, crucial in the internal capsule as they supply the anterior limb, genu, and a significant portion of the posterior limb. Occlusion of these vessels can cause ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes.

A pure motor type of hemiparesis is of the face, arm, and leg, often due to a lesion in the posterior limb of the internal capsule, cerebral peduncle of the brain, or pons. The internal capsule receives its blood supply from the lateral and medial striate arteries, which originate from the middle and anterior cerebral arteries, respectively.

Additionally, the anterior choroidal artery contributes to the blood supply of the ventral part of the posterior limb and the retrolenticular part of the internal capsule.



Other options: 

Option B & C: The medial striate artery, which branches mainly from anterior cerebral arteries, supplies the anterior limb and genu of the internal capsule as well as the basal ganglia, but not the posterior limb of the internal capsule. 

Option D: The superior cerebellar artery arises from the basilar artery and supplies the pons, pineal body, superior medullary velum, and tela choroidea of the third ventricle.

questions.text: 148. The collagen defective in Alport syndrome is
questions.solution:
In Alport syndrome, there is a defect in Type IV collagen due to mutations in several genes encoding type IV collagen fibres.

Type IV collagen is an important component in the basement membranes of renal glomeruli, inner ear, and eye. Hence, the main presenting feature of Alport’s syndrome is hematuria, accompanied by ocular lesions and hearing loss. Patients may eventually develop end-stage renal disease.

Electron microscopy reveals characteristic abnormalities of the structure of the basement membrane and lamina densa, giving a basket-weave appearance.

questions.text: 149. A 45-year-old man presented with a widespread rash. It started on the chest and spread out over his body. On examination, there are multiple purpuric macules affecting the face and torso. Nikolsky's sign is positive. There is also the involvement of his mouth and eyes. The body surface area affected is 10%. He was recently started on allopurinol for gout. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). 

SJS is a drug-induced condition characterized by widespread epithelial keratinocyte necrosis of both skin and mucous membranes. It is due to cytotoxic T-lymphocytes. SJS with extensive involvement of skin (more than 30% of body surface area) is considered toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN).

The most common drugs involved in SJS/TEN are allopurinol, carbamazepine, lamotrigine, nevirapine, oxicam nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, phenobarbital, phenytoin, sulfamethoxazole, and sulfasalazine. 

Patients usually present 7-10 days after consuming the drug with malaise and fever. It then progresses to a skin rash starting on the face and chest which then spreads over the rest of the body. There are purpuric macules that can easily be desquamated. Positive Nikolsky's sign may be present (gentle lateral pressure causing sliding of the epidermis).

Eyes, oral mucosa, and genitals are frequently involved. 

SJS/TEN is classified based on severity and involvement of body surface area (BSA)

SJS Epidermal detachment of less than 10% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
SJS/TEN overlap Epidermal detachment of 10-30% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
TEN with spots Epidermal detachment of >30% BSA with widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets
TEN without spots Epidermal detachment of >30% BSA with loss of large epidermal sheets without widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets


Complications of SJS/TEN involve loss of thermoregulatory control, severe dehydration, and septicemia. Dehydration can cause acute kidney injury due to hypoperfusion. 

The first step in management is to identify and stop the offending drug. Those with extensive loss of epidermis should be admitted to the burns unit for skin-directed therapy, fluid replacement, and nutrition. The skin should be carefully handled to avoid further removal of skin. In addition, local therapy should be provided for the eyes, mouth, and urogenital tract. Patients should be given analgesia and be monitored for infection. Immunomodulating drugs like corticosteroids and cyclosporin may be used.  

The following image shows Nikolsky's sign, where the application of gentle lateral pressure causes sliding of the epidermis.



The following image shows the involvement of the oral mucosa and large areas of loss of skin.



Other options: 

Option B - TEN is not the answer as the BSA involvement is only 10%. 

Option C - Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune blistering disease that mainly affects older people. It is characterized by pruritus with widespread tense blisters. It doesn't occur after consumption of allopurinol. There is not much mucosal involvement. The following image shows bullous pemphigoid with unruptured, multiple tense blisters.



Option D - Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic autoimmune blistering disease due to antibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins. Patients usually present with oral lesions which are the predominant feature. There are flaccid blisters which rupture. The following image shows the multiple ruptured and flaccid blisters.

Histo-pathology Interface dermatitis – Basal cell vacuolization, apoptotic bodies and inflammatory cells at Dermo-epidermal junction Dermo-epidermal separation, Intense inflammatory cell infiltrates in dermis, some areas of epidermal detachment  Epidermal necrosis, Dermo-epidermal separation, minimal dermal inflammatory cell infiltrate, large areas of epidermal detachment.
Recurrence Common, related to Herpes infections Uncommon, drug-related Uncommon, drug-related
Mortality Rare – recovery in 1 to 4 weeks Elevated mortality Highest mortality


 

Note: Overlap SJS-TEN: There is detachment of 10–30% body surface area, plus widespread purpuric macules or flat atypical targets.

Erythema Multiforme is regarded as a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity most commonly to infection or drugs.

questions.text: 150. A 50-year-old female came to the surgical outpatient department with a swelling in the neck. On clinical examination, it was determined to be a thyroid swelling with a suspected extension into retrosternum. What is the imaging modality of choice to determine the extension of swelling in deciding management?
questions.solution:
The imaging modality of choice to determine the retrosternal extension of thyroid swelling in deciding management is a CT scan.

Retrosternal extension of a thyroid swelling requires more advanced techniques to determine the extent adequately prior to considering management. A CT scan is preferred. Rapid acquisition times minimise artefacts secondary to breathing, and the lung fields can be accurately assessed simultaneously.

Other options:

Option B: Chest radiograph can be used to predict the retrosternal extension of thyroid, but it is not the imaging modality of choice.

Option C: MRI is not used to determine the extension of thyroid swelling. In invasive primary thyroid cancer, MRI is superior at determining the presence of prevertebral fascia invasion. 

Option D: Ultrasonography is used to determine the type of thyroid swelling, visualisation of neck lymph nodes and extension to the soft tissue, but its use is limited in determining extension to the retrosternum.

questions.text: 151. You are a biochemist working on various cytogenetic abnormality. You use the following cytogenetic technique to study the abnormality from a tissue specimen. Which of the following cytogenetic abnormality cannot be picked up by this technique?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an array-based comparative genomic hybridization (CGH). This cytogenetic technique cannot detect balanced translocation.

In array CGH, two genomes are compared. The test DNA and the reference DNA are labeled with two different fluorescent dyes (red and green respectively) and are added to a DNA chip spotted with the entire human genome.

* If the contribution of both samples is equal for a given chromosomal region, then all spots on the array will fluoresce yellow.

* If the test sample has amplification, that spot will fluoresce red.

* If the test sample has a deletion, that spot will fluoresce green.

Uses of Array CGH:

* To detect gene amplification

* To detect gene deletion 

* To detect copy number variations

Limitations:

Cannot detect balanced translocations. Reason being as follows:

If there is less DNA in the patient than the control for a particular probe, the a-CGH will show a deletion of material from the patient for that particular locus; if there is more DNA in the patient than the control for a particular probe, the a-CGH will show a gain of material from the patient for that locus. In a balanced translocation, there is no gain or loss of material, so the probes will show that the patient and the control have equal amounts of DNA in those translocated regions.

Other methods for molecular analysis of genetic alterations include:

* Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH)

* Southern blotting

* SNP - single nucleotide polymorphisms genotyping arrays

* Multiple ligation dependant probe assays (MLPA)

Comparison of different cytogenetic techniques:

Method Required growing of cells Detects deletions and duplications Detects balanced structural re-arrangements Detects uniparental disomy Lower limits of deletions
G Banding YES YES YES NO 5-10 mb
Metaphase FISH YES YES YES NO 40-250 thousand mb
Interphase FISH NO YES SOME NO 40-250 thousand mb
CGH Array NO YES NO NO single exon or single gene
SNP array NO YES NO SOME single exon or single gene


Pearl PM1019: Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH)



It is a simple technique for the detection of specific genetic information on a morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes.

The fluorescent probes are added to cells usually arrested in the metaphase stage of cell division (when every chromosome is separately).

Types of FISH:

1) Chromosomal painting: Each chromosome is identified by using a different colour of the fluorescent probe, however, each chromosome does not have a unique colour. Since the fluorescent dyes are limited.

2) Multicolour FISH: 23 distinct fluorescent colours made by mixing 5 fluorophores. Thus each chromosome is identified by a unique colour. It is also known as spectral karyotyping (SKY). It offers various advantages such as

* Detects structural and numeric abnormalities in chromosomes.

* Detects gene amplification and subtle microdeletions

* Maps a newly isolated gene to its correct chromosomal loci

However, this process requires prior knowledge of the genes and chromosomes.

3) Interphase FISH: It is a rapid procedure of FISH, wherein growing cells are not needed. It is used in prenatal diagnosis and in tumour diagnosis.

The image shown is of a Multicolor FISH also known as Spectral karyotyping with a unique colour to each chromosome pair.

questions.text: 152. A 50-year-old male with a history of hemoptysis presented with lower limb edema and urine output 400ml/24hr. His laboratory investigations show elevated CRP, ESR with progressively increasing serum creatinine levels , along with pANCA positivity. A renal biopsy indicated non-granulomatous inflammation. What is the first-line treatment for the severe form of this disease during the induction phase?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette suggestive of respiratory and renal involvement with pANCA positivity and biopsy findings of non-granulomatous inflammation of the glomerulus, suggests the diagnosis of microscopic polyangiitis. An increasing serum creatinine level suggests progression to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). In severe forms, the first-line treatment during the induction phase includes cyclophosphamide combined with high-dose glucocorticoids.

Microscopic polyangiitis is a pANCA-positive small-to-medium-vessel vasculitis, more common in males. Symptoms include fever, weight loss, musculoskeletal pain, and rapid renal failure. Patients may experience hemoptysis from alveolar haemorrhage, often without upper airway involvement and pulmonary nodules. Renal biopsy typically shows non-granulomatous vasculitis. 

Management is divided into induction and maintenance phases. In the induction phase, acute severe disease or organ/life-threatening, is treated with cyclophosphamide and high-dose glucocorticoids to effectively induce remission and prolong survival. Rituximab with high-dose glucocorticoids can also be used during induction phase of severe disease.

For non-severe disease or non-organ/life-threatening, induction phase can be tried with Methotrexate, Azathioprine, or Mycophenolate mofetil along with glucocorticoids due to higher toxicity of cyclophosphamide (Option A, B and C). 

In maintenance phase, lower doses of glucocorticoids and Methotrexate, Azathioprine, or Mycophenolate mofetil are used. Mycophenolate mofetil has higher replase rate than Azathioprine

Pearl PM0442: Microscopic polyangiitis v/s granulomatosis with polyangiitis

Both microscopic polyangiitis and granulomatosis with polyangiitis are small vessel vasculitides that are mainly caused due to antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). Therefore, they share common clinical features with some differences.

Features Microscopic polyangiitis Granulomatosis with polyangiitis

Kidney

Upper airway involvement

More common

(Sinusitis, otitis media, hearing loss, septal perforation)
Nodular cavities in the lungs Absent Present
ANCA pANCA (mainly) cANCA(mainly)
Granuloma Absent Present
Necrosis Present Present
Kidney Glomerulonephritis Glomerulonephritis


Pearl PM0952: Classification of vasculitis - Modified Chapel Hill classification



Pearl PM0951: ANCA Antibodies

The antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are the antibodies that are targeted against the specific proteins present in neutrophils and monocytes. They can be further classified as:

questions.text: 153. Abnormally high HbA1c levels may be observed in normal newborns when analyzed using chromatography due to:

choices.text: Presence of HbF in the blood

questions.solution:
Newborns may have abnormally high HbA1c levels when analysed with chromatography due to the presence of HbF in the blood.

In chromatography, the positively charged normal haemoglobins attach to the negatively charged resins. However, HbA1c, where the charge is masked by glucose, elutes from the column without binding. HbF also behaves similarly to HbA1c in the separating column. As a result, abnormally high values may be seen even in normal children, as well as in persons with thalassemia.

Other options

Option B: Normal newborns are less likely to have elevated blood glucose levels that could lead to abnormally high HbA1c readings.

Option C: Newborns have a reduced RBC lifespan (60–80 days). 

Option D: High red blood cell turnover, as seen in cases of hemolytic anaemia, is associated with falsely low levels of HbA1c.

questions.text: 154. The goal of IV thrombolysis and revascularisation in acute ischemic stroke is to:

choices.text: Prevent rupture of cerebral vessels when BP >185/100mmHg
Improve cerebral perfusion in ischemic penumbra

questions.solution:
The goal of IV thrombolysis and revascularisation is to improve cerebral perfusion in the ischemic penumbra. 

The ischemic penumbra, an area of the brain surrounding a core infarction, is salvageable. Since it eventually progresses to an infarction, the immediate goal in ischemic stroke treatment is to save this penumbral tissue through revascularization therapies, thereby optimizing cerebral perfusion.

Note: IV thrombolysis by rtPA, tenecteplase, and endovascular mechanical thrombectomy are ways of revascularization.  

Other Options:

Option A: Identifying the site of occlusion is a part of an investigation done through CT angiography in which bolus IV contrast demonstrates deficits in brain perfusion, produced by vascular occlusion. 

Option B: A blood pressure exceeding 185/100 mmHg is a contraindication for thrombolysis, not a goal. 

Option D: Decreasing cerebral edema is not done through revascularisation therapies, but IV mannitol and water restriction are treatment modalities for managing cerebral edema in ischemic stroke.

Pearl PM1788: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

* Clinical diagnosis of stroke

* Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours

* Age ≥ 18 years

* CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

* Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment

* Bleeding diathesis

* Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage

* Major surgery in preceding 14 days

* Minor stroke symptoms

* Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days

* Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text:
155. A PHC Medical Officer observes high rates of iron deficiency anemia among adolescent girls in a village. To address this, she initiates a programme where:

* The agriculture department helps local families start kitchen gardens to grow iron-rich vegetables.

* Teachers in the village school conduct weekly nutrition education sessions.

* PHCs ensure regular supply and distribution of Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) supplements and deworming tablets (Albendazole) to Accredited Social Health Activists (ASHAs) and Anganwadi Centres

The above best demonstrates which principle of Primary Health Care?
questions.solution:
This is intersectoral coordination, one of the four pillars of Primary Health Care under Alma-Ata. It means collaboration between different sectors , in this case:

* Agriculture: kitchen gardens (food production)

* Education: teachers conduct nutrition sessions

* Health department : supply and distribution of Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) supplements and deworming tablets (Albendazole) 

The 4 pillars of primary Health Care under Alma-Ata are - Equitable distribution, Appropriate technology, Community participation, and Intersectoral coordination

Other options:

Option A: Equitable distribution: This ensures all groups have fair access to services and not collaboration between different sectors  .

Option B: Appropriate technology: This means using simple, low-cost solutions like ORS, MUAC tape .

Option C: Community participation: It is a vital process where individuals and communities actively engage in identifying health needs, making decisions, and implementing actions to improve health outcomes.

Pearl PM0153: Elements and Principles of Primary Health Care

A. Elements of Primary Health Care

(Mnemonic: ELEMENTS)

* Education about health problems and their prevention and control

* Locally endemic diseases – prevention and control

* Essential drugs

* Maternal and child health care

* Expanded programme of immunization against vaccine preventable diseases

* Nutrition and proper food supply

* Treatment of common diseases and injuries

* Safe water and sanitation

B. Principles/Pillars of Primary Health Care

* Equitable distribution

* Community participation

* Intersectoral coordination

* Appropriate technology

questions.text: 156. A female patient with bilateral hilar adenopathy on chest X-ray shows the following findings on histology. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette, along with the histopathological specimen showing giant cells with concentric concretions (Schaumann bodies), suggests a diagnosis of sarcoidosis. 

Sarcoidosis is a systemic granulomatous disease that most commonly presents as cough, dyspnea, dry eyes, and usually has bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. Lesions of the eyes and skin are also very common in these patients. It is seen more in middle-aged women than in men.

Sarcoidosis results from an increase in CD4+ T-cells (increased CD4+:CD8+ ratio). As a result, cytokines like IL-2, TNF, IL-8, and IFN-gamma will increase. These cytokines are the cause of granuloma formation in this disorder.

It presents with granulomas in multiple organs. They are classically described as non-caseating granulomas composed of epithelioid macrophages with giant cells. There is no central necrosis as there would be in tubercular granulomas. Naked granulomas are non-caseating granulomas minimally surrounded by lymphocytes.

Laminated calcium and protein-containing bodies called Schaumann bodies and star-shaped inclusions called asteroid bodies (stellate concretions) are also found in the giant cells of most of these granulomas. These are not pathognomonic to sarcoidosis.





Other options: 

Option A: Tuberculosis on histology shows Ghon complex, which is a combination of parenchymal and nodal lesions along with caseous necrosis at the centre. 

Option C: Histoplasmosis on histology shows small to oval yeast forms with necrotic granulomas.  

Option D: Asbestosis is marked by diffuse interstitial pulmonary fibrosis characterised by the presence of asbestos bodies and ferruginous bodies.

Giant cell arteritis

questions.text: 157. Which of the following triads is classically associated with chronic elemental mercury poisoning?

choices.text: Gingivostomatitis, intentional tremors, and behavioural changes
Bluish gum line, anemia, and abdominal colic

questions.solution:
Chronic mercury poisoning presents with a classic triad of gingivostomatitis, intentional tremors, and behavioural changes.

Mercury is a liquid metal and a metallic irritant available in elemental, inorganic, and organic forms. Chronic poisoning can occur from long-term occupational exposure, repeated medicinal use, recovery from a high dose, or prolonged application of mercury-containing ointments.

Chronic exposure to elemental mercury can present with a classic triad showing:

* Gingivostomatitis: Characterized by inflamed gums often accompanied by ptyalism (excessive salivation).

* Intentional tremors: Fine tremors initially, which progressively become coarse and disabling, also known as Danbury tremors.

* Behavioral changes: Includes shyness, memory loss, emotional instability, and irritability, collectively referred to as mercurial erethism.

Exposure to inorganic mercury salts, such as mercuric chloride, primarily leads to gastrointestinal corrosion and nephrotoxicity, whereas organic mercury compounds, like methylmercury, predominantly affect the central nervous system, classically causing Minamata disease, which presents with ataxia, visual disturbances, tremors, rigidity, dysarthria, and impaired consciousness.

Other options:

Option A: Ataxia, visual blurring, and rigidity are seen in organic mercury poisoning, especially methylmercury (Minamata disease).

Option C: Excessive salivation, diarrhea, and hallucinations are mixed signs of acute toxicity; they lack the specificity of the chronic triad.

Option D: Bluish gum line, anemia, and abdominal colic are classic signs of lead poisoning, not mercury.

Pearl PM2100: Mercury Poisoning

Mercury

Industries (inorganic mercury)

Fish (organic mercury) 
Route of absorption

Elemental - Respiratory tract (negligible through GI unless the mucosa is damaged) 

Inorganic - GI tract

Organic - GI tract
Mechanism of action

binds to sulhydryl groups of enzymes and affects

  • glutathione metabolism
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

Respiratory tract (elemental mercury)

GI tract (inorganic mercury)

Respiratory + GI tract (organic mercury)
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Renal (elemental mercury)

Renal (inorganic mercury)

CNS (organic mercury)
Characteristic clinical findings

 

Mnemonic: MEATS

M -

  • Mercuria lentis
  • Membranous colitis 
  • Minimata disease
  • Membranous glomerulopathy

E-Erethism (personality disturbance, insomnia, and loss of memory)

A-Acrodynia (Pink disease)

T-Tremors (Coarse tremors) - Include Danbury tremors, hatter’s or Glass blower’s shakes

S-Salivation (excessive salivation)
Diagnosis Blood and/or 24 hour urine mercury level
Treatment BAL; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text:
158. During a surprise inspection at a district hospital, the biomedical waste audit team finds the following. Which of these practices are correct according to the Biomedical Waste Management Rules?

* Used glass vials of BCG vaccine are stored in the blue box.

* Cotton swabs soaked with OPV drops are placed in the yellow bag.

* Used IV tubing with residual blood in the red bag.

* Expired and damaged drug vials/ampoules of cyclophosphamide are disposed of in the blue box.
questions.solution:
The correct statements are 1 and 2.

Statement 1: Used glass vials of BCG vaccine are considered non-infectious recyclable glass. They should be collected in the blue container, which is meant for discarded glassware, including medicine vials and ampoules (except cytotoxic or chemically contaminated glass).

Statement 2: Cotton swabs soaked with OPV drops become soiled waste due to contact with biological fluids. Such waste must be collected in a yellow bag.

Other statements:

Statement 3: IV tubing with residual blood is soiled waste, which must go in the yellow bag, not red. The Red bag is only for recyclable, contaminated plastic that is not soiled with blood or body fluids.

Statement 4: Expired and damaged cyclophosphamide drug vials/ampoules are hazardous chemical waste. These should be collected in a yellow container or bag with a cytotoxic hazard symbol. The blue box is only for non-hazardous glass.

questions.text: 159. A 2-year-old boy with a congenital heart disease presents with cyanosis and breathlessness during exertion. He assumes a knee-chest position but gets little relief. The cardiologist administers phenylephrine. What is the rationale behind its use in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of a paroxysmal hypercyanotic attack/cyanotic spell. Phenylephrine administration causes a reduction of the right-to-left shunt.

Phenylephrine is an α-agonist that increases the systemic vascular resistance. Administration of phenylephrine increases afterload for the heart and, in turn, reduces the flow from the right ventricle to the left ventricle (right-to-left shunt). This reduces the amount of deoxygenated blood in the systemic circulation and thereby reduces the cyanosis.

Paroxysmal hypercyanotic spells, also referred to as tet spells/ bluespells/ hypoxic spells, are episodes marked by the infant or child becoming hyperpneic and restless, with increased cyanosis, gasping respirations, and possible syncope. Though commonly associated with tetralogy of Fallot, they can also occur in other forms of pulmonary stenosis with a ventricular septal defect. Precipitating factors include crying, defecation, feeding, wakening from sleep, dehydration, fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and events provoking agitation.

They are characterized by:

* Period of uncontrolled crying/ panic/ irritability

* Rapid and deep breathing

* Increased cyanosis

* Limpness and lethargy

* Reduced murmur intensity (signifying substantial blood flow reduction across the right ventricular outflow tract)

Management options for this child include the following:

* Calm the child and minimize the stimuli

* Place in the knee-chest position (increases venous return to the heart and systemic vascular resistance)

* Administer oxygen

* Subcutaneous morphine (not over 0.2mg/kg) to cause sedation and depression of the respiratory centre (option D)

* IV Sodium Bicarbonate to correct the ongoing metabolic acidosis (option C)

* IV Phenylephrine to increase the systemic vascular resistance that reduces the right-to-left shunting (option A)

* IV Propranolol to reduce the pulmonary infundibular spasms in TOF (option B)

If the spell is resistant to all the above-mentioned measures, then intubation and sedation of the child are required to break the spell.

questions.text: 160. A 43-year-old lady comes to the OPD with complaints of fever, abdominal pain and itching over her arms and legs. On examination, there is presence of icterus and mild hepatomegaly. Liver function test shows deranged values. A liver biopsy shows the following findings. The patient also tests positive for anti-nuclear antibodies and an elevated level of serum IgG. Which of the following features is not present in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features along with a positive ANA test and increased serum IgG levels with histopathology showing interface hepatitis, a cluster of plasma cells and lymphocytes at the interface between the portal tract and liver lobule, indicates Autoimmune hepatitis(AIH). All the features are found in AIH except “ground glass” hepatocytes which are characteristically found in Hepatitis B and is a diagnostic hallmark.

Autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) is characterised by extensive inflammation, fibrosis and ultimately cirrhosis. The pathologic features include:

* Emperipolesis - Lymphocytes and plasma cells within the cytoplasm of hepatocytes.

* Interface hepatitis or piecemeal necrosis.

* Rosette formation due to necrosis of groups of hepatocytes and resultant regeneration.

Bile duct injury and granulomas are uncommon except in case of overlap with primary biliary cirrhosis.

Based on the types of autoantibodies present, autoimmune hepatitis is subclassified as types 1 and 2 :

* Type 1 disease (more common overall) -

* Antinuclear antibodies (ANAs) 

* Anti–smooth muscle actin (SMA) antibodies

* Antibodies against soluble liver antigen/liver-pancreas antigen (SLA/LPA)

* Less commonly, anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA, more typical of primary biliary cholangitis) also may be seen. 

* Type 2 disease (more common in children) - 

* Anti liver-kidney-microsome-1 (LKM-1) antibodies, which are directed against CYP2D6

* Anti–liver cytosol-1 (ACL-1) antibodies.

The simplified scoring system for the diagnosis of autoimmune hepatitis includes four variables. They are:

* Autoantibodies

* Elevated serum IgG level

* Typical compatible histologic features

* Absence of viral hepatitis markers

A small number of drugs such as minocycline, nitrofurantoin, and α-methyldopa can trigger the formation of autoantibodies and hepatocellular injury that mimics autoimmune hepatitis.

The different patterns of liver injury:



Pearl PM2264: Types of autoimmune hepatitis (AIH)

  Type I AIH Type II AlH
Characteristic antibodies Anti-SMA (F-actin), ANA, pANCA, anti-SLA/LP, anti-AMA antibodies Anti-LKM1, anti-liver cytosol 1
Age of onset Bimodal, peaks at 10–20 years and 45–70 years 2–14 years
Gender distribution 78% female 89% female
lgG increase Pronounced Moderate
lgA decrease Absent Occasional
Association with HLA haplotypes B8, DR3, DR4 B14, DR3


Type III autoimmune hepatitis does not appear to represent a distinct category but, instead, is part of the spectrum of type I autoimmune hepatitis

* ANA: Anti-nuclear antibodies

* anti-SMA: Anti–smooth muscle actin antibodies

* anti-SLA/LP: Anti–soluble liver antigen/liver–pancreas antigen

* AMA: Anti-mitochondrial antibodies

* anti-LKM: Liver–kidney microsomal antibodies

* pANCA: Perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies

questions.text: 161. A 7-year-old boy is scheduled for surgery. Before inserting an IV cannula, the anesthesiologist applied a eutectic mixture of local anaesthetic to provide skin analgesia. Identify the local anaesthetic mixture that was used.
questions.solution:
The local anaesthetic mixture that was used was 2.5% Lidocaine + 2.5% Prilocaine.

EMLA is a eutectic mixture of 2.5% lidocaine base and 2.5% prilocaine base. This preparation is applied under an occlusive bandage for 45 to 60 minutes to obtain effective cutaneous anaesthesia. Longer application times increase the depth and reliability of skin analgesia. An eutectic mixture has a melting point lower than the individual drugs, and hence the mixture is in the oil form at room temperature.

Methemoglobinemia occurs with large doses of prilocaine, upwards of 600mg. EMLA is a topical mixture containing prilocaine, and in term neonates, minimal amounts of methemoglobin are produced, which can be safely excreted. Thus, it is regarded as safe in the majority of newborns. The risk is increased in neonates with metabolic disorders or in those receiving drugs that can impair the reduction of methemoglobin. Side Effects include blanching of the skin, erythema, and oedema. 

EMLA can provide adequate dermal analgesia for procedures like split skin-graft harvesting, venipuncture, intravenous cannulation in children, laser skin treatments, lithotripsy, and circumcision. EMLA cream should not be used on mucous membranes,  infants younger than 1 month of age, or patients with a predisposition to methemoglobinemia.



EMLA is applied 45-60 minutes before the procedure with an occlusive dressing as shown in the above image. It provides analgesia up to a depth of 5 mm, which lasts for 1-2 hours.

Pearl PM0513: High Yield Points in Local Anaesthetics

Cocaine: 

* Naturally occurring

* Vasoconstrictor

* 1st local anesthetic

Chloroprocaine: Intradural injections are contraindicated and may cause paraplegia

Prilocaine: 

* Safest

* Causes maximum methemoglobinemia

* Suitable for Bier’s IV block

* EMLA is a eutectic mixture of LA containing 2.5% lidocaine & 2.5% prilocaine

Bupivacaine

* Long-acting

* Most cardiotoxic

* Contraindicated in regional IV anesthesia

* Toxicity is treated with amiodarone, bretylium(for VT), vasopressors (for circulatory collapse), isoproterenol and benzodiazepines (sedative)

Procaine

* LA of choice in malignant hyperthermia

* 1st synthetic LA

* Metabolized to PABA, which have been associated with rare anaphylactic reactions

questions.text: 162. A 40-year-old man presents with complaints of fever, fatigue, and weight loss for the past 3 months. On examination, he has pallor and bruising on his lower limbs and abdomen. Bone marrow aspirate is shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding this disease?

choices.text: DIC is a dreaded complication of this disease
All-trans retinoic acid is used in treatment
Blast count of 10% is required to establish a diagnosis

questions.solution:
The bone marrow aspirate findings in this patient show myeloblasts containing Auer rods (eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions) are suggestive of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML/ APL) variant of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). A blast count of ≥ 20% is required to make a diagnosis.

The below image shows Auer rods.



The patient presents with fever, fatigue, and weight loss. On examination, findings consistent with anemia (pallor) and thrombocytopenia (easy bruising) are seen. This is due to the accelerated destruction of RBC and platelet precursors in the bone marrow. 

APL is associated with aberrant translocations between chromosomes, one of which is t(15;17). This translocation results in the formation of a fused gene with components of promyelocytic leukemia (PML) from chromosome 15 and retinoic acid receptor alpha (Rar-alpha) from chromosome 17. This fused gene codes for a chimeric protein (PML-Rar-alpha) that blocks promyelocyte differentiation.

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is a complication of APL. Symptoms can range from minimal bleeding to significant hemorrhage (gastrointestinal, intrapulmonary, intracranial). This is thought to be secondary to the Auer rods and primary granules present in promyelocytes. They activate the coagulation cascade and cause consumptive coagulopathy responsible for the bleeding manifestations. 

All-trans-retinoic acid (tretinoin, ATRA) increases the concentrations of the Rar-alpha which in turn relieves this block and facilitates further differentiation. 

The mainstay of treatment includes induction (cytarabine + anthracycline) and post-remission chemotherapy.

questions.text: 163. A 9-month-old infant presents with fever, irritability, vomiting, lethargy, and a bulging fontanelle. The child is not fully vaccinated. CSF analysis reveals pleomorphic, gram-negative coccobacilli. The best culture medium for primary isolation of the causative organism is:
questions.solution:
The best culture medium for primary isolation of the  causative organism is Fildes' Agar. 

The given clinical scenario of an infant presenting with fever, irritability, vomiting, lethargy, and a bulging fontanelle, and whose CSF analysis reveals pleomorphic, gram-negative coccobacilli, is suggestive of meningitis caused by Haemophilus influenzae type b. Fildes' agar is the best culture medium for the primary isolation of H. influenzae. Not being fully vaccinated increases the infant’s susceptibility to Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) infections, including meningitis, which are largely preventable with routine immunization.

H. influenzae is a small, gram-negative, non-motile, non-sporing coccobacillus, exhibiting considerable pleomorphism. The bacillus has fastidious growth requirements. The accessory growth factors, named X and V, present in the blood are essential for growth. It can present clinically as meningitis, laryngoepiglottitis (croup), pneumonia, suppurative lesions, and bronchitis.

The image below shows Haemophilus influenzae appearing as gram-negative coccobacilli:



For isolation, CSF should be plated promptly on any of the following culture media: 

* Chocolate agar: When blood agar is heated to 80-90°C for 15-20 minutes, the V factor is released from within the erythrocytes

* Levinthal's medium: Enriched chocolate agar used for isolating fastidious bacteria like Haemophilus influenzae

* Fildes' agar: Best for the primary isolation of H. influenzae and gives copious growth. The media should be incubated in an environment of 5-10% CO2 and high humidity. After overnight incubation at 37°C, small opaque colonies of gram-negative, short, oxidase-positive coccobacilli appear. 

* Blood agar with Staphylococcus aureus streaked across the plate: H. influenzae exhibits satellitism, growing near S. aureus due to local release of V factor, as shown in the image below:



Other options:

Option A: Deoxycholate citrate agar (DCA) is a selective medium to isolate enteric bacteria such as Salmonella. 

Option B: Thayer-Martin medium, containing vancomycin, colistin, and nystatin in chocolate agar, is selective for Neisseria species, including N. gonorrhoeae and N. meningitidis. CSF isolates of N. meningitidis appear as gram-negative diplococci, not pleomorphic coccobacilli.

Option D: Lowenstein-Jensen medium is used for the primary isolation of Mycobacterium species. It consists of mineral salts, asparagine, glycerol, malachite green, and hen's egg.

questions.text:
164. In Type IV hypersensitivity, interferon-𝜸 activates macrophages by which of the following mechanisms?

* Increase in TNF receptors 

* Stimulating T(DTH) cells 

* Increase expression of MHC-II 

* Increase levels of nitric oxide
questions.solution:
In Type IV hypersensitivity, interferon-𝜸 activates macrophages by increasing TNF receptors, increasing expression of MHC-II, and increasing levels of nitric oxide (Statements 1, 3, and 4).

Type IV hypersensitivity occurs through two phases, sensitization and the effector phase. During the sensitization phase antigen-presenting cells present and process antigens along with MHC-II to T-helper cells, which later differentiate into TDTH cells. In the effector phase, the T(DTH) cells secrete various cytokines on contact with the antigen, such as  IFN-𝜸, which activate macrophages.

Interferon-𝜸(IFN-𝜸) activates macrophages by following mechanisms:

* Increasing TNF receptors (Statement 1)

* Increasing expression of MHC-II (Statement 3)

* Increasing levels of nitric oxide (Statement 4)

Interleukin-2 released during the effector phase recruits macrophages by stimulating the proliferation of T(DTH) cells (statement 2). MCAF (monocyte chemotactic and activating factor), TNF-𝛃, MIF(migration inhibitory factor), IL-3, and GM-CSF(granulocyte-monocyte colony-stimulating factor) are other cytokines released during the effector phase.

* Lepromin test

* Chronic graft rejection

* Contact dermatitis

* Sarcoidosis

* Type I lepra reaction

* Crohn’s disease

questions.text:
165. A 3-year-old female child is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of regressing developmental milestones. Genetic studies show mutations in the MECP2 gene. Choose the correct statements about this patient's progressive neurologic developmental disorder from those below.

* This disorder is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner

* Abnormal respiration with periods of hyperventilation is characteristic

* There will be a progressive increase in head circumference

* Occurs predominantly in females

* Most patients will have a history of perinatal birth trauma
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 4 are correct.

Mutations in the MECP2 gene are associated with Rett's syndrome. This disorder occurs almost exclusively in females, and abnormal respiration with periods of hyperventilation is characteristic. 

Features of Rett Syndrome:

* Apparently normal prenatal and perinatal period, and apparently normal psychomotor development through the first 5 months and normal head circumference at birth

* Deceleration of head growth between 5 months and 4 years and loss of acquired purposeful hand skills between 5 and 30 months of age

* Most cases are caused by mutations in the MECP2, which maps to Xp28 and is inherited in an X-linked dominant

* The typical manifestations include loss of spoken language (communication via eye gaze, body language, and facial expressions), motor dysfunction (stereotypic hand movements and gait disturbance). The stereotypic hand movements include opposition of hands, finger kneading, rubbing, twisting, and pill-rolling. The gait is broad-based, clumsy, and ataxic. These patients also have scoliosis, growth failure with the deceleration of head growth, feeding impairment, epilepsy, cardiac abnormalities, bone mineral deficit, autonomic dysfunction, disorders of respiratory control (episodes of hyperventilation with concomitant hypocapnia alternating with hypoventilation and/or apnea), and sleep disturbance

* The exclusion criteria include brain injury secondary to trauma (perinatal or postnatal), neurometabolic, or severe infection that causes neurologic problems and grossly abnormal psychomotor development in the first six months of life

Under DSM-5, Rett Syndrome is diagnosed as an autism spectrum disorder. World Autism Awareness Day is observed annually on April 2nd to highlight the need to help improve the quality of life of those with autism so they can lead meaningful lives as an integral part of society and also to address stigmatisation and discrimination.

questions.text: 166. A 38-year-old woman presents to you with fatigue & palpitations. She gives a history of 4 spontaneous abortions early during pregnancy & provides a lab report showing very high titers of anti-beta2 glycoprotein1. On cardiac auscultation, you hear a pansystolic murmur. Which of the following vegetations would you most likely find on echocardiography?
questions.solution:
The vegetations depicted in "Image 4" are most likely to be seen in echocardiography.

The h/o repeated, early spontaneous abortions & lab report showing high titers of anti-beta2 glycoprotein1 are strongly suggestive of Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS). With this background, the given presentation of fatigue, palpitations, and finding of the pan-systolic murmur (most likely of MR) should raise a strong suspicion for Libman-Sacks endocarditis. It is characterised by very small vegetations on either or both sides of the valve, as given in "Image 4".

Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoantibody-mediated acquired thrombophilia characterised by recurrent arterial or venous thrombosis and/or pregnancy morbidity. It primarily affects females. APS may occur alone (primary) or in association with other autoimmune diseases, mainly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) (secondary).

Diagnosis:

* The diagnosis of APS should be seriously considered in cases of thrombosis, cerebral vascular accidents in individuals <55 years of age, or pregnancy morbidity in the presence of livedo reticularis or thrombocytopenia.

* The presence of at least one clinical and one laboratory criterion is compatible with the diagnosis, in the absence of other thrombophilia causes.

* Clinical criteria include:

* Vascular thrombosis is defined as one or more clinical episodes of arterial, venous or small vessel thrombosis in any tissue or organ

* Pregnancy morbidity, defined as:

* ≥1 unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond the tenth week of gestation

* ≥1 premature births of a morphologically normal neonate before the thirty-fourth week of gestation because of eclampsia, severe preeclampsia, or placental insufficiency or

* ≥3 unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before the tenth week of gestation

*

Laboratory criteria for APS include high titers of any 1 of the following three antiphospholipid antibodies on two occasions, 12 weeks apart 

* Lupus anticoagulant (LA) - It is measured indirectly by

* Diluted Russell's viper venom time assay (most specific) 

* Kaolin coagulation time(KCT)

* prolongation of aPTT

* Anticardiolipin (aCL) antibody assay (most sensitive)

* Anti-β2GPI (glycoprotein 1) antibodies assay
