questions.text: 167. A 30-year old male patient presents with complaints of frequent, long-standing respiratory tract infections. He is a known case of cystic fibrosis. Which among the given organisms is more commonly implicated in such patients?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common etiological agent associated with chronic airway infection in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF).

Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive exocrinopathy affecting multiple epithelial tissues. In this condition, due to the CFTR protein defect, there is thick inspissated mucus and impaired mucociliary clearance. Due to these factors, P. aeruginosa can cause chronic infection/colonization of the respiratory tract in patients of CF.

A complex bacterial flora that includes Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa is routinely cultured from CF sputum. Infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa is common in adults with CF

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, non-lactose fermenting bacteria that shows swarming motility.

The GIF below shows swarming motility seen in Pseudomonas aeruginosa.



They produce a characteristic blue-green pigment called pyocyanin and a greenish-yellow pigment called fluorescein/pyoverdin. Other pigments produced by these organisms include pyorubin (Red), pyomelanin (Brown).

The image given below shows green coloured colonies of Pseudomonas aeruginosa on a nutrient agar.



Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

* Burns infections

* Opportunistic and nosocomial infections

* Shanghai fever: severe enteric disease and sepsis

* Malignant otitis externa in diabetics

* Jacuzzi syndrome (Hot tub folliculitis)

* Ecthyma gangrenosum

* Green-nail syndrome

Other options:

Option A: Stenotrophomonas maltophila, formerly called Pseudomonas maltophila, is an opportunistic pathogen that causes wound infection, urinary tract infection, and septicemia. It is sensitive to cotrimoxazole.

Option B: Burkholderia pseudomallei, formerly called Pseudomonas pseudomallei, is the causative agent of melioidosis, a disease that can manifest as acute septicemia, pneumonia, hemoptysis resembling tuberculosis, or a chronic form with abscess formation in the skin and subcutaneous tissues, bones, and internal organs.

Option D: Burkholderia cepacia, formerly called Pseudomonas cepacia, is an opportunistic pathogen that causes fatal necrotizing pneumonia.

Stenotrophomonas maltophila, Burkholderia pseudomallei, Burkholderia cepacia infections have also been found to be associated with CF. However, among the given options, Pseudomonas aeruginosa infections are more commonly seen in such patients.

questions.text: 168. A 68-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease presents with shortness of breath at rest, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and leg swelling. On examination, he has bibasilar crackles and elevated jugular venous pressure. Which pattern of breathing is most likely to be observed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests severe heart failure, in which Cheyne-Stokes respiration is observed, depicted in Graph 4.

Heart failure occurs in most chronic cardiac conditions, including hypertension, valvular heart disease, and coronary artery disease/ischemic heart disease. Patients may present with shortness of breath, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (shortness of breath after lying down for 30 minutes or longer), pedal edema, weight gain, early satiety, raised pulsatile jugular venous pressure (JVP), and hepatic congestion with tender hepatomegaly, reflecting systemic effects of impaired cardiac function.

Cheyne-Stokes respiration is a periodic breathing pattern characterized by alternating phases of hyperventilation with gradually waxing and waning tidal volumes, separated by equal periods of apnea. It occurs during sleep and in patients with severe heart disease or brain injury.

In Cheyne-Stokes respiration, the depth of breathing varies according to the CO2 level at the respiratory center, with the maximum depth of respiration occurring when CO2 is highest. Cheyne-Stokes respiration occurs due to two main mechanisms:

* Prolonged lung-to-brain circulation time - This is usually seen in heart failure. Changes in CO2 levels in the blood take longer to reach the brain’s respiratory center. By the time the low CO2 is sensed, the body has already hyperventilated, leading to apnea. This delayed feedback creates the characteristic waxing and waning pattern of Cheyne-Stokes respiration.

* Increased sensitivity of the brain to CO2 - This is mainly due to disruption of neural pathways. Even small rises in CO2 trigger excessive hyperventilation, which lowers CO2 too much and causes temporary apnea. When CO2 rises again, the cycle repeats, producing a rhythmic pattern of breathing.

Causes of Cheyne-Stokes respiration: 

* Premature infants 

* Unacclimatized persons at high altitude 

* Deep sleep in certain individuals

* Congestive cardiac failure 

* Uremia 

* Brain diseases like uncal herniation 

Other options:

Option A: Graph 1 shows a normal breathing pattern. This may be seen in the case of mild-moderate heart failure, where the patient is comfortable at rest.

Option B: Graph 2 shows Biot’s breathing, with 3–4 normal respirations followed by abrupt apnea. Seen in meningitis, raised intracranial pressure, morphine poisoning, and brainstem disease.

Option C: Graph 3 shows Kussmaul breathing, commonly seen in diabetic ketoacidosis due to metabolic acidosis, and also in sepsis, uremia, salicylate, methanol, and aldehyde poisoning.

questions.text: 169. A patient who had second-degree thermal burns with the following parts injured (front and back), as shown in the figure. Calculate the Burns percentage for the patient using the Wallace rule of 9.
questions.solution:
The affected percentage of body surface area (BSA) is calculated using Wallace's rule of 9:

* Right upper limb - 9% (Both anterior and posterior aspects being 4.5% each)

* Circumferential right lower limb - 18% (Both anterior and posterior aspects being 9% each)

Thus, totalling 27%.

Wallace rule of 9 is used for calculation of total burns surface area based on the areas of body involved in burns. Based on the Total burn surface area, the fluid resuscitation requirement can be calculated.

The following image shows Wallace's rule of 9:



Lund and Browder's chart is an accurate method to measure burns if it is used correctly. In this, different proportions of body surface areas in children are taken into consideration. This chart compensates for the changes in the shape of the body with age and can accurately assess the burn area in children.

The image below shows the Lund and Browder chart.



Pearl PM2215: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation (Updated according to ATLS 11th edition Guidelines)

Below are the formulae provided by ATLS 11th edition to calculate fluid need with a starting target rate. Subsequently, the rate of fluid provided should be adjusted based on patient response by monitoring urine output.

Category of burn Age Adjusted hourly fluid rate of Ringer’s Lactate (ml/hour) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
Thermal burns Adults & Children ≥13 years  [2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA]/16 0.5 (30-50 ml/hour)
<13 years [3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA]/16 1
≤ 1 year & Children ≤30kgs [3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA]/16 + LR containing 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
Electrical burns All ages

[4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA]/16

Children <13 years require LR containing 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate in addition

 1-1.5 (until urine clears)


Dextrose maintenance:

* 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg

* 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg

* 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24 hours = TBSA % x weight (kgs) x 4. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours. However, ATLS in its 10th edition, recommended against the use of this formula due to the concern of over-resuscitation.

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

* Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA

* Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA

* 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

* 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2

* 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: 170. Which of the following viruses show genetic change similar to the influenza virus?
questions.solution:
Rotavirus exhibit genetic reassortment similar to that of the influenza virus.

Rotaviruses appear as cartwheel-shaped structures with short spokes radiating from them. 11 segments of double-stranded RNA constitute the genome. Influenza viruses have a linear, segmented, single-stranded RNA. Reassortment of the genome occurs readily due to the presence of this segmented RNA.



Other options:

Option B - Adenovirus contains double-stranded DNA. It has icosahedral symmetry, with structures known as fibers extruding from the vertices.



Option C - Ebola viruses are filamentous viruses with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA as genetic material.



Option D - Rabies viruses belonging to the family Rhabdoviridae are bullet-shaped viruses, with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA.

questions.text: 171. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of an oxygen concentrator?

choices.text: Uses molecular sieve to selectively remove nitrogen from air
Compresses atmospheric air to store oxygen in cylinders
Chemical decomposition of water to generate oxygen gas
Uses cryogenic separation to liquefy oxygen from air

questions.solution:
The oxygen concentrator uses molecular sieve to selectively remove nitrogen from air to produce concentrated oxygen.

It use a technique called pressure swing adsorption and zeolite crystals to extract nitrogen from the air to produce oxygen with 90% to 96% purity, although purity drops to around 85% with higher flow rates. Zeolite is selective for Nitrogen. Hence, nitrogen adsorbs onto Zeolite. These devices help in providing up to 95% oxygen when there is no dedicated oxygen source

It can provide supplemental oxygen in the operating theater, ward, home oxygen therapy, rural health centers with mild hypoxia cases but most models cannot deliver more than 10 liters per minute. It delivers oxygen at pressures less than 3.4 bar (50 psi). This means they cannot power certain high-pressure medical devices like ventilators that lack a built-in turbine or compressor. As a result, their use is limited mainly to direct oxygen supply through nasal cannulas and masks in most settings.

The image below shows an oxygen concentrator:



Other options:

Option B: Oxygen concentrators do not compress or store oxygen but continuously filter it from air.

Option C: Chemical decomposition of water to generate oxygen gas is not related to the molecular sieve technology used in oxygen concentrators to concentrate oxygen.

Option D: Cryogenic separation involves cooling air to very low temperatures to liquefy oxygen, unlike the room-temperature process in concentrators.

questions.text: 172. A 30-year-old woman presents with impaired hearing. Audiometry was performed, and the results are provided below. The true statement regarding the most probable diagnosis is:

choices.text: Rinne’s test will show AC > BC
Sodium fluoride can be used for management if the Schwartze sign is negative
Poorer hearing in noisy environments compared to quiet ones
Tympanometry may be normal in early disease

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a 30-year-old female patient with impaired hearing and a pure tone audiogram showing Carhart’s notch (a dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz), suggestive of otosclerosis.  Tympanometry may be normal in otosclerosis. (Option D).

Otosclerosis is caused by bony overgrowth involving the endochondral layer of the otic capsule. It presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss, resulting in a negative Rinne’s test (BC > AC) (Option A). It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and may worsen with stress or hormonal changes, such as during pregnancy or menopause. Tympanometry shows a Type As tympanogram with reduced compliance at or near ambient air pressure, though it may be normal in early disease (Option D).

An otoscopic examination may reveal a reddish hue through the tympanic membrane, which is known as the Schwartze sign. This sign is shown in the image below:



Medical management with sodium fluoride is used in the active stage if the Schwartze sign is positive (Option B). Definitive treatment is stapedectomy or stapedotomy with prosthesis placement. 

A patient with otosclerosis experiences improved hearing in noisy environments compared to quiet ones, as people tend to speak louder in noisy settings. This phenomenon is called Paracusis of Willis (Option C).

Pearl PM1750: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its intensity can be increased or decreased by 5dB.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:

* For AC: 15 dB

* For BC: 25 dB

Symbols used in pure tone audiometry:



 

Disease Findings in PTA audiogram
Conductive hearing loss AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present
Sensorineural hearing loss Both AC and BC are abnormal and no air-Bone gap
Mixed hearing loss Both AC and BC abnormal and air-bone gap present
Presbycusis, ototoxicity, noise-induced hearing loss (higher frequencies affected first) Downsloping or descending audiogram 
Early stages of Meniere's disease (lower frequencies affected first) Upsloping or ascending audiogram
Congenital hearing loss and cochlear otosclerosis (mid-frequency hearing loss) U-shaped or trough-shaped or cookie bite shaped audiogram
Early cases of noise-induced hearing loss

Acoustic dip - characteristic dip in both AC and BC at 4000 Hz
Otosclerosis  Carhart's notch- dip at 2000 Hz in BC curve


Pearl PM0227: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: 173. Cape distribution of sensory deficit is seen in ____.
questions.solution:
Cape distribution of sensory deficit is seen in central cord syndrome. 

Central cord syndrome results from selective damage to the grey matter nerve cells crossing the spinothalamic tracts surrounding the central canal. The main etiologies include spinal trauma, syringomyelia, and intrinsic cord tumors.

In the cervical cord, the central cord syndrome is characterised by:

* Arm weakness out of proportion to leg weakness

* Dissociated sensory loss, i.e. loss of pain and temperature sensations over the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk (cape distribution)

* Preservation of light touch, joint position, and vibration sense in the shoulders, lower neck, and upper trunk

Other options: 

Option A: Brown-Sequard syndrome is characterised by a contralateral sensory deficit.

Option C: Anterior spinal artery syndrome typically presents as loss of motor function and pain/temperature sensation, with relative sparing of proprioception and vibratory sense below the level of the lesion.

Option D: Foramen magnum syndrome is characterised by an around-the-clock pattern of weakness.

questions.text: 174. A 65-year-old male patient who is on medication for benign prostatic hyperplasia was posted for cataract surgery. Intraoperatively, the surgeon noticed a floppy iris with progressive intraoperative pupillary constriction. Which of the following is the most likely drug responsible for the above features?
questions.solution:
The most likely drug responsible for the above features is tamsulosin.

The above clinical scenario, with a history of medication for benign prostatic hyperplasia and the intraoperative finding of floppy iris with progressive pupillary constriction, is suggestive of floppy iris syndrome. The causative drug for floppy iris syndrome is tamsulosin.

Tamsulosin is an α1 receptor antagonist with receptor selectivity at α1A and α1D receptors. This selectivity causes blockade of the α1A receptor in the prostate. It is used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. It has very little effect on blood pressure due to its selective effect on α1A and α1D and hence is not used in the treatment of hypertension.

Some of the adverse effects of tamsulosin include orthostatic hypotension, abnormal ejaculation, and floppy iris syndrome, characterised by the intraoperative finding of floppy iris, the propensity of iris prolapse, and progressive pupillary constriction.

Examples of other drugs causing floppy iris syndrome include finasteride, benzodiazepines, donepezil, and duloxetine. Some α1 receptor antagonists, like alfuzosin, doxazosin, and terazosin, are associated with floppy iris syndrome but have a very low risk compared to tamsulosin.

Other options:

Option B: Prazosin is an α1 receptor antagonist with equal potency to all the subtypes of α1 receptor. It is used in the treatment of hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia(BPH). Prazosin causes orthostatic hypotension after its initial dose.

Option C: Silodosin is an α1 receptor antagonist with more selectivity over the α1 subtype. It is approved in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia with lesser effects on blood pressure. The main adverse effect is retrograde ejaculation. Dizziness and orthostatic hypotension can also be seen.

Option D: Dutasteride is a 5α-reductase inhibitor that blocks the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone. It is approved for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Impotence is a documented side effect, and gynecomastia is a rare side effect.

Pearl PM2436: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

questions.text: 175. A patient presenting with non-fluent, labored speech and preserved comprehension likely has an infarction in which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points toward Broca's aphasia, which is characterized by non-fluent, labored speech with preserved comprehension, and is caused by infarction of the superior division of the middle cerebral artery.

Broca's area, or the motor speech area, is located in the inferior frontal gyrus (Brodmann areas 44 and 45) on the left dominant hemisphere. It is crucial for word formation because it communicates with nearby primary motor regions that control speech muscles.

The superior division of the middle cerebral artery supplies most of the lateral surface of the cerebral cortex, excluding the temporal lobe and the inferior parietal cortex. Infarction here can present with contralateral hemiparesis, sensory impairment, and non-fluent aphasia of Broca’s area.

Wernicke's area, or the sensory speech area, is located in the superior temporal gyrus and is supplied by the inferior division of the middle cerebral artery (option D). Wernicke's area is connected to Broca's area via the arcuate fasciculus and is responsible for comprehension. Hence, in an infarction involving the superior division of the middle cerebral artery, comprehension remains preserved.

Other options:

Option A: The posterior cerebral artery supplies the occipital and medial temporal lobes, affecting the visual association areas. It does not reach the inferior frontal gyrus, which contains Broca’s area.

Option C: The anterior cerebral artery supplies the dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes. Occlusion can cause contralateral lower limb weakness and sensory deficits.

Pearl PM0908: Aphasias and Related Conditions

  Comprehension Repetition of Spoken language Naming Fluency

Global Impaired Impaired Impaired Decreased
Conduction Preserved Impaired Impaired Preserved
Anterior (nonfluent) transcortical Preserved Preserved Impaired Impaired
Posterior (fluent) transcortical Impaired Preserved Impaired Preserved
Isolation Impaired Echolalia Impaired No purposeful speech
Anomic Preserved Preserved Impaired Preserved except for word finding pauses
Pure Word Deafness Impaired only for spoken language Impaired Preserved Preserved
Pure Alexia Impaired only for reading Preserved Preserved  Preserved


 



Pearl PM0063: Blood supply of Brain

The brain is supplied by Internal Carotid arteries and Vertebrobasilar arteries. 



Areas supplied by various arteries
Anterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves around the corpus callosum within the sagittal fissure

Supply - Dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes

Effects of occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA): 

- Contralateral Paralysis (or weakness) of muscles of the leg and foot - Upper part of motor area affected.

- Contralateral Loss (or dulling) of sensations from the leg and foot - Upper part of the sensory area affected.
Middle Cerebral Artery

Course - Runs within Sylvian fissure

Supply - Lateral convexity of the cerebral cortex

Effects of occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA):

- Contralateral Hemiplegia -  loss of sensations. The face and arms are most affected, foot and leg are spared.  

- Aphasia - Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas affected, especially if the thrombosis is in the left hemisphere in a right-handed person.  

- Contralateral Homonymous hemianopia - due to the involvement of optic radiation.  
Posterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves behind the midbrain

Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe

Effects of occlusion of posterior cerebral artery (PCA):

- Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing - Affected Cortical blood supply > Damage to association cortex of visual area causes visual hallucinations (distortion of colour vision).

Note: Macular sparing is due to collateral circulation from MCA to that cortical region.

questions.text: 176. A 25year old admitted in ICU has a heart rate of 38/min despite giving the maximum dose of atropine and subsequently developed hypotension. The clinician decided to added another drug to manage symptomatic bradycardia. Which drug should he select from the following?
questions.solution:
Dopamine is the second-line drug for symptomatic bradycardia. 

Dopamine is given as an IV infusion rate of 5-20mcg/kg per minute. Dopamine is dopaminergic (D1and D2), weaker adrenergic β1 (not β2) + very weak α receptor agonist.



Other options:

Option A: Glycopyrrolate has no role in Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS). It is primarily used as a preoperative medication to reduce salivary, tracheobronchial, and pharyngeal secretions, and to block cardiac vagal inhibitory reflexes during anesthesia induction.

Option C: MgSO4 is recommended for cardiac arrest if torsades de pointes or hypomagnesemia is suspected. 

Option D: Adenosine is the first drug for stable narrow complex SVT.

questions.text: 177. An ophthalmologist performs the swinging flashlight test, which reveals the findings as shown in the image given below. Which structure is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image above shows Marcus Gunn pupil, which is confirmed by the swinging-flashlight test. The right eye is affected, while the left eye is normal. It is the earliest sign of optic nerve/cranial nerve II disease.

The flashlight is swung to and fro and the pupillary response is observed. Normally, both pupils remain constricted. In the presence of relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), both pupils dilate on moving the flashlight from the normal to the abnormal eye. This paradoxical response of the pupil to light is called Marcus Gunn pupil.

Impaired pupillary constriction due to a defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex in one eye, causes a RAPD or a Marcus-Gunn pupil on a swinging flashlight test. 

The image given below shows the swinging flashlight test as seen in a normal person and in a patient with a right relative afferent pupillary defect.





Other abnormal pupillary reactions:

* Amaurotic light reflex - On flashing light to the affected eye, there is no direct light reflex in the affected eye, and there is no consensual light reflex in the normal eye. This occurs due to a lesion in the optic nerve or retina.

* Efferent pathway defect - Absence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the affected side and presence of both direct and consensual light reflex on the normal side. It occurs due to a defect in the efferent pathway.

* Wernicke’s hemianopic pupil -In this condition, light reflex (ipsilateral direct and contralateral consensual) is absent when light is thrown on the temporal half of the retina of the affected side and nasal half of the normal side, while it is present when the light is thrown on the nasal half of the affected side and temporal half of the normal side. It occurs due to a lesion in the optic tract.

* Adie’s tonic pupil - In this condition, the light reflex is absent and the response to near reflex is very slow and tonic. The affected pupil is larger than normal (anisocoria). It is caused by postganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor damage.

questions.text: 178. A 60-year-old patient underwent below-knee amputation 1 month ago following a road traffic accident. He now complains of severe burning pain in his amputated leg and foot. History reveals that he is suffering from clinical depression. On examination, the amputation stump is clean and healing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for the given clinical vignette is phantom limb pain. 

Phantom limb pain is the painful sensation that seems to come from a limb or body part that has already been amputated. It is different from phantom limb sensation, which refers to sensations such as tingling or warmth in the absent limb. It primarily results from extensive reorganization of the cortex and thalamus following limb amputation. Amputees with phantom limb pain might also be suffering from clinical depression or other mood disorders.

Management strategies can be diverse and include massage, ice or heat application, increased prosthetic use, relaxation training, biofeedback, sympathetic blockade, oral medications, local nerve blocks, epidural blocks, and transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS).

Additional general measures include controlling stump edema, reducing anxiety and stress, establishing good sleep hygiene, managing depression, and smoking cessation.

Other options: 

Option A: Choking of the distal stump refers to edema of the distal stump due to disruption of normal fluid balance. The affected area appears swollen and, if untreated, may develop ulceration or gangrene. Pain is usually localized to the stump rather than the amputated limb.

Option B: Residual limb pain is pain at the existing amputation stump, often due to nerve entrapment, neuroma formation, ischemia, surgical trauma, infection, or poorly fitting prosthesis. It usually occurs in the early post-amputation period and often improves as the wound heals.

Option D: Stump neuroma is a nodular mass of regenerating nerve tissue at the site of a transected peripheral nerve that is formed due to the unorganized growth of nerve fibers. It is often palpable, and Tinel’s sign (tingling sensation following percussion of the nerve) may be positive.

questions.text:
179. A 65-year-old former smoker with COPD, currently on LABA+LAMA therapy, continues to experience exacerbations. His FEV₁ is 55% of the predicted value, and his eosinophil count is 95 cells/µL. What is the next step in management?

LABA - Long-acting β-agonist LAMA - Long-acting muscarinic antagonists
questions.solution:
In a patient with COPD who is a former smoker and is on LABA+LAMA combination therapy, but continues to have exacerbations despite adherence and proper inhaler technique, and has an eosinophil count < 100 cells/µL, the addition of Azithromycin (option B) is indicated.

COPD is a progressive, preventable, and treatable respiratory disease, characterised by chronic airflow obstruction and an exaggerated inflammatory response of lung epithelium to noxious stimuli. Common risk factors include tobacco smoke, chronic exposure to coal and silica, and alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. COPD includes emphysema, chronic bronchitis, and small airway disease. The mainstay of treatment includes smoking cessation, bronchodilators, muscarinic antagonists (LAMA), beta agonists (LABA), and inhaled glucocorticoids (ICS).

In COPD, recurrent exacerbations are often precipitated by multiple factors, including bacterial infections. Azithromycin helps reduce the frequency of these episodes through its antimicrobial activity and anti-inflammatory effects, with the greatest benefit observed in former smokers with mild disease.

According to the latest GOLD 2025 guidelines for the management of COPD exacerbations:



*For patients requiring more than one inhalational agent, using a single combination inhaler offers better convenience and efficacy compared to multiple individual inhalers.

questions.text:
180. An epidemiologist is investigating an outbreak of food poisoning in a hostel. Match the data included with the best plot for each.

1. The number of new cases by time of onset, plotted hourly over a single day. a. Histogram
2. The percentage distribution of cases by type of food consumed.  b. Scatter Diagram
3. The association between the amount of food consumed and the severity of symptoms (both continuous variables). c.Pie Chart
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1–a, 2–c, 3–b.

1- a: Epidemic curve (time of onset) - Histogram

* The standard plot for an epidemic curve is a histogram, which shows the number of new cases on the y-axis and the time intervals (e.g., hourly) on the x-axis.

* This clearly depicts how cases occur over time, helping identify the pattern (point source, continuous, or propagated)

2 - c: Food item distribution - Pie Chart

* A pie chart is used for displaying the percentage or proportional distribution of a qualitative variable, here, the type of food items consumed.

* It visually shows which food item contributed most to the outbreak.

3 - b: Amount vs. severity - Scatter Diagram

* A scatter diagram (scatter plot) is best when exploring the relationship between two continuous variables, such as the amount of food eaten and the severity of symptoms.

* The pattern of points shows whether there is a correlation (positive, negative, or none).

Pearl PM0932: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

* A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.

* The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.

* The following image shows a histogram.



2. Bar Chart

* It is also called a bar graph.

* It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.

* The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.

* Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.



3. Pie Charts

* Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.

* The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.



4. Frequency polygons

* Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.

* In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.



5. Ogive

* A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.



6. Line chart

* It is also called a line diagram or line graph.

* Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.



Pearl PM1139: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

* Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).

* Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship

* Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:



Types of correlation coefficients

* Pearson coefficient

* Spearman coefficient



Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text: 181. The cerebroplacental ratio (CPR) is a parameter calculated in fetal Doppler assessment that uses two vessels. One of these is the Middle Cerebral Artery (MCA). The other vessel is:
questions.solution:
Cerebroplacental ratio (CPR) is calculated as the middle cerebral artery pulsatility index ÷ umbilical artery pulsatility index.

In cases of fetal growth restriction, there can be hypoxemia that leads to cerebral vasodilation as an adaptive fetal response. This response is assessed using the cerebroplacental ratio (CPR).

Here, MCA PI (Middle Cerebral Artery Pulsatility Index) indicates cerebral vascular resistance, and UA PI (Umbilical Artery Pulsatility Index) reflects placental resistance. A CPR <1 is abnormal and suggests fetal compromise or fetal growth restriction.

questions.text:
182. A 25-year-old man and a 22-year-old woman are both employed as nurses in a busy hospital ward, engaging in moderate physical activity throughout their shifts. According to the 2020 ICMR guidelines, which of the following daily calorie intake recommendations is most appropriate for each individual?

ICMR: Indian Council of Medical Research
questions.solution:
According to the 2020 ICMR calorie recommendations for Indians, the recommended daily calorie intake for moderate physical activity is 2710 kcal for an adult man and 2130 kcal for an adult woman.

Current recommendations are based on the principle that energy requirements must be assessed in terms of energy spent in daily activities. Adult men and women are thus classified into separate categories based on the nature of their work. This includes sedentary, moderate, and heavy work. The daily energy requirement increases accordingly with the category.

Dietary Reference Intakes

* Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) - The average daily dietary intake that is sufficient to meet the requirements of almost all individuals in a group

* Estimated Average Requirement (EAR) - A nutrient intake value that is estimated to meet the requirements of half the individuals in a group

The EAR for an elderly male (>60 years) is 1700 Kcal/D and for an elderly female (>60 years) is 1500 Kcal/D.

Note: There is no RDA for energy. The EAR is equivalent to Estimated Energy Requirement (EER).

questions.text: 183. Which of the following is the earliest and most common symptom in patients with rectal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The most common and earliest symptom in carcinoma rectum patients is the passage of fresh blood in or with stools.

Other symptoms include tenesmus, mucoid discharge, and altered bowel habits. The bleeding is usually bright red in colour and painless. It can be indistinguishable from haemorrhoidal bleeding, which is the most common differential diagnosis, particularly in younger patients.

Adenocarcinoma is the most common variant of rectal carcinoma.

Symptoms of rectal carcinoma include:

* Bleeding

* Mucus drainage

* Tenesmus

* Early morning diarrhoea

* Pain

* Weight loss

Modified Duke’s staging for rectal carcinoma:

A

Growth limited up to the rectal mucosa

B

B1: Tumor invading muscularis propria, no lymph node invasion.

B2: Tumors invading into or through serosa, no lymph node invasion.

C

C1: The tumour did not exceed the bowel wall, lymph node metastasis.

C2: Tumour exceeded the intestinal wall and lymph node metastasis.

D

Distant metastasis

questions.text: 184. A patient with mature senile cataract cannot count fingers when they are close to the face. What is the next step in visual acuity assessment?
questions.solution:
Perception of hand movements is the next step in assessing visual acuity. 

If the patient cannot read the top line of a Snellen distant vision chart from 1 meter, they are asked to count fingers (CF). Visual acuity is recorded as CF-3, CF-2, CF-1, or CF close to face, depending on the distance at which they can count. If the patient cannot count fingers, the examiner will check for hand movements (HM, option B). If the patient perceives hand movements, vision is recorded as HM+ve.

If the patient cannot see hand movements, the examiner will check for light perception (LP, option C). It is recorded as LP positive if the patient perceives light, and LP negative if not.

Light Perception should be followed by the projection of rays (option D) to determine the direction from which light is projected.

Other options: 

Option A: Distant and near visual acuity should be tested separately. Near vision is assessed by having the patient read the near vision chart placed 35 cm away in good lighting, testing each eye individually.

questions.text: 185. Which of the following statements regarding the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) is true?

choices.text: IFN-γ does not have any action on MHC I and MHC II promoter genes
IL-4 decreases the expression of class II MHC molecules on resting B cells.
Class I and II MHC antigen are involved in MHC restriction
Corticosteroids and prostaglandins increase the expression of MHC II molecules

questions.solution:
The true statement is that both Class I and Class II MHC antigens are involved in MHC restriction.

The importance of major histocompatibility complex (MHC) antigens in immune responses is demonstrated by the phenomenon known as MHC restriction. T cells respond to processed antigens on macrophages or other accessory cells only when the antigen is presented along with the self-MHC molecule. Both MHC class I and class II antigens are involved in this process.

Cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CD8⁺ T cells) recognize intracellular antigens on virus-infected target cells only when the target expresses the same Class I MHC molecules as the T cells. Helper T cells (CD4⁺ T cells) respond to extracellular antigens presented by macrophages or dendritic cells only when the cells display the same Class II MHC molecules. Similarly, T cells involved in delayed-type hypersensitivity require antigens to be presented with Class II MHC determinants. This selective recognition ensures that T cells respond only to antigens presented by self-MHC, which is critical for immune control.

The major histocompatibility complex (MHC) is a group of genes that code for cell surface proteins (called HLA in humans) that present pathogen-derived peptides to T cells. The gene for MHC is located on the short arm of chromosome 6, and the HLA genes are grouped into MHC class I, II, and III regions:

* MHC Class I: Presents intracellular antigens, expressed by all the nucleated cells, except mature red blood cells (which lack nuclei).  Platelets and spermatids also express low levels of MHC Class I.

* MHC Class II: Presents extracellular antigens, expressed by antigen-presenting cells.

* MHC Class III: Includes some complement components and TNF-alpha and Lymphotoxin-alpha, which do not function in antigen presentation.

The following image shows MHC Class I and MHC Class II molecules:



Other Options:

Option A: Cytokines influence MHC expression. IFN-γ activates both MHC-I and MHC-II promoter genes.

Option B: IL-4 increases the expression of class II MHC molecules on resting B cells. 

Option D: Corticosteroids and prostaglandins decrease the expression of MHC II molecules.

Pearl PM1552: MHC Classes I and II

MHC Class I

MHC Class II

Expressed on all nucleated cells (except sperms) and platelets

Expressed on antigen-presenting cells: macrophages, B lymphocytes, dendritic cells

Consist of a polymorphic α, heavy-chain, linked non-covalently to β2-microglobulin

Heterodimer consisting of non-covalently associated α and β chains, both of which are polymorphic.

α chains are encoded by three genes- HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C

Encoded by HLA-D, with subregions: HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR.

Display antigenic peptides that are derived from viral and tumor proteins

Present antigens that are internalized into vesicles, and derived from extracellular microbes 

Class I complexes are recognized by CD8+ T cells

 

Class II complexes are recognized by CD4+ T cells

Endogenous peptide is the type of antigen presented to CD8+ T cells

 Exogenous antigen is the type of antigen presented to CD4+ T cells 

Presents antigen via the cytosolic pathway

 Presents antigen via the endocytic pathway 

Antigen binding site is present between α1/α2 groove

 Antigen binding site is present between α1/β1 groove 

α3 binds to CD8 molecules on cytotoxic T cells

 β2 binds to CD4 on helper T cells

questions.text: 186. A 35-year-old man presents with profuse watery diarrhea, lower abdominal cramps, and foul-smelling stools for 2 days after returning from a trip abroad. He was treated empirically for a suspected anaerobic infection. Shortly after drinking a small amount of alcohol, he develops restlessness, palpitations, facial flushing, sweating, and headache. Which drug is most likely responsible, and what is its mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient’s symptoms after alcohol intake, like restlessness, palpitations, flushing, sweating, and headache, suggest a disulfiram-like reaction. Among the given options, the drug most likely responsible is metronidazole, used for anaerobic bacterial infections, which acts via the formation of free radicals.

Metronidazole is a nitroimidazole that leads to the formation of reactive compounds that interact with DNA, possibly disrupting its structure and inhibiting replication. Metronidazole enters microbial cells by diffusion, and in anaerobic microbes, its nitro group is reduced to a highly reactive nitro radical. This radical disrupts the organism’s DNA and acts as an electron sink, interfering with the pyruvate: ferredoxin oxidoreductase (PFOR) enzyme pathway that generates energy in anaerobes lacking mitochondria. 

Metronidazole is highly effective against anaerobic bacteria (e.g., Bacteroides, Clostridium, Fusobacterium, Peptococcus) and certain parasites. Its clinical uses include:

* C. difficile colitis

* Empiric coverage of anaerobes in intra-abdominal and skin/soft-tissue infections

* H. pylori gastritis (combined with other drugs)

* Bacterial vaginosis

A disulfiram like reaction occurs when a drug inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase, similar to disulfiram. When alcohol is combined with these drugs, acetaldehyde accumulates in the body and causes unpleasant symptoms like flushing, sweating, tachycardia, hypotension, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and headache.

Other drugs that can cause disulfiram like reactions:

* Tinidazole

* Some Cephalosporins, like Cefoperazone

* 1st generation Sulfonylureas like Tolbutamide

* Procarbazine

* Griseofulvin

Other options:

Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone and acts by inhibiting bacterial DNA gyrase. DNA gyrase is particularly important in gram-negative bacteria, where it introduces negative supercoils into the DNA to relieve torsional strain. Ciprofloxacin binds to and inhibits this enzyme, preventing the proper replication of bacterial DNA. Additionally, topoisomerase IV is the target of gram-positive bacteria, and its inhibition by ciprofloxacin prevents chromosome segregation during cell division.  However, it is not associated with disulfiram-like reactions. It can cause tendon ruptures, joint pain, gastrointestinal upset, and neurological side effects.

The following image shows the mechanism of action of various antibiotics:

questions.text: 187. A college-going student comes with complaints of muffled speech with throat pain, fever, and painful swallowing. The examination of the oral cavity reveals frank pus from tonsillar crypts. In order to drain the pus, the treating doctor should make an incision just lateral to the junction of which of the following 2 lines?

choices.text: Vertical line through superior constrictor and Horizontal line through base of uvula
Vertical line through superior constrictor and Horizontal line through tip of uvula
Vertical line through anterior pillar and Horizontal line through tip of uvula
Vertical line through anterior pillar and Horizontal line through base of uvula

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Quinsy, also known as Peritonsillar Abscess.  To drain the pus in this condition, the treating doctor should make an incision just lateral to the junction of the vertical line through the anterior pillar and the horizontal line through the base of the uvula.

Quinsy is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.

Clinical features:

* Sore throat, which is usually unilateral

* Odynophagia - The patient is unable to swallow even his own saliva, which may drool from the mouth.

* Trismus - due to spasm of the pterygoid muscles, which are in close proximity to the superior constrictor.

* Ipsilateral otalgia - due to referred pain via CN IX, which supplies both the tonsil and the ear.

* Foul breath due to sepsis in the oral cavity and poor hygiene.

* The speech is usually muffled and thick, often called “hot potato voice".

Investigations:

* Contrast-enhanced CT or MRI reveals the abscess and its extent.

* Needle aspiration of the abscess to collect pus for culture and sensitivity. Management:

Peritonsillar abscess may be cured with conservative measures, which include:

* Hospitalization

* IV fluids to combat dehydration

* Antibiotics in large IV doses, covering both aerobic and anaerobic organisms.

* Analgesics like paracetamol, or sometimes pethidine. Aspirin is avoided due to the risk of bleeding.

* Oral hygiene, maintained by hydrogen peroxide or saline mouthwashes.

If the above conservative measures fail, and a frank abscess has formed, then incision & drainage would be required.

* Incision and drainage of the abscess: A peritonsillar abscess is opened at the point of the maximum bulge above the upper pole of the tonsil or just lateral to the point of junction of the anterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of the uvula.



* Interval tonsillectomy can be done, where tonsils are removed 4–6 weeks following an attack of quinsy.

* Abscess or hot tonsillectomy: In some cases, the doctor may choose to perform tonsillectomy without draining the abscess first. The procedure carries the risk of rupture of the abscess during anaesthesia and excessive bleeding during the operation.

questions.text: 188. The government uses the following sign at public places in order to directly or indirectly alter human behavior. This is an example of which of the following approaches towards health education?
questions.solution:
The "No smoking" sign is an example of a regulatory approach.

A regulatory approach with respect to health education is defined as a government intervention, which is designed to alter human behavior either directly or indirectly. Regulations may take many forms, from prohibition to imprisonment.

Examples of this approach include The Child Marriage Restraint Act and the use of compulsory seatbelts. However, there are many failures to this approach, as some of these approaches involve areas related to personal choices as well, like diet, exercise, smoking, etc

The four approaches to health education:

* Regulatory approach

* Service approach

* Health education approach

* Primary health care approach

Other Options:

Option A: The health education approach is an intervention to provide necessary behavioral changes in people to make their own choice for a healthy life through health education. Examples of this approach are cessation of smoking, use of a safe water supply, and fertility control through health education. 

Option B: The service approach is a government intervention aimed at providing all the health services needed by the people at their doorstep so the people would use them to improve their own health. An example of this approach is the free-of-cost latrines provided by the government. But many people in the rural areas did not make use of this because its need was not felt.

Option D: The primary health care approach is an intervention with active involvement from the people in the planning and delivery of health services based on the principle of primary health care. This actually deals with community involvement and intersectoral coordination.

questions.text: 189. Which of the following NSAIDs is a preferential COX-2 inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Diclofenac is a preferential COX-2 inhibitor.

The following drugs are preferential COX-2 inhibitors that inhibit COX-2 more than COX-1:

* Diclofenac

* Nimesulide

* Aceclofenac

* Etodolac

* Meloxicam

The following drugs are selective COX-2 inhibitors that specifically block COX-2 only:

* Celecoxib

* Etoricoxib

* Parecoxib

Ibuprofen, aspirin, and flurbiprofen are non-selective COX inhibitors and block both COX-1 and COX-2 enzymes equally.

Pearl PM0523: Some Important Points about Selective COX-2 Inhibitors

They are also known as coxibs. They are different from non-selective COX inhibitors as follows:

* Fewer GI side effects as COX-1 is not inhibited

* No antiplatelet action as thromboxane A2 production is unaffected.

Adverse effects and contraindications:

* Myocardial infarction

* Stroke

* Congestive heart failure

* Hypertension

* Renal impairment.

Order of COX-2 selectivity

* Lumiracoxib > etoricoxib > rofecoxib > valdecoxib > celecoxib.

* Lumiracoxib - most selective

* Celecoxib - least selective

The only coxib which can be given parenterally is Parecoxib.

questions.text: 190. In Leriche syndrome, which bypass graft is preferred for the treatment of peripheral vascular disease?
questions.solution:
The bypass graft preferred for Leriche syndrome is the aorto-bifemoral graft.

Leriche syndrome is caused due to aortoiliac arterial obstruction. Due to involvement of the aortoiliac artery, the gonadal arteries may be affected, leading to sexual impotence in males. It is associated with bilateral claudication in the buttocks, thighs, and calves. Absent distal pulses, bruit over the aortoiliac region, and associated or isolated discomfort of the calf can also be seen.  CT angiography is the preferred investigation. 

Medical management includes exercise, smoking cessation, diabetes control, and weight loss if obese. Drugs such as HMG CoA reductase inhibitors (Statins) and antiplatelets (Clopidogrel or Aspirin) can be given.

For surgical management, bypass grafting is preferred over percutaneous transluminal angioplasty and stenting for large artery blocks. The bypass graft preferred for Leriche syndrome is the aorto-bifemoral graft.

questions.text: 191. A patient presented with complaints of growth in the anal region. On examination and biopsy, the patient was diagnosed with anal carcinoma above the pectinate line. Which lymph nodes are the first site of spread for carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Anal carcinoma above the level of the pectinate line of the anal canal spreads first into the internal iliac lymph nodes.

The anal canal measures approximately 3.8 cm in length and extends from the anorectal junction to the anus. It is divided into three parts:

* The upper mucosal part is 15 mm long, is endodermal in origin, and contains the anal columns and anal sinuses. The pectinate line marks the junction between the upper mucosal part and the middle transitional zone.

* The middle transitional zone is 15 mm long, is also lined by mucous membrane, and is ectodermal in origin. The lower boundary of this part often appears whitish and is referred to as the white line of Hilton.

* The lowest cutaneous part is 8 mm long, is lined by keratinising stratified squamous epithelium, and contains sebaceous glands.

Lymphatic drainage from the region above the pectinate line is directed to the internal iliac lymph nodes, whereas drainage from the region below this line is directed to the medial group of superficial inguinal lymph nodes. The pectinate line serves as the watershed line of the anal canal.



Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common type of anal carcinoma. It is associated with HPV (Types 16, 18, 31, 33). Typical symptoms include pain and rectal bleeding. Advanced disease may present with incontinence, altered bowel habits, pelvic pain, or fistulas.

Proctoscopy with biopsy is the diagnostic test of choice. CT abdomen and pelvis are essential to assess lymph nodes and detect metastases. Anal canal carcinoma is primarily treated with chemoradiotherapy (Nigro regimen), combining 5-FU with mitomycin C or cisplatin, followed by radiotherapy. Abdominoperineal resection (APR) is reserved for residual, recurrent tumours or complications like incontinence or fistulas.

Other options:

Option B: Lymphatic spread to the superficial inguinal nodes occurs only primarily if the tumor extends below the pectinate line.

Option C and D: Superficial femoral and para-aortic nodes are not primary drainage sites. They are involved only secondarily or in advanced disease.

Below Pectinate line

Systemic: Inferior rectal vein

To pelvic and lumbar nodes

To inguinal nodes

Nerve supply

Somatic—Inferior rectal nerves (branches of pudendal nerve )

Physiology

Sensation quickly diminishes

Sensitive to pain

Cancer

External hemorrhoids, Painful


Pearl PM2214: Lymphatic drainage of pelvic structures

LYMPH NODES STRUCTURES DRAINING

questions.text:
192. A 17-year-old female patient has not attained menarche. Examination reveals short stature, webbed neck, low posterior hairline, widely spaced nipples, no axillary or pubic hair, and normal external genitalia. USG abdomen shows a small uterus and streak ovaries. FSH and LH are increased. What is the likely cause of amenorrhea?

USG - Ultrasound

FSH - Follicle-stimulating hormone

LH - Luteinizing hormone
questions.solution:
The likely cause of amenorrhea in this patient is primary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. 

Primary amenorrhea refers to the failure of the onset of menstruation, beyond the age of 16 years, regardless of the development of secondary sexual characteristics. This patient's clinical picture of amenorrhea, short stature, webbed neck, low posterior hairline, widely spaced nipples, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics is seen in Turner's syndrome. Turner's syndrome is a chromosomal abnormality with partial or complete monosomy of the X chromosome (45+XO).

In Turner's syndrome, gonadal dysgenesis causes primary ovarian failure, that is hypogonadism. The levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), and luteinizing hormone (LH) are indicative of the cause of hypogonadism. Increased levels of FSH and LH, as seen in this patient, are indicative of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism. Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism is defined as 1) a decrease or absence in ovarian function and 2) due to absent negative sex-steroid feedback. 

The pathophysiology in Turner's syndrome is primary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, where there is oocyte atresia and the replacement of ovaries by fibrous streaks. This causes a decrease in serum estrogen levels which, by negative feedback, causes a rise in gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), FSH, and LH (gonadotropic hormones) as seen in this patient. Hypogonadism with a rise in gonadotropic hormones is known as hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

Other options:

Option B: Secondary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism patients also present with primary ovarian failure with increased levels of FSH and LH. Secondary hypergonadotropic hypogonadism is seen in damage to the gonads, as seen post-chemotherapy, radiation, infection, or in autoimmune disorders. This patient has no history suggestive of a secondary cause.

Option C: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism results when there is a primary abnormality in the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. Loss of hypothalamic function causes a decrease in the production of GnRH, or pituitary dysfunction causes decreased production of FSH and LH, which results in decreased ovarian function and reduced serum estrogen levels. Inherited hypothalamic abnormality, like Kallmann's syndrome, is an example.

Option D: Functional(acquired) hypothalamic dysfunction is seen with eating disorders, in patients who exercise excessively, and during periods of stress.

questions.text: 193. Which of the following activities is the Anganwadi Worker (AWW) responsible for performing?

choices.text: To assist in preparation of Village Health Plan
Maintain and update Eligible Couple Register
Conduct home deliveries for pregnant women

questions.solution:
The Anganwadi Worker (AWW) plays a supportive role in community-level planning, which includes assisting ASHA and ANM in the preparation of the Village Health Plan.

Services provided by Anganwadi Workers under ICDS (Integrated Child Development Services) include the following:

* Supplementary nutrition

* Infant & Young Child feeding (IYCF) Promotion & Counselling

* Maintenance of the growth chart

* Immunisation- organising sessions and mobilizing mothers

* Refer sick children, pregnant/ lactating mothers to subcentre, PHC/CHCs

* Non-formal preschool education

* Health and nutrition education

* Health check-up

* Depot Holder of Medicine Kit/Contraceptives of ASHA & under ICDS.

* Counsel women on safe institutional delivery

* Assist in organizing Village Health Day and Village Health Plan.

Other options:

Option B. Maintain and Update the Eligible Couple Register is primarily the job of the ANM, often supported by the ASHA. The AWW’s registers focus on growth charts, supplementary nutrition, and preschool attendance, not reproductive couple tracking.

Option C: The AWW is not a trainer for skilled birth attendants. Training SBAs is done by qualified health professionals at higher levels.

Option D. The AWW is not trained or authorised to conduct deliveries. This is done by a Skilled Birth Attendant (ANM/SBA) or at an institution. The AWW’s role is to encourage institutional delivery and mobilise mothers.

questions.text:
194. According to WHO, which of the following indicators is used to calculate both HDI and PQLI?

HDI - Human Development Index PQLI - Physical Quality of Life Index
questions.solution:
Literacy is used in the measurement of both HDI and PQLI.

The components of the Human Development Index (HDI) include life expectancy at birth, literacy, and standard of living.

Human Development Index (HDI) is a measure of a country's average achievements in three dimensions of human development:

* A long and healthy life, as measured by life expectancy at birth

* Knowledge (literacy), as measured by mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling, and

* A decent standard of living, as measured by GNI (gross national income) per capita

HDI values range from 0 to 1, with 1 as the maximum value.

Life expectancy at 1 year, literacy and infant mortality rate are components of the Physical quality of life index (PQLI).

Pearl PM0134: HDI vs. PQLI

 

Human Development Index (HDI)

 Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI)
Components

Longevity (Life expectancy at birth)

A decent standard of living (Real GNI per capita in PPP US$)

Knowledge (mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling)

Life expectancy at 1 year of age 

Infant Mortality rate

Literacy rate
Range 0 to +1 0 to 100

questions.text: 195. Which type of cataract is associated with galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency?
questions.solution:
Oil droplet cataract is associated with galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency. 

Classical galactosaemia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT). Normally, newborns receive a major part of their calorie intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). Without GALT, the infant cannot metabolize galactose 1-phosphate, which accumulates and causes injury to various organs. 

This condition is often associated with the development of bilateral cataracts, which appear as oil droplet-like central lens opacities. If diagnosed early, the lens changes may be reversible, and the onset of cataracts can be prevented by eliminating milk and dairy products from the diet.

questions.text: 196. A child who has been saved from a human trafficking ring has been subjected to a medical examination. The child has no recollection of his identity. His age is estimated to be around 14 years. Which of the following bones from this X-ray helps in the confirmation of this child's age?
questions.solution:
From the given X-ray, the first metacarpal and pisiform help in confirming this child's age. The child's age is estimated to be between 12 to 17 years. 

In the X-ray photograph of the wrist and hand, the lower epiphysis of the first metacarpal is not united with the shaft. The epiphyses of the metacarpal bones fuse with the shaft between the ages of 15 to 17 years. The pisiform has ossified. This makes the minimum age of the child 12 years. Hence, the child's age will be between 12 and 17 years.

Hence, the pisiform and metacarpals help in estimating the age of the child in this case. 

Ossification centres of carpal bones:

* Capitate: 1–3 months

* Hamate:  2–4 months

* Triquetral: 2–3 years

* Lunate: 3–4 years

* Scaphoid: 4–6 years

* Trapezium: 5-6 years

* Trapezoid: 5–6 years

* Pisiform: 10–12 years

The lower end of the radius appears at 2 years of age and fuses at 18–19 years of age. The lower end of the ulna appears at 5–6 years of age and fuses at 17–18 years of age. Here, both remain unfused indicating further that the age is likely to be less than 18 years.

questions.text: 197. A 45-year-old female presents with complaints of groin swelling. On examination, a globular swelling below and lateral to the pubic tubercle is seen. No tenderness or redness is present. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Lacunar ligament prevents the reduction of the sac
Sac lies lateral to femoral vein
There is high risk of strangulation

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a groin swelling present lateral and below the pubic tubercle is suggestive of a femoral hernia. Femoral hernia traverses the femoral canal, which lies medial to the femoral vein.

A femoral hernia occurs in both males and females, but it is more common in females. It will pass through the femoral ring proximally to enter the femoral canal. The femoral canal is bound by the femoral vein laterally, the inguinal ligament anteriorly, and the pelvic bone with the iliopectineal ligament (Cooper's) and lacunar ligament (Gimbernat's) medially. The lacunar ligament has a sharp, unyielding edge that prevents the reduction of the femoral hernia. The incidence of strangulation in femoral hernias is high because of the narrowness of the neck of the sac and the rigidity of the femoral ring.

All patients with unexplained bowel obstruction should be examined properly for a femoral hernia. Surgery is the only treatment for femoral hernia, and these patients should be treated on a priority basis because of the high risk of strangulation. The surgical approaches that are used are:

* Low approach (Lockwood): suitable when there is no risk of strangulation; bowel can't be inspected and resected in this approach

* Inguinal approach (Lotheissen)

* High approach (McEvedy): suitable for emergency situations when the risk of bowel strangulation is high

* Laparoscopic approach: both TEP and TAPP approaches can be used; the laparoscopic approach is recommended in women

Pearl PM1050: Anatomy of Femoral Canal



Pearl PM1053: Variants of femoral hernia

Laugier’s femoral hernia:

* Through a gap in lacunar (Gimbernat) ligament.

* Always strangulated

Narath’s femoral hernia:

* Seen in patients with congenital dislocation of hip

* It is behind the femoral vessels

Cloquet’s hernia:

* Sac lies under pectineus fascia.

Hesselbach’s hernia:

* Lateral to femoral artery

Serafini's hernia:

* Behind the femoral vessels

Velpeau(Prevascular/Teale's) hernia:

* Infront of femoral vessels

Beclard’s hernia:

* Through saphenous opening

Pearl PM1052: Surgeries for femoral hernia

* Lockwood’s low inguinal surgery

* McEvedy’s high inguinal surgery – preferred in emergency where risk of bowel infarction is high

* Lotheissen’s inguinal surgery

* Henry procedure – Mid abdominal Extraperitoneal Femoral Hernioplasty

* McVay – for both femoral and inguinal hernia

questions.text: 198. A 14-year-old male patient presents with pain around the knee joint. His radiographic image is given below. All of the following statements are true regarding his condition, except that _____.

choices.text: It is the most common primary malignant bone tumor.
First-line agents used in neoadjuvant therapy are doxorubicin and cisplatin.
Wide excision is used in the management.

questions.solution:
The given scenario and the X-ray image showing sunburst appearance and Codman's triangle in the proximal tibia are suggestive of osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the bone, with a bimodal age of distribution peaking in adolescence and during the 7th decade.

The most common site involved is the distal femoral metaphysis, which mainly presents with pain and swelling. Other sites commonly involved are the proximal tibia, proximal femur, and humerus.

X-rays are diagnostic, showing Codman’s triangle (new bone formation in response to periosteal elevation) and a ‘sunburst’ appearance when the periosteum does not have enough time to lay down a new layer. 

Wide excision and reconstruction are preferred if the tumor is resectable and there are no skip lesions. It is done after starting neoadjuvant chemotherapy for 8-12 weeks. Chemotherapeutic agents used are doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide, and methotrexate.

questions.text:
199. What is the device shown in the image given below used for?

HDR - High dose rate
questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a remote afterloader. Remote afterloading is related to brachytherapy.

Brachytherapy is a method of treatment in which sealed radioactive sources are used to deliver radiation at a short distance by interstitial, intracavitary, or surface application.

The following isotopes are used in brachytherapy:

* Iodine-125 and Iridium-192 are used in low-dose rate (LDR) brachytherapy. 

* Cobalt-60 is used for high-dose rate (HDR) brachytherapy.

Afterloading is the process of placing the radioactive material into the target region. This is either done manually by the oncologist or by using remote afterloading devices.

Remote afterloading devices enable us to eliminate direct contact with radioactive sources during administration. It protects healthcare professionals from radiation exposure by securing the radiation source in a shielded, safe manner.

questions.text: 200. A 30-year-old primigravida did not know that she was pregnant until she began to show. She has not had any previous antenatal visits and has never taken iron or folic acid supplements. Which of the following is likely to be elevated on the quad screen in the condition that her fetus is at risk of developing?
questions.solution:
Folic acid (Vitamin B9) deficiency is directly associated with neural tube defects, which is reflected by an increase in maternal serum alpha feto-protein levels (MSAFP).

Quadruple testing is done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. It comprises:

* Maternal serum AFP

* Human chorionic gonadotropin

* Unconjugated estriol (E3)

* Dimeric inhibin A

The following table summarizes the findings of the quad-screening test in various conditions.

Parameter Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect 
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Normal/Low Normal

Note 1: Prophylaxis with iron should be withheld in case of acute illness (fever, diarrhea, pneumonia, etc.) and in a known case of thalassemia major/ history of repeated blood transfusion. In cases of children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM), IFA supplementation should be continued as per the SAM management protocol.

Note 2: All women in the reproductive age group in the pre-conception period and up to the first trimester of the pregnancy are advised to have 400 mcg of folic acid tablets, daily, to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects in the fetus.
